curator.about:
About the Curator
Mateo Askaripour’s work aims to empower people of color to seize opportunities for advancement, no matter the obstacle. He was a 2018 Rhode Island Writers Colony writer-in-residence, and his writing has appeared in Entrepreneur, Lit Hub, Catapult, The Rumpus, Medium, and elsewhere. Black Buck is his debut novel. He lives in Brooklyn.
curator.name: Amy Maoz

collections.description: Start-up implosions, comically hubristic CEOs, and corporate-sanctioned white privilege. All are fodder for Mateo Askaripour’s Black Buck, a gripping, darkly hilarious debut novel that dials up the drama and intrigue of tech news to funhouse-mirror proportions.
collections.subtitle: Mateo Askaripour shares a mixtape of his inspirations, from Malcolm X to McKinsey & Company, that fueled his razor-sharp satire on race and corporate America, “Black Buck.”

collections.description: There is so much more to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy than his iconic “I Have a Dream” speech — and so many ways to honor his memory on what would have been his 92nd birthday. We’ve gathered some of his greatest speeches and letters, from the most notable to the lesser-known, as well as tributes and remembrances from more than 50 years of journalism about the civil rights icon. Plus, ideas for how to be of service to your community, this week and all year round.

collections.description: In polarized times, it’s tempting to retreat further into our echo chambers. Instead, consider how much we all have to gain by connecting with those who see things differently than we do. We’ve brought together some of the best advice on how to have a productive conversation with someone you disagree with, as well as proven tips for how to change someone’s mind, and the science behind how our brains process different methods of persuasion. <br data-highlightable="1" /><br data-highlightable="1" />Whether you’re trying to see eye to eye with a colleague, repair a relationship, or attempt to untangle a loved one’s problematic beliefs, our guide will arm you with the techniques you need.<br data-highlightable="1" />

collections.description: Hank Aaron, one of the greatest baseball players of all time, died in January at age 86. The Atlanta Braves slugger known as Hammerin’ Hank smashed Babe Ruth’s home run record in 1974 by hitting his 715th career homer on his way to 755. But Aaron, who started his career in the segregated Negro Leagues, paid a bitter price for dethroning the white home run king, facing racist threats and abuse every step of the way. “If I was white, all America would be proud of me,” Aaron once said as he was closing in on Ruth. “But I am Black.”
collections.subtitle: Remembering the life and legacy of an American hero who was bigger than sports.

collections.description: Some feelings and experiences can't be summed in a single word—at least in English. Luckily, if there’s one thing the English language is good at, it’s borrowing. You’ve probably felt the guilty pleasure of schadenfreude—the German word for experiencing joy at others’ misfortune. Or curled up on the couch for some hygge—the Norwegian concept of contented coziness. But what about ikigai and mamihlapinatapai? When you sit down for a meal, are you looking forward to the sobremesa or the shemomechama?

collections.description:
On February 2nd, winter-weary citizens in the United States and Canada turn toward an unlikely prophet for succor: Marmota monax, commonly known as the woodchuck or groundhog. Tradition holds that if the groundhog emerges from its den and sees its own shadow, there will be six more weeks of winter. No shadow means an early spring.

Why exactly is there a holiday centered around the prognosticating powers of an oversized ground squirrel? Read on to explore the origins and history of Groundhog Day, including how it relates to actual groundhog biology. But if you’re more interested in the classic 1993 Bill Murray film Groundhog Day, well, we’ve got you covered there, too.
collections.subtitle: Everything you ever wanted to know about one of North America’s weirdest traditions (and also the Bill Murray classic).
collections.title: Everything you ever wanted to know about one of North America’s weirdest traditions (and also the Bill Murray classic).

collections.description: As a chef, I’m always on the lookout for inspiration and new recipes to try out, and I love getting to collect the best recipes from fellow chefs. I don’t have subscriptions to all different cooking outlets, nor do I have enough time in the day to read through all of them honestly. The ones I do find and I can’t wait to make, I save to my Pocket app. With a simple click, I can save them and read them back whenever I want. It’s also an incredibly helpful tool for keeping track of my own recipes. These are some of my favorites for the holidays.

curator.about:
About the Curator
Jill Chang is currently the Asia Pacific network manager of Give2Asia, an international nonprofit organization. She has over fifteen years of experience working in cross-disciplinary marketing across sectors, including working with Major League Baseball, the US government, long-term medical care providers, international businesses, and international public welfare strategy consultants. She is a graduate of leadership programs at Harvard University and Tsinghua University in Beijing.
curator.name: Amy Maoz

collections.description: Historically, the workplace has been set up in a way for extroverts to thrive. Now, with record numbers of office workers punching in from home, often on their own, there’s an opportunity to find success in new ways and tap into different aspects of our personalities.

curated_info.title: 9 Shocking Things That Happen To Your Brain When You Get A Phone Or Email Notification

curated_info.author: Ezra Klein
curated_info.excerpt: “Technology feels disempowering because we haven’t built it around an honest view of human nature,” says tech critic Tristan Harris.
curated_info.title: Tristan Harris on How Facebook and Twitter Bring Out the Worst In Us [LISTEN]

curated_info.author: Simon Parkin
curated_info.excerpt: Silicon Valley is keen to exploit the brain chemical credited with keeping us tapping on apps and social media.
curated_info.title: Has Dopamine Got Us Hooked on Tech?

curated_info.author: Julie Shiels
curated_info.excerpt: Every moment of potential boredom can now be ameliorated or avoided by all manner of tasks, modes of entertainment or other distractions conveniently provided courtesy of our mini computer and bodily prosthetic.
curated_info.title: Waiting: Rediscovering Boredom in the Age of the Smartphone

curated_info.author: Kira M. Newman
curated_info.excerpt: Time away from Facebook has its ups and downs, research suggests—so Kira Newman gave it a shot.
curated_info.title: What Happens When You Take a Facebook Break

curated_info.author: Larry Rosen
curated_info.excerpt: Why does anxiety about needing to stay in contact negatively impact sleep?
curated_info.title: Relax, Turn Off Your Phone, and Go to Sleep

curated_info.author: Elle Hunt
curated_info.excerpt: The author and artist’s keynote address on our fractured attention spans went viral. Now she has a plan for how to heal them: lose ourselves in nature.
curated_info.title: Jenny Odell on Why We Need To Learn To Do Nothing: ‘It's a Reminder That You're Alive’

curated_info.author: Jeremy Hobson and Serena McMahon
curated_info.excerpt: “Something's in the air. I think people are finally getting fed up with how much of their humanity they're losing to always staring at these screens.”
curated_info.title: 'Digital Minimalism': How To Hang Up On Your Phone Addiction [LISTEN]

curated_info.author: Amelia Abraham
curated_info.excerpt: Screen time has skyrocketed as we all stay inside to combat the pandemic, but now more than ever is an opportunity to disconnect.
curated_info.title: Expert Advice on How To Digital Detox in Self-Isolation

curated_info.author: Tiffany Shlain
curated_info.excerpt: In this excerpt from her book ‘24/6,’ filmmaker author Tiffany Shlain explains how she manages her social media use to keep it happy, not stressful.
curated_info.title: How To Use Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter Less

curated_info.author: Brian X. Chen
curated_info.excerpt: Excessive screen time can be harmful to our well-being, but we can free ourselves from tech’s hooks with goals, rules and boundaries.
curated_info.title: It’s Time for a Digital Detox. (You Know You Need It.)

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Grace Saunders
curated_info.excerpt: Pre-quarantine, you likely thought that you spent almost all of your workday at the computer. But little did you know that you could spend so much more.
curated_info.title: 5 Tips to Reduce Screen Time While You're WFH

curated_info.author: Pam Belluck
curated_info.excerpt: This article, from 1996, was one of the first to explore a then-emerging issue. As one doctor in the piece says, ''I think we're about a year away from having people recognize it's really a problem. It's out there. There's no question.''
curated_info.title: BONUS READ: The Symptoms of Internet Addiction

collections.description: Yes, you’re reading this on a screen. And yes, this guide is brought to you by the app Pocket, so we can hardly preach about the need to convert to an entirely off-the-grid, device-free lifestyle.
collections.subtitle: A primer on the benefits of cutting back on screen time — and tips on how to get started in a way that works for you.
collections.title: A primer on the benefits of cutting back on screen time — and tips on how to get started in a way that works for you.

collections.description: Resolutions don’t have to be reinventions. You can set yourself up for a healthier, more fulfilled year by setting manageable goals that add up.
collections.subtitle: The world is unpredictable. But you have the power to set yourself up for better days ahead.
collections.title: The world is unpredictable. But you have the power to set yourself up for better days ahead.

curated_info.author: David Balzer
curated_info.excerpt: Jeremy D. Larson: “This is one of those essays that lights up every part of my brain and takes a totally new and remarkably challenging path to the summit. It's about our relationship to technology but its spokes include: early computing, proto synthesizers, James Joyce, a deep dive into Bulgarian folk music, and Prince. All in service of trying to dissect Kate Bush's broken heart on one song from her 1989 album. A dazzling read.”
curated_info.title: I Press Execute

curated_info.author: Ed Caesar
curated_info.excerpt: Josh Dean: “I'll read anything Ed Caesar writes. But this was my kind of story. A slightly niche-y subject with a great character at the center and a fascinating world to dive into. I'd probably read a book on this.”
curated_info.title: The Woman Shaking Up the Diamond Industry

curated_info.author: Ben Blum
curated_info.excerpt: Rhaina Cohen: “This deeply-reported piece did more than introduce me to a new form of therapy and the patients being treated by it. It gave me a new framework for understanding the mind, one that I think can help all of us make sense of the seemingly warring factions within us — the part of us that wants to be in tune with our body and the part that's compelled to down a pint of ice cream; the part of us that's confident, and the part that tells us we're incapable.”
curated_info.title: Inside the Revolutionary Treatment That Could Change Psychotherapy Forever

curated_info.author: Britni de la Cretaz
curated_info.excerpt: Julia Sklar: “I loved this story by Britni de la Cretaz about a queer and trans wrestling league in Boston, because it shows how compelling sports can be when they exist outside a gendered and capitalist framework. They write about how a league like this not only opens the literal playing field to people and bodies traditionally excluded from both the athleticism and performance of sports but also makes room for a fanbase similarly excluded from safely watching sports or stepping foot in an arena. Britni has been reporting on sports in this sort of framework-busting way for a long time, and we need more sports writers like them!”
curated_info.title: The Rowdy Queer and Trans Wrestling League BLOWW-ing Stereotypes Away

curated_info.author: Graeme Wood
curated_info.excerpt: James Hamblin : “A poignant meditation on the happiest place on earth.”
curated_info.title: I Went to Disney World

curated_info.author: Jesse Frederik
curated_info.excerpt: Rutger Bregman: “This is a brilliant article by the investigative journalist Jesse Frederik in which he savagely bursts the blockchain-hype. As a developer says in this piece: ‘You could also use a forklift to put a six-pack of beer on your kitchen counter. But it’s just not very efficient.’”
curated_info.title: Blockchain, the Amazing Solution for Almost Nothing

curated_info.author: Jiayang Fan
curated_info.excerpt: Andy Greenberg: “When I heard this piece in February, the horrors of the novel coronavirus that it captured through the story of the eccentric Chinese video blogger Chen Qiushi were eye-opening. Like most Americans, I had no idea those same horrors were about to arrive in the U.S., and particularly my hometown of New York. For the last nine months, the details Chen captured in Wuhan have continued to resonate with me as my first real warning of what was to come, in the form of a perfectly constructed radio story.”
curated_info.title: Mr. Chen Goes to Wuhan [LISTEN]

curated_info.author: Laura Bauer and Judy L. Thomas
curated_info.excerpt: Dan Hurley: “ The Kansas City Star ran an extraordinary series of articles about the awful state of Kansas's department of child protection. It's shocking and eye-opening. The kind of investigative journalism that should win a Pulitzer.”
curated_info.title: Throwaway Kids: ‘We Are Sending More Foster Kids To Prison Than College’

curated_info.author: Patricia Lockwood
curated_info.excerpt: R. Eric Thomas: “No one writes like Patricia Lockwood, mixing humor and sharp observations and a dizzying sense of chaos in a seemingly effortless way. I've found myself thinking about her July reflection on her experience after contracting coronavirus and encountering Covid deniers a lot lately. Like so much of her writing, it seems prophetic now, filled to the brim with black humor and uncomfortable truth.”
curated_info.title: Insane After Coronavirus?

curated_info.author: Dahlia Lithwick
curated_info.excerpt: Aymann Ismail: “A few months before she passed, Ruth Bader Ginsburg sat for an interview with my colleague, Dahlia Lithwick. Justice Ginsburg walked us through intimate details of her time in law school, and the few other women in her class. It's beautifully written and really feels like one of those pieces that will need to be archived. Truly a masterful and timeless work.”
curated_info.title: “It’s Amazing to Me How Distinctly I Remember Each of These Women”

curated_info.author: Francesca Mari
curated_info.excerpt: Zach Baron: “This story by Francesca Mari is a lovely tribute to the person who raised her and what happened to him and his business when the pandemic arrived; it's also a frank and unsparing look at the reality behind all the quaint local shops that we say we adore, even as many of us heedlessly participate in the larger systems that help destroy them.”
curated_info.title: What My Dad Gave His Shop

curated_info.author: Jeffrey Ladish
curated_info.excerpt: Ben Taub: “It has been a year in search of small comforts, and one of them, it turns out, is that even an all-out nuclear war targeting population centers and optimizing for the maximization of death is unlikely to cause human extinction. ‘It would be almost impossible to kill every human via radiation with the existing nuclear arsenals, even if they were targeted explicitly for this purpose,’ the biologist and security consultant Jeffrey Ladish writes, in this fascinating post on LessWrong . Starvation by loss of agriculture, in a climate-altering nuclear winter, ‘would likely kill most people on earth,’ he continues — but not everyone. I sleep better already.”
curated_info.title: Nuclear War Is Unlikely To Cause Human Extinction

curated_info.author: Jack Nicas
curated_info.excerpt: Mark Seal: “This was the most memorable article I read and passed along this year. Because it said everything about 2020: Coronavirus, fear, Purell, hoarding, desperation and a world in flames.”
curated_info.title: He Has 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer and Nowhere to Sell Them

curated_info.author: Casey Cep
curated_info.excerpt: Elizabeth Weil: “This is one of the purest, loveliest reading experiences I had all year — and so exactly what my COVID-addled nerves needed. Marilynne Robinson is a miracle of a writer and Casey Cep captures her perfectly. ‘One of Robinson’s schoolteachers told her that “one must make one’s mind a good companion, because you live with it every minute of your life,” advice that she either took to heart or never required.’”
curated_info.title: Marilynne Robinson’s Essential American Stories

curated_info.excerpt: Ed Yong’s Atlantic story, How the Pandemic Will End, was the most-read story of 2020. Here, he shares 21 of the exceptional pieces that he most admired on the pandemic beat this year.
curated_info.title: Bonus Read: Ed Yong: Must-Read Stories of the Pandemic

collections.description: The end of the year brings many feelings, so let us remind you of one of our favorites: The sensation you get when you’ve just finished reading something so captivating and spot-on that you’re itching to share it with everyone you know.

collections.description: The days are getting darker here in the northern hemisphere and so, it seems, are the Pocket community’s reading habits. November’s most-saved article in Pocket was Nicholas Thompson’s story for Wired about the mysterious death of an Appalachian Trail hiker known only as “Mostly Harmless,” a case that has become an obsession for self-styled online sleuths.
collections.subtitle: An internet mystery, Bill Gates’s interviewing strategies, and unpacking the presidential election.

collections.description: How to explain what happened to us in 2020? There has been no shortage of incredible and moving writing about what it has been like to live through the coronavirus pandemic: The bravery and exhaustion of frontline workers. The frustrations of Zoom school. The eye-watering sensation of a COVID test nasal swab. The quarantine dog adoptions. The FaceTime funerals. The fear. The loneliness. The boredom. The gallows humor. The surprising moments of comfort and joy (and millions of loaves of banana bread). The unbearable grief.
collections.subtitle: The most unforgettable first-person essays and on-the-ground reports that told the story of coronavirus in 2020.
collections.title: The most unforgettable first-person essays and on-the-ground reports that told the story of coronavirus in 2020.

collections.description: Protecting kids’ digital privacy has gotten more challenging every year—and that was before 2020 introduced families to virtual schooling, digital homework, and Zoom playdates. Connectivity is seeping into every part of children’s lives, from the toys that now come with built-in Bluetooth or WiFi connections to the smart devices they encounter at home.
collections.subtitle: What to know about the security of connected devices, and how to steer kids toward the best digital practices.

curated_info.author: Megan Gambino

curated_info.title: What Was on the Menu at the First Thanksgiving?

curated_info.author: Jenny Jarvie
curated_info.excerpt: In the runup to the Civil War, there was strong resistance in the South toward Thanksgiving itself.
curated_info.title: In America, There Was a Time When Even ‘Thanksgiving’ Was a Fightin’ Word

curated_info.author: Barbara Maranzani
curated_info.excerpt: The author of the children's poem "Mary Had a Little Lamb" was persistent in arguing that establishing the national November holiday could help heal wounds from the Civil War.
curated_info.title: How the 'Mother of Thanksgiving' Lobbied Abraham Lincoln to Proclaim the National Holiday

curated_info.author: Lorraine Boissoneault
curated_info.excerpt: The history of Cucurbita pepo has a surprising connection to the abolitionist cause.
curated_info.title: How the Formerly Ubiquitous Pumpkin Became a Thanksgiving Treat

curated_info.author: Megan Garber
curated_info.excerpt: Before trick-or-treating came along, there was "Thanksgiving masking" and "Ragamuffin Day.”
curated_info.title: People Used to Celebrate Thanksgiving Like We Now Celebrate Halloween

curated_info.author: Eliza McGraw
curated_info.excerpt: This was, first lady Grace Coolidge later wrote, “no ordinary raccoon.”
curated_info.title: This Raccoon Could Have Been a President’s Thanksgiving Meal. It Became a White House Pet Instead

curated_info.author: Lina Zeldovich
curated_info.excerpt: Tofu turkey was created in 1990, but some Americans celebrated Thanksgiving with veggie dishes over a century ago.
curated_info.title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving Dates Back to the 1900s

curated_info.author: Anne Ewbank
curated_info.excerpt: Before Friendsgiving, there was Franksgiving.
curated_info.title: For Years, Republican and Democratic States Held Separate Thanksgivings

curated_info.author: Kenzie Bryant and Jordan Amchin
curated_info.excerpt: Come on a trip through America’s second-most absurd tradition, right after the Electoral College.
curated_info.title: The Long, Absurd History of Presidential Turkey Pardonings

curated_info.author: Jason Diamond
curated_info.excerpt: How John Hughes made a 1987 buddy comedy/road movie that doubles as a rare Turkey Day classic.
curated_info.title: Why ‘Planes, Trains and Automobiles’ Is the Ultimate Thanksgiving Movie

curated_info.author: Paul Musgrave
curated_info.excerpt: In 1997, the former Soviet leader needed money, and Pizza Hut needed a spokesman. Greatness ensued.
curated_info.title: Mikhail Gorbachev’s Pizza Hut Thanksgiving Miracle

curated_info.author: Amy Maoz
curated_info.excerpt: Cultivating gratitude can improve your life, rewire your brain, and influence those around you. Here’s how to get started.
curated_info.title: How to Be Grateful

curated_info.author: Avery Cullinan
curated_info.excerpt: From Ben Franklin to visual prowess, here are nine reasons to talk turkey.
curated_info.title: 9 Fun Facts About Turkeys

collections.description: Thanksgiving is probably a little different for most of us this year. But if it’s any consolation, the Great Zoom Thanksgiving of 2020 is actually part of a long tradition of autumnal weirdness. Lean into the strangeness (and impress your remote dinner guests) with this collection of surprising Thanksgiving histories, from how eels were served at the first Thanksgiving to the time that Mikhail Gorbachev cut a Pizza Hut ad on Thanksgiving Day.
collections.subtitle: Dig into this collection of fascinating Thanksgiving reads while you’re waiting for dinner to cook.
collections.title: Dig into this collection of fascinating Thanksgiving reads while you’re waiting for dinner to cook.

curated_info.author: Jeremy Gordon
curated_info.excerpt: The Foo Fighters leader and the English prodigy struck up a competitive friendship on social media that has brought them, and thousands of music fans, immense joy.
curated_info.title: Dave Grohl, 10-Year-Old Nandi Bushell and One Very Epic Drum Battle

curated_info.author: Alex W. Palmer
curated_info.excerpt: When the country shut down and the highways thinned out, a stealthy group of amateur car obsessives glimpsed an opportunity to revive the fabled cannonball run—the highly daring, absurdly illegal cross-country endurance race. And in the record-breaking frenzy that followed, they became legends of the unlikeliest pastime of the pandemic age.
curated_info.title: The Incredible Story of the Great Cannonball Boom

curated_info.author: A.C. Shilton
curated_info.excerpt: “I wanted them to know James’s heart was safe, that I was going to do everything I could to protect it.”
curated_info.title: Their Son’s Heart Saved His Life. So He Rode 1,426 Miles to Meet Them.

curated_info.author: Chris Stokel-Walker
curated_info.excerpt: When Jay Flynn was homeless, he packed up his worldly belongings every morning so that London tourists wouldn't see his plight. Now he's being watched by millions across the world, and raising hundreds of thousands of pounds for charity in the process. This is how he did it.
curated_info.title: How One Man Created The Biggest Virtual Pub Quiz In The World

curated_info.author: KC Ifeanyi
curated_info.excerpt: Writer-director David E. Talbert explains why it took his wife and son, free rein from Netflix, and 22 years to create the holiday movie of his dreams.
curated_info.title: Why It Took David E. Talbert Two Decades to Make ‘Jingle Jangle,’ His Black Christmas Classic

curated_info.author: Lauren Michele Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: A voice for working-class women and an icon for all kinds of women, Parton has maintained her star power throughout life phases and political cycles. Save Bonus Read: Dolly Parton Helped Fund Moderna’s Vaccine. It Began With a Car Crash and an Unlikely Friendship. Via The Washington Post. Save
curated_info.title: The United States of Dolly Parton

curated_info.author: Jo Marchant
curated_info.excerpt: Scientists long believed that biological clocks were predominantly driven by internal rhythms. Then came a fraught discovery—about mollusks and the moon.
curated_info.title: The Oysters That Knew What Time It Was

curated_info.author: Maria Konnikova
curated_info.excerpt: One of the world’s best players taught me his unique psychological style of play—and it worked.
curated_info.title: How I Became a Poker Champion in One Year

curated_info.author: Wesley Morris
curated_info.excerpt: A quarantine facial-hair experiment led me to a deep consideration of my Blackness.
curated_info.title: My Mustache, My Self

curated_info.author: Sarah Gilman
curated_info.excerpt: A faraway island in Alaska has had its share of visitors, but none can remain for long on its shores.
curated_info.title: The Island That Humans Can’t Conquer

curated_info.author: Nicholas Thompson
curated_info.excerpt: After 20 years of long-distance competition, I ran my fastest. All it took was tech, training, and a new understanding of my life.
curated_info.title: To Run My Best Marathon at Age 44, I Had to Outrun My Past

curated_info.author: Amanda Fortini
curated_info.excerpt: Las Vegas is both stranger and more normal than you might imagine, and for some reason, people don’t think anyone lives there.
curated_info.title: The People of Las Vegas

curated_info.author: Alix Spiegel and Elena Renken
curated_info.excerpt: For most of her life, Joy Milne had a superpower that she was totally oblivious to.
curated_info.title: Her Incredible Sense Of Smell Is Helping Scientists Find New Ways To Diagnose Disease

curated_info.author: Alex Beggs
curated_info.excerpt: Ever wonder why are we so drawn to the snap of a potato chip or the crackle of fried chicken? Biology, psychology, and an incredible amount of engineering.
curated_info.title: There’s an Entire Industry Dedicated to Making Foods Crispy, and It Is WILD

curated_info.author: John Wolfson
curated_info.excerpt: “That’s ridiculous,” Lisa Piccirillo thought when she first learned about the Conway knot problem. “We should be able to do that.”
curated_info.title: A Math Problem Stumped Experts for 50 Years. This Grad Student Solved It in Days

curated_info.author: Aishwarya Kumar
curated_info.excerpt: Tani Adewumi, 9, fled Nigeria with his family and later settled into a New York homeless shelter. Today he dreams of becoming the world's youngest chess grandmaster.
curated_info.title: From Homeless Refugee to Chess Prodigy

curated_info.author: Steven Bertoni
curated_info.excerpt: It took decades, but Chuck Feeney, the former billionaire cofounder of retail giant Duty Free Shoppers has finally given all his money away to charity. He has nothing left now—and he couldn’t be happier.
curated_info.title: The Billionaire Who Wanted To Die Broke... Is Now Officially Broke

collections.subtitle: Seventeen amazing articles that provided a respite from a year of gloom and doomscrolling.
collections.title: Seventeen amazing articles that provided a respite from a year of gloom and doomscrolling.

curated_info.author: Joshua Brown, Joel Wong
curated_info.excerpt: Research is starting to explore how gratitude works to improve our mental health.
curated_info.title: How Gratitude Changes You and Your Brain

curated_info.author: Arthur C. Brooks
curated_info.excerpt: In a nutshell, acting grateful can actually make you grateful.
curated_info.title: Choose to Be Grateful. It Will Make You Happier.

curated_info.author: Tanmeet Sethi
curated_info.excerpt: In this thought provoking talk, Tanmeet Sethi shares how the overlooked value of gratitude can have surprising health and medical benefits.
curated_info.title: Two Words That Can Change Your Life [WATCH]

curated_info.author: Kira M. Newman
curated_info.excerpt: Americans say thanks a lot, but other cultures may have a deeper understanding of gratitude.
curated_info.title: How Cultural Differences Shape Your Gratitude

curated_info.excerpt: Readers respond to Barbara Ehrenreich’s essay about “gratitude’s rise to self-help celebrity status.”
curated_info.title: Two Sides of Gratitude

curated_info.author: Richard Gunderman
curated_info.excerpt: Gratitude can be difficult to practice, but you can gain a lot from making it an everyday part of your life.
curated_info.title: How To Make Gratitude a Way of Life

curated_info.excerpt: This simple switch flips your perspective for the better.
curated_info.title: How to Be Thankful For Your Life by Changing Just One Word

curated_info.author: Chloe Anello
curated_info.excerpt: There’s really no wrong way to journal, according to our experts, but “sometimes a blank page can be really intimidating,
curated_info.title: The Best Wellness, Gratitude, and Happiness Journals, According to Therapists and Journalers

curated_info.author: Thomas Lickona
curated_info.excerpt: If you’ve been trying to make kindness part of your family culture and there’s still a lot of complaining, it’s time to take further steps to teach and practice gratitude.
curated_info.title: How to Raise Grateful Kids in an Era of Thankless People

curated_info.author: Christopher Littlefield
curated_info.excerpt: “Gratitude is an emotion that grounds us and is a great way to balance out the negative mindset that uncertainty engenders.”
curated_info.title: Use Gratitude to Counter Stress and Uncertainty

curated_info.author: Carolyn L. Todd
curated_info.excerpt: Now seems like as good a time as any, right?
curated_info.title: 4 Small Ways to Practice Gratitude Every Day

curated_info.author: Larissa Pham
curated_info.excerpt: Thoughts on gratitude.
curated_info.title: Column of Light

curated_info.author: Mary Kaye Schilling
curated_info.excerpt: the “Great Coffee Gratitude Trail,” a project that has become his sixth book, Thanks a Thousand,
curated_info.title: A.J. Jacobs Thanked One Thousand People For His Morning Coffee—He Likes It That Much

curated_info.author: Gina Hamadey
curated_info.excerpt: Instead of scrolling through my phone on my commute, I decided to thank people.
curated_info.title: How Writing 365 Thank-You Notes Helped Me Reconnect with What’s Important in My Life

curated_info.author: Leslie Turnbull
curated_info.excerpt: What if “happiness” could be actively learned?
curated_info.title: I Skeptically Tried Practicing Gratitude. It Completely Changed My Life.

collections.description: You might be one “thank you” away from a much better mood. Science (and celebrities—just ask Oprah.) have proven time and again that gratitude may be the closest thing we have to a silver bullet to a better life. Read on to explore how gratitude works, how to make giving thanks a way of life, and why the return on investment is so enormous.
collections.subtitle: Cultivating gratitude can improve your life, rewire your brain, and influence those around you. Here’s how to get started.
collections.title: Cultivating gratitude can improve your life, rewire your brain, and influence those around you. Here’s how to get started.

curated_info.author: Amy Qin
curated_info.excerpt: Ed Yong: “Amy Qin’s stark dispatches from Wuhan were among my most important “oh shit” moments from the earliest months of the pandemic. They vividly captured what the new virus was capable of.”
curated_info.title: Coronavirus Pummels Wuhan, a City Short of Supplies and Overwhelmed

curated_info.author: Helen Branswell
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “Helen Branswell is perhaps the most respected veteran of the infectious disease beat—a tireless reporter who was covering the pandemic from its very first week. In this piece, she shows that even seasoned public health experts underestimated the COVID-19 threat early on. It’s an important historical marker that the world should learn from when thinking about pandemics of the future.”
curated_info.title: The Months of Magical Thinking: As the Coronavirus Swept Over China, Some Experts Were in Denial

curated_info.author: Mara Gay
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “I remember the seismic impact of these pieces, which blew away the lingering myth that COVID-19 only affected the elderly, and clearly showed that even young, healthy people could be debilitated by the disease. These important op-eds also hinted at the existence of the group who would eventually become known as long-haulers.”
curated_info.title: ‘I Wish I Could Do Something for You,’ My Doctor Said

curated_info.author: Roxanne Khamsi
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “Roxanne Khamsi has been one of the very best pandemic journalists, repeatedly finding important stories well ahead of anyone else. Her piece on whether the new virus is airborne, and the tricky scientific debates around that seemingly simple word, came out months before the matter was furiously debated by the scientific community.”
curated_info.title: They Say Coronavirus Isn't Airborne—but It's Definitely Borne By Air

curated_info.author: Zeynep Tufekci
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “Zeynep Tufekci has been consistently right about the pandemic from the beginning, calling attention to the need for masks and better ventilation well before either became commonly discussed. This piece—an explanation of the superspreading problem and what to do about it—is her crowning achievement. It’s a masterpiece of science writing, taking difficult concepts and suffusing them with clarity and urgency.”
curated_info.title: This Overlooked Variable Is the Key to the Pandemic

curated_info.author: Susan Dominus
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “Faced by an entirely new disease and strained emergency rooms, doctors were pulled between the need to try something, anything, right now and the need to accumulate evidence about what treatments actually work. This is a tough topic, but one that’s masterfully and compassionately handled by Susan Dominus, surely one of the most formidable magazine writers working today.”
curated_info.title: The Covid Drug Wars That Pitted Doctors Vs. Doctors

curated_info.author: Katie Engelhart
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “When COVID-19 first arrived in the U.S., nursing homes took the brunt of its assault. This astonishing piece details what happened in the first American hotspot—the Life Care Center of Kirkland. Extraordinarily gripping, it conveys how scared, confused, and unprepared parts of the country were for a pandemic.”
curated_info.title: What Happened in Room 10?

curated_info.author: Helen Ouyang
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “More than perhaps any other piece, this haunting account of what the new coronavirus does to hospitals has stuck in my mind. Helen Ouyang juxtaposes her first-hand experiences in New York with the similar ordeals endured by colleagues in Lombardy. It is an extraordinary piece of writing, and a grim harbinger of what hospitals throughout the U.S. would face at the end of the year.”
curated_info.title: I’m an E.R. Doctor in New York. None of Us Will Ever Be the Same

curated_info.author: Sarah Kaplan
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “At least 250,000 Americans have died of COVID-19—a huge number that elides unfathomable tragedy into cold digits. Sarah Kaplan cuts through the habituation, and tells the story of just one of those deaths—Keith Redding, and the people who now grieve him.”
curated_info.title: The Storm Inside

curated_info.author: Jesmyn Ward
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “In this shattering essay, Jesmyn Ward writes about losing her husband at the start of the year, and dealing with grief through the pandemic, the protests, and more.”
curated_info.title: On Witness and Respair: A Personal Tragedy Followed By Pandemic

curated_info.author: Maggie Koerth
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “While pundits argued about whether COVID-19 deaths are overcounted or undercounted, Maggie Koerth showed why it’s the latter in this deeply moving piece. It effortlessly moves from personal tragedy to statistical shenanigan, allowing both to illuminate the other.”
curated_info.title: The Uncounted Dead

curated_info.author: Julia Craven
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “COVID-19 disproportionately infected and killed Black communities in the U.S.. Julia Craven beautifully explains why in this piece, in which she juxtaposes the poignant stories of two women against a sweeping look at America’s centuries-old legacy of racism.”
curated_info.title: It’s Not Too Late to Save Black Lives

curated_info.author: Patrice Peck
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “In April, Patrice Peck started the invaluable newsletter Coronavirus News for Black Folks. Here, she reflects on what she saw, what others didn’t, and why staying in the game matters.”
curated_info.title: What Writing a Pandemic Newsletter Showed Me About America

curated_info.author: Nicole Chung
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “Among a litany of bad decisions, this was a year in which the U.S. collectively chose to prioritize bars, restaurants, and gyms over schools. This lack of foresight will have especially important consequences for the millions of children with disabilities.
curated_info.title: My Child Has a Disability. What Will Her Education Be Like This Year?

curated_info.author: Usha Lee McFarling
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “While surrounding Oklahoma floundered, the Cherokee Nation beat back its COVID-19 surge thanks to strong leaders who listened to public health officials. This is one of many great pieces from Usha Lee McFarling, who has spent the year focusing on marginalized communities.”
curated_info.title: ‘They’ve Been Following the Science’: How the COVID-19 Pandemic Has Been Curtailed in Cherokee Nation

curated_info.author: Julia Marcus
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “The U.S. has an unfortunate tendency to castigate individuals for societal failures, offering blame and shame instead of guidance. Julia Marcus has led the charge to resist that instinct. Consistently, she has offered sensible and much-needed advice on navigating risk, and urged everyone else to lean towards compassion and empathy instead of judgement and punishment.”
curated_info.title: Quarantine Fatigue Is Real

curated_info.author: Amanda Mull
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “For years, Amanda Mull’s work at The Atlantic has redefined my conception of what health journalism can be. This piece is a good example—a thought-provoking and often profound look at why feeling safe and being safe are so very different, and why that difference has mattered so much during this pandemic.”
curated_info.title: The Difference Between Feeling Safe and Being Safe

curated_info.author: Meehan Crist
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “In the spring, as the world sheltered in place, many pieces were written about whether distancing would blunt the sting of climate change. This is not one of those pieces. Meehan Crist, one of the most thoughtful writers I know, offers something more profound—a sweeping, forward-looking look at two of the most pressing problems of our time.”
curated_info.title: What the Coronavirus Means for Climate Change

curated_info.author: Bathsheba Demuth
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “‘On the first day of summer, Siberia and I were the same temperature.’” That's the incredible opening sentence of Bathsheba Demuth's essay on COVID-19, climate change, and how slowly the abnormal becomes normal.”
curated_info.title: The Empty Space Where Normal Once Lived

curated_info.author: Sarah Zhang
curated_info.excerpt: EY: “Finally, hope. With the announcement of positive results for several vaccines, the pandemic endgame is now upon us—and in record time. This is the stirring story of the scientific achievement of the year, as told by one of the most accomplished science writers working today.”
curated_info.title: The End of the Pandemic Is Now in Sight

curated_info.author: Alex Dalenberg
curated_info.excerpt: Our roundup of the year’s most unforgettable first-person essays and on-the-ground reports that told the story of coronavirus in 2020.
curated_info.title: Living Through a Pandemic

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: Dive into Ed Yong’s stellar journalism with this collection of pandemic coverage for The Atlantic.
curated_info.title: Fascinating Coronavirus Features from Science Journalist Ed Yong

curator.about:
About the Curator

Ed Yong is a staff writer at The Atlantic, where he covers science. He is author of the best-selling I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life.
curator.name: Ed Yong

collections.description: Ed Yong spent much of 2020 covering the coronavirus pandemic, writing more than two dozen features about the virus and our often-bungled response to it for The Atlantic — including Pocket’s most-read article of 2020. He has curated a list of a few of the exceptional pieces that he most admired on the pandemic beat this year — pivotal writing that landed at critical moments, clear explainers that helped translate our evolving understanding of COVID-19, and unforgettable stories that stood above others for their beauty and lyricism.
collections.subtitle: Stand-out stories that help make sense of the coronavirus pandemic, curated by science journalist Ed Yong.
collections.title: Stand-out stories that help make sense of the coronavirus pandemic, curated by science journalist Ed Yong.

curated_info.excerpt: The fight against the coronavirus won’t be over when the U.S. reopens. Here’s how the nation must prepare itself.
curated_info.title: Our Pandemic Summer

curated_info.excerpt: A guide to making sense of a problem that is now too big for any one person to fully comprehend.
curated_info.title: The Pandemic Doesn’t Have to Be This Confusing

curated_info.excerpt: The coronavirus is coursing through different parts of the U.S. in different ways, making the crisis harder to predict, control, or understand.
curated_info.title: We Live in a Patchwork Pandemic Now

curated_info.excerpt: The disease’s “long-haulers” have endured relentless waves of debilitating symptoms—and disbelief from doctors and friends.
curated_info.title: COVID-19 Can Last for Several Months

curated_info.excerpt: Many American public-health specialists are at risk of burning out as the coronavirus surges back.
curated_info.title: The Pandemic Experts Are Not Okay

curated_info.excerpt: A virus has brought the world’s most powerful country to its knees.
curated_info.title: Why the Pandemic Is So Bad in America

curated_info.excerpt: Which is too bad because we really need to understand how the immune system reacts to the coronavirus.
curated_info.title: The Pandemic’s Biggest Mystery Is Our Own Immune System

curated_info.excerpt: Without understanding the lingering illness that some patients experience, we can’t understand the pandemic.
curated_info.title: Long-Haulers Are Redefining COVID-19

curated_info.excerpt: As the U.S. heads toward the winter, the country is going round in circles, making the same conceptual errors that have plagued it since spring.
curated_info.title: America Is Trapped in a Pandemic Spiral

curated_info.excerpt: The new coronavirus seems so strange because it has our full attention in a way most viruses don’t.
curated_info.title: What COVID-19 Does to the Heart

curated_info.excerpt: The metaphors that Trump and others use when talking about COVID-19 are making the pandemic worse.
curated_info.title: Donald Trump’s Strength Did Not Beat the Coronavirus

curated_info.excerpt: More people than ever are hospitalized with COVID-19. Health-care workers can’t go on like this.
curated_info.title: COVID-19’s Third Surge Is Breaking Health-Care Workers

curated_info.excerpt: “We are on an absolutely catastrophic path,” said a COVID-19 doctor at America’s best-prepared hospital.
curated_info.title: Hospitals Know What’s Coming

curated_info.excerpt: The epidemics of the early 21st century revealed a world unprepared, even as the risks continue to multiply. Much worse is coming.
curated_info.title: Bonus Read from 2018: Is America Ready for a Global Pandemic?

curated_info.author: Alex Dalenberg
curated_info.excerpt: Our roundup of the year’s most unforgettable first-person essays and on-the-ground reports that told the story of coronavirus in 2020.
curated_info.title: Living Through a Pandemic

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: The stand-out articles that have helped make sense of the pandemic, curated by science journalist Ed Yong.
curated_info.title: Must-Read Coronavirus Stories

collections.description: Ed Yong, author of 2020’s most-read article in Pocket, How the Pandemic Will End, tenaciously covered COVID-19 and the response to the virus throughout the year. Dive into more of his stellar journalism with this collection of pandemic coverage for The Atlantic, including a prescient 2018 feature on how America fell behind in preparing for the next plague.
collections.subtitle: Dive into Ed Yong’s stellar journalism with this collection of pandemic coverage for The Atlantic.
collections.title: Dive into Ed Yong’s stellar journalism with this collection of pandemic coverage for The Atlantic.

curated_info.author: Julie Miller
curated_info.excerpt: Jennifer Shahade, a two-time U.S. women’s chess champion, tells Vanity Fair how accurate the series is in terms of women in the sport, addiction, and rock star prodigies.
curated_info.title: A Real-Life Chess Champion on Netflix’s Addictive Hit

curated_info.author: Dylan Loeb McClain
curated_info.excerpt: The Netflix show is one of the best screen adaptations of the game yet. But there are a few wrong moves.
curated_info.title: Here’s What ‘The Queen’s Gambit’ Gets Right

curated_info.author: Jackson McHenry
curated_info.excerpt: By the end of the show, you might actually find yourself wanting to watch more chess.
curated_info.title: How The Queen’s Gambit Made Its Chess Scenes Believable and Exciting

curated_info.author: David Hill
curated_info.excerpt: Walter Tevis, the author of the book upon which the Netflix hit is based, spent his life gambling and drinking in pool halls before turning to chess. But once you know his story, it’s stunning that the book ever came out at all.
curated_info.title: The Man Who Brought ‘The Queen’s Gambit’ to Life

curated_info.author: Walter Tevis
curated_info.excerpt: “Beth learned of her mother's death from a woman with a clipboard. The next day her picture appeared in the Herald-Leader.”
curated_info.title: Excerpt From ‘The Queen's Gambit’

curated_info.author: Stephen Moss
curated_info.excerpt: You don’t have to be a polymath like Beth Harmon in The Queen’s Gambit to improve your game.
curated_info.title: How to Get Good at Chess

curated_info.author: Alex Gendler
curated_info.excerpt: Trace the storied history of the game of chess, from its origins in 7th century India to the computer software we use today.
curated_info.title: Watch: A Brief History of Chess

curated_info.author: Tom Vanderbilt
curated_info.excerpt: What I learned trying to keep up with my 4-year-old daughter at the royal game.
curated_info.title: Learning Chess at Forty

curated_info.author: Jonathan Rowson
curated_info.excerpt: The challenge of chess – learning how to hold complexity in mind and still make good decisions – is also the challenge of life.
curated_info.title: Concentrate!

curated_info.author: Caroline Delbert
curated_info.excerpt: Netflix's hit series The Queen's Gambit confirms it: A game as old as time can help you strategize for basically anything.
curated_info.title: Want to Make Better Decisions? Start Playing More Chess

curated_info.author: Sophie Roell
curated_info.excerpt: You don't have to be a genius to play chess, but it helps. The former Sunday Telegraph editor and chess aficionado, Dominic Lawson, chooses the best books on chess.
curated_info.title: The Best Books on Chess

curated_info.author: Gary Kasparov
curated_info.excerpt: “Deep Blue was only intelligent the way your programmable alarm clock is intelligent. Not that losing to a $10 million alarm clock made me feel any better.”
curated_info.title: The Chess Master and the Computer

curated_info.author: Cecilia D'Anastasio
curated_info.excerpt: Hikaru Nakamura is the top-ranked blitz chess player in the world—and his channel has seen a meteoric rise as he coaches streamers in the ancient game.
curated_info.title: The Grandmaster Who Got Twitch Hooked on Chess

curated_info.author: Joe Holmes
curated_info.excerpt: Magnus Carlsen, the best chess player alive, has been slipping into online speed tournaments behind pseudonyms to crack jokes, let loose, and destroy the competition.

curated_info.excerpt: CS: I tend to like dark, moody series, and Mind Hunter totally captivated me. Save Bonus Read: Star Jonathan Groff opens up about compartmentalizing—and engaging in a little “Mindhunter emotional eating” via Vanity Fair . Save

curated_info.excerpt: LFB: This recipe demonstrates how segregating information and then integrating it at the end produces complexity. If you cook a bunch of vegetables together in a pot, the mixture will have a single, blended flavor. No individual ingredient stands out. But, Keller explains, there’s a better, tastier way to make your dish: cook each vegetable separately and assemble them in the pot at the end. Now every spoonful is a different complex medley of flavors. A brain works sort of in the same way.

curator.about:
About the Curator
Lisa Feldman Barrett, PhD, has received numerous scientific awards, including a Guggenheim Fellowship in neuroscience and an NIH Director’s Pioneer Award. She is a University Distinguished Professor at Northeastern University, with appointments at Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital.
curator.name: Amy Maoz

collections.description: If you ask her husband, Dr. Lisa Feldman Barrett has just written the first neuroscience beach read. But Dr. Barrett considers her new book, Seven and a Half Lessons About the Brain, more of a choose-your-own-adventure, a chance to distill her favorite dinner party stories about the mind—from how our big gray blobs evolved to the myth of the “lizard brain”—into a witty and information-packed page-turner.
collections.subtitle: Your brain is more complex than you probably realize. Let neuroscientist Lisa Feldman Barrett expand your mind.
collections.title: Your brain is more complex than you probably realize. Let neuroscientist Lisa Feldman Barrett expand your mind.

curator.about:
About the Curator

Simran Jeet Singh loves sports and signed up for his first marathon after being inspired by Fauja Singh—and like Fauja, he hasn't stopped running since. Simran is an activist, writer, and scholar who believes deeply in the divine goodness of all people. He was born and raised in San Antonio, Texas, and now lives in New York City with his wife and two daughters.
curator.name: Amy Maoz

collections.description: The internet loves a list, especially those that lionize the hustle-hard, kid-geniuses of typical “30 under 30” tallies. We’re taking a different route, inspired by 109-year-old Fauja Singh, the oldest person to ever run a marathon. His story is captured in Fauja Singh Keeps Going, a new children’s book by Simran Jeet Singh, who tells us:
collections.subtitle: There’s no age limit to embarking on captivating, inspiring adventures. Author and activist Simran Jeet Singh spotlights eight stories about people of a certain age.

collections.description: You’ve heard that perfect is the enemy of done. But perfection’s list of enemies extends well beyond that. Vulnerability, freedom, progress…oh, and reality. Whether you’re staring down back-to-school season or just your weekend to-do list, take a breather with this collection. We’ve rounded up the best stories about the sneaky ways perfectionism influences our lives—and how to break free.

collections.description: So much about 2020 has been unprecedented, and the U.S. election promises to be no different. The coronavirus pandemic has changed everything, including how tens of millions of Americans cast their ballots. All the while, voters in the U.S. are attempting to navigate a flood of misinformation on social networks, while bracing for an Election Night that might not deliver a decisive result.<br data-highlightable="1" /><br data-highlightable="1" />Read on to explore curated guides to key issues surrounding the nuts and bolts of this year's U.S. election, from decoding the Electoral College to learning how to fight and stop the spread of misinformation. We’ve also included historical context about past contentious elections and tips for decompressing when the news cycle has you reeling. Each collection serves up a list of fascinating, informative, and helpful stories to help you make sense of how U.S. elections work, and why your vote matters.
collections.subtitle: From chaotic past elections to fighting misinformation, your guide to the unique way America votes.

collections.description:
Here’s a Pocket October surprise: Not a single story about the 2020 U.S. election made the top 10 most saved articles for the month. That contrasts with September, when politics was top of mind, with stories about disastrous Election Day scenarios and President Trump’s taxes claiming the top two spots.

That’s not to say the Pocket community turned away from current events in October. Atlantic contributor Zeynep Tufecki’s analysis of the overlooked variable in the coronavirus pandemic was the top saved story for the month. But otherwise, readers were clearly looking for some lightness and escapism, saving stories about remote islands, jokes for kids, and even the history of grapefruit.

collections.description: Feeling anxious? You’re not alone—and not without resources. We’ve created a collection of a dozen stories that delve into how anxiety affects your body, brain, and habits, as well as the world around you. Because the first step towards better mental health is understanding the science of how and why anxiety works. As for the next steps? From vaccines to psychedelics to video games, scientists and experts are on the case.

collections.description: Before you add one more thing to your to-do list, ask yourself: How’s that to-do list working for you anyway? And would you fare better with a lesser-known method like the Eisenhower box? Zettelkasten? GTD? With so many modern options for wrangling your time and attention, we’ve rounded up some of the best to help you understand how they work—and which one might work best for you. Set that pomodoro timer—if that’s your style—and let’s get started.
