curated_info.excerpt: Nosleep's indistinguishable mixture of the real and merely realistic (weighed heavily toward the latter, most likely) has helped it grow into the Internet’s main source of amateur horror stories.
curated_info.title: Inside the Horror Website That’s Freaking Out Millions of People

curated_info.author: Kat Tenbarge
curated_info.excerpt: Scary stories aren’t the stuff of campfires and sleepovers anymore. For adults who still enjoy a good spook, the internet is the place to turn for tales of horror and the supernatural.
curated_info.title: The 40 Most Terrifying Creepypasta and NoSleep Stories on the Internet

curated_info.author: Jeffrey Kluger
curated_info.excerpt: It would be nicer for all of us if nightmares didn’t exist in the first place, but it’s hardly surprising that they do. If the sleeping brain is forever screening the sometimes absurdist movies that are our dreams, it’s no surprise that now and then it would choose a horror film.
curated_info.title: Scientists Are Learning to Read—and Change—Your Nightmares

curated_info.author: Jake Bittle
curated_info.excerpt: Current science can’t prove their existence, but these seven mental and environmental factors might.
curated_info.title: Why Do We See Ghosts?

curated_info.author: Jake Flanagin
curated_info.excerpt: Respected scientists are lending credibility to parapsychological research.
curated_info.title: There Is a Paranormal Activity Lab at the University of Virginia

curated_info.author: David Robson
curated_info.excerpt: In the 21st Century, why do so many people still believe in the paranormal? David Robson discovers that there’s good reason we hold superstitions – and a few surprising benefits.
curated_info.title: The Truth About the Paranormal

collections.description:
With Halloween upon us, there’s no better time to curl up with a story about things that go bump in the night. Whether you’re a true believer in the supernatural or a hardened skeptic, you’ll find something spine-tingling in this collection of specters, zombies, and all things strange and spooky.

Looking for more Halloween fun?  You can host physically-distant, spooky and fun virtual Halloween parties with Mozilla Hubs. With a single click, you can create a virtual 3D space and invite others to join you using a simple URL. No downloads. No installation process. Just click, and you are there. Happy Halloween!
collections.subtitle: Get into the Halloween spirit with this collection of terrifying and spooky stories, including the true story behind The Amityville Horror, the real lives of vampires, and the science of why we see ghosts.
collections.title: Get into the Halloween spirit with this collection of terrifying and spooky stories, including the true story behind The Amityville Horror, the real lives of vampires, and the science of why we see ghosts.

curated_info.author: Jennifer Nalewicki
curated_info.excerpt: It has always had the potential for chaos—one that hasn’t been tapped…yet.
curated_info.title: The Electoral College Has Been Divisive Since Day One

curated_info.author: Eric Foner
curated_info.excerpt: Rooted in distrust of ordinary citizens and, like so many other features of American life, in the institution of slavery, the electoral college is a relic of a past the United States should have abandoned long ago.
curated_info.title: The Corrupt Bargain

curated_info.author: Allen Guelzo
curated_info.excerpt: The Electoral College has been a significant, if poorly comprehended, mechanism for stability, liberty, and legitimacy — all of which democracies can too easily come to undermine.
curated_info.title: In Defense of the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Ian Millhiser
curated_info.excerpt: In close elections, Republicans are favored to win even when they lose the popular vote.
curated_info.title: The Astounding Advantage the Electoral College Gives to Republicans, in One Chart

curated_info.author: Amel Ahmed
curated_info.excerpt: While the disconnect between the electoral and popular votes may be cause for alarm, abolishing the Electoral College poses even greater dangers, particularly for liberals.
curated_info.title: In Defense of the Electoral College [From the Left]

curated_info.author: Saul Anuzis and Michael Steele
curated_info.excerpt: Things are going to look much, much worse for the GOP’s chances with the Electoral College if red Texas, along with the battleground state of Florida, move to purple or blue in the coming years.
curated_info.title: Why Republicans Should Get Behind a National Popular Vote, Too

curated_info.author: Dan McLaughlin
curated_info.excerpt: What would American politics look like without the Electoral College? Changing our current system would unsettle so many of the assumptions and incentives that drive presidential politics that the outcomes could easily be unpredictable.
curated_info.title: What the Electoral College Saves Us From

curated_info.author: Robert Robb
curated_info.excerpt: Electoral College or direct election, conservatives have to convince more people, including in urban areas, that their policies are preferable.
curated_info.title: Do Conservatives Really Think They Can’t Win?

curated_info.author: G. Alan Tarr
curated_info.excerpt: Defenders of the Electoral College argue that it was created to combat majority tyranny and support federalism, and that it continues to serve those purposes. This stance depends on a profound misunderstanding of the history of the institution.
curated_info.title: Five Common Misconceptions About the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Richard A. Posner
curated_info.excerpt: All are practical reasons, not liberal or conservative reasons.
curated_info.title: Five Reasons to Keep Our Despised Method of Choosing the President

curated_info.author: Nate Cohn
curated_info.excerpt: A winner-take-all system within states can produce results counter to the majority for no high-minded reason.
curated_info.title: The Electoral College’s Real Problem: It’s Biased Toward the Big Battlegrounds

curated_info.author: Kurtis Lee
curated_info.excerpt: The reason both parties united in support: Former Alabama Gov. George Wallace.
curated_info.title: In 1969, Democrats and Republicans United to Get Rid of the Electoral College. Here’s What Happened

curated_info.author: Kamala Kelkar
curated_info.excerpt: The Electoral College was built in part to accommodate white, male slave owners who could not have anticipated a two-party system, that slaves would be freed or that black people and women would be able to vote.
curated_info.title: The Racial History of the Electoral College — and Why Efforts to Change It Have Stalled

curated_info.author: Joshua Holzer
curated_info.excerpt: As a scholar of presidential democracies around the world, I’ve examined a range of options the U.S. could consider, if it chose to change how the president is elected.
curated_info.title: What Could Replace the Electoral College?

curated_info.author: Vikram David Amar
curated_info.excerpt: There is a plan that can get the country closer to having a national popular election for president within the current constitutional framework, and without the need for a constitutional amendment.
curated_info.title: How to—Carefully—Surmount the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Edward B. Foley
curated_info.excerpt: The way we now elect presidents would horrify the authors of the U.S. electoral system. But the system can be fixed, and the power lies with the states.
curated_info.title: An Idea for Electoral College Reform That Both Parties Might Actually Like

curated_info.author: Charles Lane
curated_info.excerpt: The electoral college is hardly the optimal way to choose a national leader, and the case against it deserves serious debate. So does the complexity of devising a better alternative.
curated_info.title: The Electoral College Has Its Issues. So Do the Alternatives.

curated_info.author: Lee Drutman
curated_info.excerpt: The Electoral College is a slippery target. In most political constituencies, opposition to the institution is fluid; with every elimination effort, the battle lines change.
curated_info.title: Can Anything Dislodge the Electoral College?

curated_info.author: 270 To Win
curated_info.excerpt: Don't like the results? Change the rules! Use this interactive map to see how alternative electoral vote allocation methods would have affected the results had they been in place for the 2012 or 2016 presidential election.
curated_info.title: Gaming the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Alex Dalenberg
curated_info.excerpt: Everything you ever wanted to know about America’s byzantine system for selecting a president.
curated_info.title: Understanding the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Alex Dalenberg
curated_info.excerpt: Partisan rancor. Conspiracy theories. Disenfranchised voters. Foreign meddling. Contested results. Maybe it’s not exactly a comfort, but the United States has seen it all before.
curated_info.title: America’s History of Nasty, Tumultuous, and Strange Presidential Elections

collections.description: This is the second part in Pocket’s guide to the Electoral College. For articles about how the system works and its history, see Understanding the Electoral College.
collections.subtitle: A roundup of the best arguments for and against America’s unique system for electing a president. Plus, a look at possible alternatives.
collections.title: A roundup of the best arguments for and against America’s unique system for electing a president. Plus, a look at possible alternatives.

curated_info.author: Minami Funakoshi, Wen Foo and Jan Wolfe
curated_info.excerpt: A guide to the complex system the United States uses to select a president.

curated_info.author: Throughline
curated_info.excerpt: What is it, why do we have it, and why hasn't it changed?
curated_info.title: Podcast: The Electoral College

curated_info.author: Dave Roos
curated_info.excerpt: The Founding Fathers had to compromise when it came to devising a system to elect the president.
curated_info.title: Why Was the Electoral College Created?

curated_info.author: Jean Tanis
curated_info.excerpt: Today's process would be unrecognizable to the nation’s founders, who imagined it as an indirect and deliberative system with considerably narrower public participation.
curated_info.title: The Evolution of the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Jeff Nilsson
curated_info.excerpt: The electoral college outcome doesn’t always reflect the popular vote, but that’s not the only factor that determines how influential your vote is.
curated_info.title: How Much Does Your Vote Weigh?

curated_info.author: Ed Kilgore
curated_info.excerpt: In politics, as in military conflict, there is a tendency among generals and journalists alike to fight the last war. But battlegrounds often change.
curated_info.title: Presidential Battleground States Change All the Time

curated_info.author: Drew DeSilver
curated_info.excerpt: The very nature of the way the U.S. picks its presidents tends to create a disconnect between the outcome in the Electoral College and the popular vote.
curated_info.title: Why Electoral College Landslides Are Easier To Win Than Popular Vote Ones

curated_info.author: Andrew Prokop
curated_info.excerpt: Here are the most promising paths to victory for each candidate.
curated_info.title: How Biden — or Trump — Could Win 270 Electoral Votes

curated_info.author: Alex Dalenberg
curated_info.excerpt: A roundup of the best arguments for and against America’s unique system for electing a president. Plus, a look at possible alternatives.
curated_info.title: Debating the Electoral College

curated_info.author: Jodi Enda
curated_info.excerpt: The notion that there were “red states” and “blue states”—and that the former were Republican and the latter Democratic—wasn’t cemented on the national psyche until the year 2000.
curated_info.title: When Republicans Were Blue and Democrats Were Red

collections.description:
This is the first part in Pocket’s guide to the Electoral College. For a roundup of the best arguments for and against the system, as well as possible alternatives, see Debating the Electoral College.

American presidential elections are a strange beast. As the world was reminded in 2016, the candidate who wins the most votes overall won’t necessarily win the White House. For that, you can blame and/or thank the Electoral College.
collections.subtitle: Everything you ever wanted to know about America’s byzantine system for selecting a president.
collections.title: Everything you ever wanted to know about America’s byzantine system for selecting a president.

curated_info.author: Jamie Feldmar
curated_info.excerpt: A shopping list to make your cooking that much better.
curated_info.title: How to Stock a Pantry

curated_info.author: Daniela Galarza
curated_info.excerpt: Rules for cooking safety at home: best practices for using knives, stoves, ovens, and other appliances to avoid common injuries.
curated_info.title: Kitchen Safety 101: How To Prevent Cuts, Burns, and Other Injuries

curated_info.author: Claire Lower
curated_info.excerpt: The more cooking you do, the more intuitive timing becomes, but it can still be overwhelming.
curated_info.title: The Grown-Up Kitchen: How to Time Your Cooking So Everything Is Ready at Once

curated_info.author: Julia Sherman
curated_info.excerpt: A vegetable enthusiast’s best practices.
curated_info.title: Are You Storing Your Produce Properly?

curated_info.author: Tony Naylor
curated_info.excerpt: Getting your hands on everyday staples is not always as quick and easy as it used to be – but you can still rustle up delicious dishes by making a few judicious substitutions.
curated_info.title: No Flour, Pasta or Eggs? the Perfect Substitutes for 20 Common Ingredients

curated_info.author: J. Kenji López-Alt
curated_info.excerpt: To be a faster, more creative cook, take a cue from restaurant chefs, J. Kenji López-Alt suggests, and rely on culinary building blocks.
curated_info.title: How To Build a Better Dinner

curated_info.author: Jenny Rosenstrach
curated_info.excerpt: “Sometimes I forget that not everyone is walking around with a mental catalog of time-saving, energy-saving, sanity-saving, life-saving, money-saving, surefire, guaranteed foolproof, plan-ahead, stress-free, problem-solving shortcuts, tips and tricks in the kitchen.”
curated_info.title: 15 Things I Wish Someone Had Told Me When I Started Cooking

curated_info.author: Jesse Szewczyk
curated_info.excerpt: A little prep goes a long way.
curated_info.title: The 9 Most Important Things I Learned in Cooking School

curated_info.author: Tatiana Bautista
curated_info.excerpt: If you’re finding yourself taking three times as long to make dinner as the recipe says, you’re not alone.
curated_info.title: The 30-Minute Meal Myth

curated_info.author: Sohla El-Waylly
curated_info.excerpt: Get a crash course on an endlessly riffable dish—and learn how to put your own spin on it.
curated_info.title: Chicken & Rice, However the Heck You Want, a la Sohla El-Waylly

curated_info.excerpt: Once you’re familiar with the fundamentals of marinating, you can ditch the store-bought stuff and make your own with ingredients that are already in your pantry.
curated_info.title: Marinating: A Guide To How It Works and What It Does

curated_info.author: Emma Christensen
curated_info.excerpt: With this one trick you can make great frittata with whatever you have on hand.
curated_info.title: How To Make an Easy Frittata

curated_info.author: Katherine Sacks
curated_info.excerpt: Somewhere, somehow, the simple act of cooking a pot of beans became mired in gossip, rumors, and crazy myths. We wanted to cut through all that, and we did—it just took 12 pots of water and several pounds of pintos.
curated_info.title: How to Cook Beans: The Epicurious Myth-Busting Guide

curated_info.author: Shaunacy Ferro
curated_info.excerpt: The sauce’s simplicity makes it a little radical.
curated_info.title: The Pasta Sauce Hailed as the World’s Best Is Surprisingly Easy to Make at Home

curated_info.excerpt: How texture, size, and flavor can help pair pasta shapes with sauces.
curated_info.title: Your Pasta & Sauce Pairing Cheat Sheet

curated_info.author: Genevieve Ko
curated_info.excerpt: If there’s a vegetable you think you don’t like, just roast it.
curated_info.title: The Essential Guide To Roasted Vegetables

curated_info.author: Rochelle Bilow
curated_info.excerpt: Anyone can learn how to make salad. This formula will show you how to make a knockout one, every time.
curated_info.title: Learn This Simple Formula and Never Make a Mediocre Salad Again

collections.description: There’s nothing better for your health, wallet, or personal sense of accomplishment than learning how to cook. We’ve pulled together the best resources to help you establish confidence in the kitchen, from proper preparation and creative shortcuts to mastering simple but brilliant techniques. Grab your knives (carefully!) and let’s get started.
collections.subtitle: Get comfortable in the kitchen with beginner-friendly tips and techniques.
collections.title: Get comfortable in the kitchen with beginner-friendly tips and techniques.

curated_info.author: Tara Parker-Pope
curated_info.excerpt: During a crisis, the people who cope best are those who help others.
curated_info.title: The Science of Helping Out

curated_info.author: Gina Vivinetto
curated_info.excerpt: All those “Friends” or “Golden Girls” reruns help us feel calm in an increasingly anxious world.
curated_info.title: Watching Our Favorite Old TV Shows Has Psychological Benefits, Experts Say

curated_info.author: Harriet Gross
curated_info.excerpt: Psychology research suggests that tending to a garden can have an almost magical effect, even changing the passage of time.
curated_info.title: How Pottering About in the Garden Creates a Time Warp

curated_info.author: Emma Seppälä, Christina Bradley, and Michael R. Goldstein
curated_info.excerpt: With the right breathing exercises, you can learn to handle your stress and manage negative emotions.
curated_info.title: Why Breathing Is So Effective at Reducing Stress

curated_info.author: Michelle Darrisaw
curated_info.excerpt: When yoga doesn’t cut it, a box of crayons does.
curated_info.title: Adult Coloring Books Help Me Cope When My Anxiety Is at Its Worst

curated_info.author: Cody Delistraty
curated_info.excerpt: Meet the new crop of so-called “laughter therapists.”
curated_info.title: Giggling Is the Best Medicine

curated_info.author: Jill Suttie
curated_info.excerpt: We are spending more time indoors and online. But recent studies suggest that nature can help our brains and bodies to stay healthy.
curated_info.title: How Nature Can Make You Kinder, Happier, and More Creative

curated_info.author: Sara Harrison
curated_info.excerpt: You’re not the only one who finds #quarantinebaking so soothing. Turns out, it has a lot to do with the neuroscience of mindful meditation.
curated_info.title: Why Stress-Baking and Cleaning Make You Less Anxious

curated_info.author: Christie Calucchia
curated_info.excerpt: “The quality of the choices you make in regards to the foods you eat will absolutely determine the quality of your energy, your health, and your body’s ability to ward off stress.”
curated_info.title: 8 Foods Nutritionists Use To Relieve Stress (and Recipes)

curated_info.author: Sara Kiley Watson
curated_info.excerpt: Get physically fit while also paying mind to anxiety and depression.
curated_info.title: How To Work Out for Your Mental Health

curated_info.author: Cindy Lamothe
curated_info.excerpt: Visiting a sento is a popular, age-old Japanese practice and tradition. And like forest bathing, it has many health benefits.
curated_info.title: Can a Hot Bath Deliver the Same Results as Exercise?

curated_info.author: Nick Keppler
curated_info.excerpt: Here’s everything we know about how pets affect your mood.
curated_info.title: This Is What Your Brain and Body Do When You Hang Out With Animals

curated_info.author: Tameka Kee
curated_info.excerpt: Some of the same technologies that stress us out can actually help us calm down.
curated_info.title: The Surprising Ways Tech Can Improve Our Mental Health

curated_info.author: Alix Strauss
curated_info.excerpt: The joys of a toy as tactile as slime are particularly useful today, when so much play is mediated through screens.
curated_info.title: Need Stress Relief at a Challenging Time? Try Slime.

curated_info.author: Lindsey Lanquist
curated_info.excerpt: Thinking of going on a social media cleanse? Here’s what you need to know.
curated_info.title: 5 Potential Mental Health Benefits of Deleting Social Media

curated_info.author: David Gelles
curated_info.excerpt: We offer basic tips to get you started on a path toward greater equanimity, acceptance and joy.
curated_info.title: How To Meditate

curated_info.author: Kelly McGonigal, PhD
curated_info.excerpt: We need to start thinking about how to have the courage to grow from stress.
curated_info.title: How To Be Good at Stress

collections.description: It’s hardly the time to put your head in the sand about what’s going on in the world. But you can still be informed without being pummeled by a punishing news cycle. In fact, it’s actually healthier to keep a news obsession at bay. From a how-to guide to meditation to the benefits of stress-baking, explore these scientifically proven, stress-busting strategies. Take a deep breath (see, you’re starting already!) and get your calm on.
collections.subtitle: Proven ways to break your doomscrolling habit —from laughter to re-runs to slime.
collections.title: Proven ways to break your doomscrolling habit —from laughter to re-runs to slime.

curated_info.author: Gillian Brockell
curated_info.excerpt: In 1790, George Washington fell severely ill, threatening his life and the young nation he led.

curated_info.author: Jane McHugh and Philip A. Mackowiak
curated_info.excerpt: The accepted wisdom is that the shortest-serving president developed pneumonia after delivering a long Inaugural Address in cold weather. But that might not be true.

curated_info.author: Allan B. Schwartz
curated_info.excerpt: Some suspected assassination, perhaps by poisoning, when President Zachary Taylor died unexpectedly after a brief and unexpected illness on July 9, 1850. What actually took down this previously robust military man?

curated_info.author: Joshua Wolf Shenk
curated_info.excerpt: Abraham Lincoln fought clinical depression all his life, and if he were alive today, his condition would be treated as a “character issue”—that is, as a political liability. His condition was indeed a character issue: it gave him the tools to save the nation.

curated_info.author: NPR Morning Edition
curated_info.excerpt: President Grover Cleveland believed that if anything happened to his trademark mustache during his surgery at sea, the public would know something was wrong.

curated_info.author: Stacy Conradt
curated_info.excerpt: During the summer of 1923, President Warren G. Harding and First Lady Florence Harding did what many do during the warmer months: They decided to take a road trip. Though much of the trip went well, by the end of the summer, Harding would end up dead and his wife’s reputation under attack.

curated_info.author: Dr. Howard Markel
curated_info.excerpt: After President Woodrow Wilson suffered a debilitating stroke on Oct. 2, 1919, First Lady Edith Bolling Galt Wilson was, essentially, the nation’s chief executive until her husband’s second term concluded in March of 1921.

curated_info.author: Michael S. Rosenwald
curated_info.excerpt: Roosevelt, diagnosed with congestive heart failure, probably had a year to live, a doctor said. The president, a Democrat, decided to run anyway — and to do everything he could to put a healthy face on a dying one.

curated_info.author: Robert Dallek
curated_info.excerpt: The core of the Kennedy image was, in many respects, a lie. A presidential biographer, granted access to medical files, portrays a man far sicker than the public knew.

curated_info.author: Isaac Chotiner
curated_info.excerpt: An interview with Lawrence Altman, a physician who has been writing for the New York Times for more than fifty years, with a focus on the health of political leaders. His interview with Ronald Reagan in 1980 marked the first time a candidate had extensively discussed his health with a reporter.

curated_info.author: Julia Belluz
curated_info.excerpt: Why was Rutherford B. Hayes the healthiest US president of all time?

collections.description: There has been nothing in American history quite like the President of the United States being infected with a potentially deadly virus amid a global pandemic less than a month before Election Day. But President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis is part of a long history of White House medical dramas.
collections.subtitle: There’s a long history of presidential ailments, including George Washington’s near-death encounter with the flu, Grover Cleveland’s secret tumor, and the clandestine suffering of John F. Kennedy.
collections.title: There’s a long history of presidential ailments, including George Washington’s near-death encounter with the flu, Grover Cleveland’s secret tumor, and the clandestine suffering of John F. Kennedy.

curated_info.author: Barton Gellman
curated_info.excerpt: In this election year of plague and recession and catastrophized politics, the mechanisms of decision are at meaningful risk of breaking down.

curated_info.author: Russ Buettner, Susanne Craig, and Mike McIntire
curated_info.excerpt: The Times obtained Donald Trump’s tax information extending over more than two decades, revealing struggling properties, vast write-offs, an audit battle and hundreds of millions in debt coming due.

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: As the U.S. heads toward the winter, the country is going round in circles, making the same conceptual errors that have plagued it since spring.

curated_info.author: Oliver Burkeman
curated_info.excerpt: After more than a decade of writing life-changing advice, I know when to move on. Here’s what else I learned.

curated_info.author: Justin Bariso
curated_info.excerpt: The rule of awkward silence has always been valuable. But in a world of instant gratification, it’s more useful than ever.

curated_info.author: Nir Eyal
curated_info.excerpt: Stop blaming technology – distraction starts within. Manage your inner triggers to enjoy greater focus and a fuller life

curated_info.author: Sarah Sloat
curated_info.excerpt: Research finds highly intelligent individuals prefer to socialize less than the rest of us.

curated_info.author: Jessica Brown
curated_info.excerpt: Oils are all packed with fat and calories, but their chemistry – and effect on our health – can be very different.

curated_info.author: Marisa G Franco
curated_info.excerpt: Friendships give us so much. Be bold, take the initiative, and you’ll be surprised how many people are pleased to connect.

curated_info.author: Philip Ellis
curated_info.excerpt: A doctor of physical therapy explains why she recommends the simple breathing exercise.

collections.description: Staying on top of the news has always been taxing—in 2020, that’s especially true. This September, the three most-saved stories by the Pocket community were concerned takes on the upcoming U.S. election and America’s handling of the pandemic, as well as The New York Times’ deep dive into President Trump’s taxes.
collections.subtitle: In September 2020, the Pocket community was focused on stressful current events—and stress-busting techniques.
collections.title: In September 2020, the Pocket community was focused on stressful current events—and stress-busting techniques.

curated_info.author: Boria Sax
curated_info.excerpt: If museums of natural history are temples to science, dinosaurs are their shrines.

curated_info.author: Chantel Tattoli
curated_info.excerpt: Most dinosaurs are dusted off as fragmentary skeletons. But those few bones can be enough to describe a new species, and on average, a new species is discovered every week. We are in the golden age of paleontology.

curated_info.author: Sara Chodosh
curated_info.excerpt: Paleontologists pull inspiration from modern birds and reptiles to design true-to-life T. rexes.

curated_info.author: Steve Macone
curated_info.excerpt: On the cusp of adulthood in an era of in-betweens, a search for fossils and meaning.

curated_info.author: Riley Black
curated_info.excerpt: The true story behind our obsession with the last and largest of the tyrannosaurs.

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Yuko
curated_info.excerpt: Though you may have never specifically thought about how much dinosaurs weighed, this is something that paleobiologists have been trying to figure out for more than a century.

curated_info.author: Kimberly Mas
curated_info.excerpt: A fully intact T. rex has never been found, but building one is no problem.

curated_info.author: Cody Cassidy
curated_info.excerpt: If, through some scientific malfunction, you found yourself transported 70 million years into the past, you might be safer from certain hungry reptiles than you think.

curated_info.author: Hilary Pollack
curated_info.excerpt: We asked experts for insight into what tearing into a rack of Tyrannosaur ribs would be like, from a flavor and texture perspective, and it doesn’t sound half bad.

curated_info.author: Douglas Preston
curated_info.excerpt: A young paleontologist may have discovered a record of the most significant event in the history of life on Earth.

curated_info.author: Daniel Kolitz
curated_info.excerpt: To find out, Gizmodo reached out to a number of geologists, paleontologists, and evolutionary biologists.

curated_info.author: Emily Singer
curated_info.excerpt: Modern birds appeared to emerge in a snap of evolutionary time. But new research illuminates the long series of evolutionary changes that made the transformation possible.

curated_info.author: Lukas Rieppel
curated_info.excerpt: In 19th-Century America, rare old bones were a resource like any other.

curated_info.author: Laura Poppick
curated_info.excerpt: Stegosaur expert Susie Maidment is laying crucial groundwork for assigning ages to fossils from North America’s most dinosaur-rich rocks. More precise timings promise to reveal plenty about how the beasts lived and evolved through time.

curated_info.author: Steve Hendrix
curated_info.excerpt: The “Wankel T. rex” is one of the largest and most complete skeletons of the meat-eating dinosaur ever found.

curated_info.author: Sabrina Imbler
curated_info.excerpt: Turns out massive flood control projects are a great way to find dinosaurs.

collections.description: If you ever want to put things in perspective, consider this: Less time separates human beings in history from Tyrannosaurus rex than T. rex from Stegosaurus. That’s right. While T. rex went extinct about 66 million years ago, at the end of the Cretaceous Period, the Jurassic Period’s stegosaurus roamed the Earth 83 million years before T. rex had even evolved. All told, dinosaurs ruled the planet for some 180 million years, while homo sapiens emerged a paltry 200,000 years ago.
collections.subtitle: Triceratops! Stegosaurus! T. rex! Channel your inner five year old with this Brachiosaurus-sized collection of the best articles about dinosaurs, dinosaur fossils, and dinosaur hunters.

curator.about:
About the Curator

A former senior culture writer for BuzzFeed, Anne Helen Petersen now writes her newsletter, Culture Study, as a full-time venture on Substack. Petersen received her PhD at the University of Texas at Austin, where she focused on the history of celebrity gossip. Her previous books, “Too Fat, Too Slutty, Too Loud” and “Scandals of Classic Hollywood,” were featured in NPR, Elle, and the Atlantic. She lives in Missoula, Montana.
curator.name: Amy Maoz

collections.description: When Buzzfeed News published How Millennials Became The Burnout Generation in early 2019, culture writer Anne Helen Petersen helped a weary generation name and legitimize their feelings of unrest. Over a year and a half later, the piece has earned over seven million reads, status as the most-Pocketed story of 2019, and an offline spin-off: Petersen’s new book “Can’t Even: How Millennials Became the Burnout Generation,” out from Houghton Mifflin Harcourt on September 22.
collections.subtitle: Anne Helen Petersen opened her Pocket to give us a peek at a dozen of the articles that inspired and informed “Can’t Even: How Millennials Became the Burnout Generation.”

curator.about:
About the Curator

Carla Murphy is an essayist and editor whose tenure as a reporter informs her current interest in journalism reform. She edits Lewis Raven Wallace’s The View from Somewhere podcast, and is a 2020-2021 visiting fellow in Boston College’s journalism program and VP and member of the board of the Journalism & Women Symposium (JAWS). Follow her on Twitter @carlamurphy.
curator.name: Carla Murphy

collections.description: After the George Floyd protests in May, Black journalists in the United States started a revolt of their own. What began with industry outcry over the on-camera arrest of a Black CNN reporter in Minneapolis (while his white colleague also worked nearby, untouched) escalated on Twitter to Black and other journalists of color exposing workplace frustrations over racism, representation and “objectivity” that affect how U.S. newsrooms cover the police killings of unarmed Black men and women. Top editors stepped down. Journalists resigned. Advertisers balked. Some outlets promised change—and still the airing of dirty laundry continues apace on Twitter.
collections.subtitle: How the latest reckoning on race is disrupting the nation’s media outlets.
collections.title: How the latest reckoning on race is disrupting the nation’s media outlets.

curated_info.author: Alan Henry
curated_info.excerpt: The best online reviews offer up the kind of information that’s invaluable when making a decision.
curated_info.title: How to Write Genuinely Useful Reviews Online

curated_info.author: Alison Green
curated_info.excerpt: Ten personalized, compelling cover letters are likely to get you far more interview invitations than 50 generic ones will.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Cover Letter That Will Get You a Job

curated_info.author: Kara Alaimo
curated_info.excerpt: Be personal. Be clear-sighted. And don’t be afraid to laugh at yourself.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Killer Commencement Speech

curated_info.author: Emma Cook
curated_info.excerpt: Everyone has a book in them, but how do you get it out? Here are some great tips from the ‘book doctor’ Philippa Pride.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Bestselling Novel

curated_info.author: Olga Khazan
curated_info.excerpt: Expert advice on ending procrastination and finishing that manuscript, dissertation, or other big project.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Book Without Losing Your Mind

curated_info.author: Drew Magary
curated_info.excerpt: The most productive writers know that writing is only one step in a larger process.
curated_info.title: How to Write 10,000 Words a Week

collections.description: There’s an old saying attributed to legendary sports journalist Red Smith: “There’s nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and open a vein.” The technology may have changed since the 1940s; the painful parts, unfortunately, haven’t. But that’s no reason for despair. Whether you’re just looking to punch up your tweets or have ambitions to write the Great American Novel, we’ve got you covered with this collection of great articles about the craft of writing, well, just about anything.
collections.subtitle: Whether you’re just looking to punch up your tweets or have ambitions to write the Great American Novel, we’ve got you covered.
collections.title: Whether you’re just looking to punch up your tweets or have ambitions to write the Great American Novel, we’ve got you covered.

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: A virus has brought the world’s most powerful country to its knees.
curated_info.title: How the Pandemic Defeated America

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: Which is too bad because we really need to understand how the immune system reacts to the coronavirus.
curated_info.title: Immunology Is Where Intuition Goes to Die

curated_info.author: Wade Davis
curated_info.excerpt: Anthropologist Wade Davis on how COVID-19 signals the end of the American era.
curated_info.title: The Unraveling of America

curated_info.author: Irina Aleksander
curated_info.excerpt: Even before the pandemic, the whole fashion industry had started to unravel. What happens now that no one has a reason to dress up?
curated_info.title: Sweatpants Forever

curated_info.author: Laura Huang and Ryan Yu
curated_info.excerpt: How do you convince someone who doesn’t see eye-to-eye with you? Someone who gives you a flat out “no”?
curated_info.title: How to (Actually) Change Someone’s Mind

curated_info.author: Steven Levy
curated_info.excerpt: The techie-turned-philanthropist on vaccines, Trump, and why social media is “a poisoned chalice.”
curated_info.title: Bill Gates on COVID: Most US Tests Are ‘Completely Garbage’

curated_info.author: Arthur C. Brooks
curated_info.excerpt: The pursuit of achievement distracts from the deeply ordinary activities and relationships that make life meaningful.
curated_info.title: ‘Success Addicts’ Choose Being Special Over Being Happy

curated_info.author: Christine Hauser
curated_info.excerpt: As the influenza pandemic swept across the United States in 1918 and 1919, masks took a role in political and cultural wars.
curated_info.title: The Mask Slackers of 1918

curated_info.author: Graham Averill
curated_info.excerpt: In his book, “Lifespan,” celebrated scientist David Sinclair lays out exactly why we age—and why he thinks we don’t have to.
curated_info.title: This Scientist Believes Aging Is Optional

curated_info.author: Jesse Frederik
curated_info.excerpt: Blockchain technology is going to change everything: the shipping industry, financial system, government … But enthusiasm for it mainly stems from a lack of knowledge and understanding. The blockchain is a solution in search of a problem.
curated_info.title: Blockchain, The Amazing Solution for Almost Nothing

collections.description: It might not come as a surprise, but the coronavirus pandemic was top of mind for Pocket users in August. Six of the top 10 most-saved stories for the month were about the virus, with science journalist Ed Yong’s coronavirus coverage for The Atlantic claiming the top two spots. Pocket readers were also interested in COVID-19’s far-reaching impact and historical parallels, including a New York Times deep dive into the pandemic’s effect on high fashion and an exploration of the 1918 culture war over face masks.
collections.subtitle: The far-reaching effects of the coronavirus pandemic were top of mind for Pocket users in August.
collections.title: The far-reaching effects of the coronavirus pandemic were top of mind for Pocket users in August.

curated_info.author: A. Roger Ekirch
curated_info.excerpt: A madman versus a crook? Unexpected twists? Fake news? Welcome to the election of 1800.
curated_info.title: The Immigration-Obsessed, Polarized, Garbage-Fire Election of 1800

curated_info.author: Mark R. Cheathem
curated_info.excerpt: Outlandish rumors helped elect Presidents Andrew Jackson and Martin Van Buren and have been with us ever since.
curated_info.title: When American Politicos First Weaponized Conspiracy Theories

curated_info.author: Harold Holzer
curated_info.excerpt: As soon as the returns were in, the burdens of the presidency weighed upon Abraham Lincoln.
curated_info.title: Election Day 1860

curated_info.author: Becky Little
curated_info.excerpt: Fearing Abraham Lincoln would lose reelection, some wondered if the country should delay the election.
curated_info.title: How the Union Pulled Off a Presidential Election During the Civil War

curated_info.author: Ed Kilgore
curated_info.excerpt: If you want an example of a real nation-rending, Constitution-bending contested presidential election that might have conceivably led to a second Civil War, you have to go back to the U.S. Centennial Year of 1876.
curated_info.title: The Last Time a Contested Presidential Election Nearly Tore the Country Apart

curated_info.author: S.J. Ackerman
curated_info.excerpt: Old style ballots cast illegally in Indiana helped President Grover Cleveland in 1888.
curated_info.title: The Vote That Failed

curated_info.author: Will Moreland
curated_info.excerpt: Though the election of 1948 is best remembered for the Chicago Tribune newspaper’s embarrassing, incorrect “Dewey Defeats Truman” headline, its forgotten story is of Henry Wallace, a liberal dreamer who became the Kremlin’s unwitting pawn.
curated_info.title: The Last Russian Leader to Mess With a US Election? Josef Stalin.

curated_info.author: John A. Farrell
curated_info.excerpt: It took decades to unravel Richard Nixon’s sabotage of Vietnam peace talks in 1968. Now, the full story can be told.
curated_info.title: When a Candidate Conspired With a Foreign Power to Win An Election

curated_info.author: Ena Alvarado-Esteller, David A. Graham, Cullen Murphy, and Amy Weiss-Meyer
curated_info.excerpt: An oral history of the craziest presidential election in modern history.
curated_info.title: The Bush-Gore Recount Is an Omen for 2020

curated_info.author: The Editors
curated_info.excerpt: What really happened?
curated_info.title: The Untold Stories of Election Day 2016

curated_info.author: Jill Lepore
curated_info.excerpt: Voting in America, it’s fair to say, used to be different. The founders didn’t anticipate that voting would be done in secret. And, in the middle decades of the nineteenth century, eighty-nine Americans were killed at the polls during Election Day riots.
curated_info.title: How We Used to Vote

collections.description: Partisan rancor. Conspiracy theories. Disenfranchised voters. Foreign meddling. Contested results. Maybe it’s not exactly a comfort, but the United States has seen it all before. Dive into the history of contentious presidential elections that rival 2020 for drama and intrigue, including the “Corrupt Bargain” of 1824 (when a popular-vote loser squeaked into the White House for the first time), the 1864 election (held during the middle of the Civil War), and, yeah, the last one.
collections.subtitle: An electoral chaos reading list.
collections.title: An electoral chaos reading list.

curated_info.author: Alex Moshakis
curated_info.excerpt: Some sleep on electromagnetic mats, others pop up to 150 pills a day. But are ‘life extensionists’ any closer to finding the key to longevity?
curated_info.title: How To Live Forever: Meet the Extreme Life-Extensionists

curated_info.author: Cynthia Koons
curated_info.excerpt: It’s based on the substance that causes botulism. That’s part of what protects Allergan’s $2.8 billion Botox empire.
curated_info.title: The Wonder Drug for Aging (Made From One of the Deadliest Toxins on Earth)

curated_info.author: David Adam
curated_info.excerpt: If this controversial idea gains acceptance, it could radically change the way we treat getting old.
curated_info.title: What If Aging Weren’t Inevitable, but a Curable Disease?

curated_info.author: Cheryl Wischhover
curated_info.excerpt: Brands are still selling the idea of trying to look younger — they’ve just changed the vocabulary.
curated_info.title: The Fall of “Anti-Aging” Skin Care

curated_info.author: Joel Stein
curated_info.excerpt: At the dawn of a new decade, I wondered: How many more decades can I live?
curated_info.title: I Biohacked for 10 Weeks To Try To Live Forever

curated_info.author: Audrey McGlinchy
curated_info.excerpt: The peat found in some anti-oxidant-rich wetlands has preserved the youthfulness of thousand-year-old corpses. Can it do the same for those who are still alive?
curated_info.title: Finding the Fountain of Youth in an Ancient Irish Bog

curated_info.author: Abby Mims
curated_info.excerpt: Five years after her mother’s death, while still grieving and suddenly middle-aged, one writer turns to beauty products to cure what ails her.
curated_info.title: Searching Sephora for an Antidote to Aging — and Grief

curated_info.author: Lauren Collins
curated_info.excerpt: Some researchers have cast doubt on the record of the celebrated supercentenarian.
curated_info.title: Was Jeanne Calment the Oldest Person Who Ever Lived—or a Fraud?

curated_info.author: Sam Anderson
curated_info.excerpt: I went to Florida recently to follow the traces of the traces of the legend of Juan Ponce de León.
curated_info.title: Searching for the Fountain of Youth

curated_info.author: Ezekiel J. Emanuel
curated_info.excerpt: An argument that society and families—and you—will be better off if nature takes its course swiftly and promptly.
curated_info.title: Why I Hope to Die at 75

collections.description: At what age does adding another birthday candle go from a thrill to slog? Society’s obsession with turning back the clock has brought us everything from pricey face creams and injectable toxins to cryogenic chambers and “miracle” diets. Explore this collection of great reads on some of our most quixotic attempts at staying forever young.
collections.subtitle: Our longing to turn back the clock has brought us everything from pricey face creams to cryogenic chambers.
collections.title: Our longing to turn back the clock has brought us everything from pricey face creams to cryogenic chambers.

curated_info.author: Sylvia Varnham O’Regan
curated_info.excerpt: Inside the strange, predatory, and lucrative world of psychics who have successfully scammed customers out of their life savings, and the private investigator who’s trying to put a stop to it.
curated_info.title: When a Psychic Reading Costs You $740,000

curated_info.author: Mark Seal
curated_info.excerpt: Investors all over the world fell for the schemes of the man who called himself Khalid bin al-Saud. But the truth turned out to be more incredible than the lie.
curated_info.title: “He Actually Believes He Is Khalid”: The Amazing 30-Year Odyssey of a Counterfeit Saudi Prince

curated_info.author: Allie Conti
curated_info.excerpt: While searching for the person who grifted me in Chicago, I discovered just how easy it is for users of the short-term rental platform to get exploited.
curated_info.title: I Accidentally Uncovered a Nationwide Scam on Airbnb

curated_info.author: Brian X. Chen
curated_info.excerpt: Fraudsters see opportunities to target us in these uncertain times. Here are their most popular schemes and how we can protect ourselves.
curated_info.title: A Guide to Pandemic Scams, and What Not to Fall For

curated_info.author: Jessica Pressler
curated_info.excerpt: The story of New York City’s most notorious faux heiress-turned-inmate, Anna Delvey, and the wild antics that won her intrigue—and tens of thousands of dollars.
curated_info.title: Maybe She Had So Much Money She Just Lost Track of It

curated_info.author: Maria Konnikova
curated_info.excerpt: Are con artists clinical psychopaths—or are they just slightly more devious versions of our more conniving selves?
curated_info.title: Psychopathic, Narcissistic Machiavellians

curated_info.author: Arielle Pardes
curated_info.excerpt: The pink princess philodendron is the ultimate Instagram plant, with three-digit price tags to match. The following it cultivated was also ripe for deception.
curated_info.title: The Princess, the Plantfluencers, and the Pink Congo Scam

curated_info.author: Dustin Grinnell
curated_info.excerpt: The son of a bank robber and sibling of a psychopath explains how he found his own calling scamming a litany of unsuspecting suckers.
curated_info.title: Secret Life of a Con Man

curated_info.author: Genevieve Carlton
curated_info.excerpt: Frisland never existed, but for centuries, people wanted to believe that it did.
curated_info.title: How to Put a Fake Island on the Map

curated_info.author: Alexis Conran
curated_info.excerpt: People and businesses routinely use five techniques to get us to do what they want. Here’s how to recognize them.
curated_info.title: Don’t Get Fooled or Conned Again — Here Are the 5 Tactics to Look out For

curated_info.author: Guy Lawson
curated_info.excerpt: That old adage that you can be anything you want? Well, Jeremy Wilson has lived it for years, crisscrossing the country and inventing new identities. A war hero, an MIT grad, a Hollywood journalist, an IRA operative—Jeremy has claimed to be all those things and more. And oh, what a mess he’s made.
curated_info.title: The Grand Schemes of the Petty Grifter

curated_info.author: Jacob Bernstein
curated_info.excerpt: Nicolas DeMeyer was a scammer. Or a hero for the age of inequality. Or a young man haunted by the death of a dear friend. Or all of these things.
curated_info.title: The Wine Thief

collections.description: Con artists have been scamming and scheming since ancient times. And yet every generation seems to bring a new bag of tricks, inspired by the latest app, platform, or pandemic there is to exploit. Take a careful step into our collection of great features about capers and frauds, and uncover some prudent advice on how to avoid becoming an unsuspecting sucker.
collections.subtitle: Every generation seems to bring a new bag of tricks, inspired by the latest app, platform, or pandemic there is to exploit.
collections.title: Every generation seems to bring a new bag of tricks, inspired by the latest app, platform, or pandemic there is to exploit.

curated_info.author: Deborah Barfield Berry
curated_info.excerpt: The search for one woman’s family led a reporter to find her own roots using oral history, archives and DNA tests. It also led to stunning results.
curated_info.title: I Was Writing About Colonial America’s First Enslaved Africans. I Was Stunned to Find My Ancestors, Too.

curated_info.author: Alix Spiegel and Elena Renken
curated_info.excerpt: Joy and her super smelling abilities have opened up a whole new realm of research.
curated_info.title: Her Incredible Sense of Smell Is Helping Scientists Find New Ways to Diagnose Disease

curated_info.author: Alexandra Alter
curated_info.excerpt: The last original Dr. Seuss book was released in 1990. No one at Random House expected an unpublished book to appear 24 years after Theodor Seuss Geisel’s death.
curated_info.title: Dr. Seuss Book: Yes, They Found It in a Box

curated_info.author: Jonathan Lambert
curated_info.excerpt: Neither animal, plant, fungus nor familiar protozoan, a strange microbe foretells incredible biodiversity yet to be discovered by new sequencing technologies.
curated_info.title: What a Newfound Kingdom Means for the Tree of Life

curated_info.author: Jason Fagone
curated_info.excerpt: Discovering a lottery loophole made Jerry and Marge Selbee millionaires and exposed more than a few hypocrisies at the heart of America’s favorite form of legalized gambling.
curated_info.title: Jerry and Marge Go Large

curated_info.author: Lorraine Boissoneault
curated_info.excerpt: First found only on the sun, scientists doubted the mysterious element even existed for more than a decade.
curated_info.title: How Scientists Discovered Helium, the First Alien Element, 150 Years Ago

curated_info.author: Alan Burdick
curated_info.excerpt: Researchers first observed the previously unnamed shape in a computer model. They then went to nature and found it in abundance.
curated_info.title: We Are All Scutoids: A Brand-New Shape, Explained

curated_info.author: Katherine Davis-Young
curated_info.excerpt: Manny Medrano cut loose on spring break by analyzing a set of khipus.
curated_info.title: The College Student Who Decoded the Data Hidden in Inca

curated_info.author: Daniel Engber
curated_info.excerpt: How one carefully calibrated study—and its shocking results—upended the academic system.
curated_info.title: Daryl Bem Proved ESP Is Real

curated_info.author: Sarah Spain
curated_info.excerpt: Kansas City Chiefs running backs coach Deland McCullough went searching for his biological parents. He found them where he never would have expected.
curated_info.title: Runs in the Family

collections.description: History-making breakthroughs don’t just happen in the lab. From finding family in the most unexpected of places to uncovering messages hidden in 16th-century Incan knots, these 10 stories embrace the thrill—and momentum—of discovery. So dive in—who knows what you might find?
collections.subtitle: From finding family in the most unexpected of places to uncovering messages hidden in 16th-century Incan knots.
collections.title: From finding family in the most unexpected of places to uncovering messages hidden in 16th-century Incan knots.

curated_info.author: Erin Blakemore
curated_info.excerpt: Despite being a heartbeat from the presidency, this role was surprisingly ill-defined throughout much of the country’s history.
curated_info.title: How U.S. Vice Presidents Went From Irrelevant to Influential

curated_info.author: Teresa Wiltz
curated_info.excerpt: Amid the celebratory memes rocketing around yesterday, other women of color who’ve cracked through ceilings have some advice: Buckle up.
curated_info.title: Here’s What Kamala Harris Faces as a ‘First’

curated_info.author: Brennan Weiss
curated_info.excerpt: Almost everyone knows the White House, but few people know that the vice president has an official residence of their own.
curated_info.title: Inside Number One Observatory Circle

curated_info.author: Ronald G. Shafer
curated_info.excerpt: Was John Tyler really president after pneumonia claimed the life of William Henry Harrison? In 1841, the country wasn’t sure.
curated_info.title: ‘His Accidency’: The First President to Die in Office and the Constitutional Confusion That Followed

curated_info.author: Gil Troy
curated_info.excerpt: A hoax about the president’s death led him to believe he was Commander-in-Chief—and it paralyzed him with fear.
curated_info.title: The Most Useless Veep in U.S. History

curated_info.author: Stacy Conradt
curated_info.excerpt: To date, Charles Dawes is the only Vice President to have a song chart at #1, though he missed the whole thing.
curated_info.title: The Vice President Who Wrote a Hit Song

curated_info.author: Jeffrey Frank
curated_info.excerpt: The possibility of a sudden succession now plays a larger part in the selection of Vice-Presidents, but not always.
curated_info.title: How F.D.R.’s Death Changed the Vice-Presidency

curated_info.author: Tony Horwitz
curated_info.excerpt: The U.S. vice presidency has been filled by a rogues gallery of mediocrities, criminals and even corpses.
curated_info.title: The Vice Presidents That History Forgot

curated_info.author: Jaime Fuller
curated_info.excerpt: John Adams, the first vice president: “I am Vice President. In this I am nothing, but I may be everything.”
curated_info.title: A Brief History of Vice Presidents Bemoaning the Vice Presidency

curated_info.author: Nicole Hemmer
curated_info.excerpt: Choosing a running mate used to be more about campaigning than governing. But after Richard Nixon’s ruinous relationship with Spiro Agnew, the job has changed. Introducing the executive vice presidency.
curated_info.title: Why the Vice Presidency Matters

collections.description: With Sen. Kamala Harris making history as the first woman elected to the vice presidency, you might be asking yourself: what, exactly, does the vice president do? For much of American history, the answer was “not much.” But since the end of World War II, the vice president’s job has evolved from a constitutional afterthought to an indispensable part of the executive branch.
collections.subtitle: From the Veep who wrote a #1 song to the one considered the most useless in history.
collections.title: From the Veep who wrote a #1 song to the one considered the most useless in history.

curated_info.author: Kenneth R. Rosen
curated_info.excerpt: It is difficult to identify burnout, which often feels like surrender or failure rather than what it really is: a chronic disease.
curated_info.title: How to Recognize Burnout Before You’re Burned Out

curated_info.author: Florence Williams
curated_info.excerpt: As it turns out, our supercharged lives aren’t great for us. Fitness experts and doctors now emphasize restorative practices and rest to improve performance and overall health.
curated_info.title: Your 2020 Burnout Recovery Plan

curated_info.author: Alina Dizik
curated_info.excerpt: You shouldn’t underestimate the positive power of having a degree of stress in your life. Identifying the tipping point, where stress turns to burnout, is the key.
curated_info.title: The Strange Psychology of Stress and Burnout

curated_info.author: Rebecca Zucker
curated_info.excerpt: Feeling “in over our heads” has nothing to do with how smart we are, but with how we make sense of the world and how we operate in it.
curated_info.title: How to Deal with Feeling Constantly Overwhelmed

curated_info.author: Michael Steger
curated_info.excerpt: It’s a gift when work is so meaningful that you’d do it for free. And that’s also a problem.
curated_info.title: Does a Meaningful Job Need to Burn You Out?

curated_info.author: Anne Helen Petersen
curated_info.excerpt: I couldn’t figure out why small, straightforward tasks on my to-do list felt so impossible. The answer is both more complex and far simpler than I expected.
curated_info.title: How Millennials Became the Burnout Generation

curated_info.author: Moya Sarner
curated_info.excerpt: What, exactly, is a ‘state of vital exhaustion,’ and how can you come back from it?
curated_info.title: How Burnout Became a Sinister and Insidious Epidemic

collections.subtitle: How to identify and combat the symptoms of burnout before they become debilitating.
collections.title: How to identify and combat the symptoms of burnout before they become debilitating.

curated_info.author: Casey Cep
curated_info.excerpt: A century after the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment, it’s worth remembering why suffragists had to fight so hard, and who was fighting against them.
curated_info.title: The Imperfect, Unfinished Work of Women’s Suffrage

curated_info.author: Anne Wallentine
curated_info.excerpt: The material history of the movement reveals many of its priorities and problems, and its relevance to the persisting struggles for equal rights today.
curated_info.title: A History of the US Women’s Suffrage Movement in Five Objects

curated_info.author: Erin Blakemore
curated_info.excerpt: This leading suffragist devoted her life to the movement but never got to vote—legally at least.
curated_info.title: Susan B. Anthony Fought for Women’s Suffrage in the Face of Ridicule

curated_info.author: Meilan Solly
curated_info.excerpt: The process varied by state, with some making accommodations for the new voting bloc and others creating additional obstacles.
curated_info.title: What the First Women Voters Experienced When Registering for the 1920 Election

curated_info.author: Martha S. Jones
curated_info.excerpt: Racism and sexism were bound together in the fight to vote – and Black women made it clear they would never cede the question of their voting rights to others.
curated_info.title: The US Suffragette Movement Tried to Leave Out Black Women. They Showed Up Anyway

curated_info.author: Samantha Schmidt
curated_info.excerpt: The anti-suffragist women would become a nationwide force that would influence later generations of conservative women. And today, a century after women gained the right to vote, echoes of their message remain.
curated_info.title: Why Thousands of Women Fought Against the Right to Vote

curated_info.author: Christine Crudo Blackburn, Gerald W. Parker and Morten Wendelbo
curated_info.excerpt: The aftermath of the 1918 flu pandemic led to unexpected social changes, opened up new opportunities for women and irreversibly transformed life in the United States.
curated_info.title: How the Devastating 1918 Flu Pandemic Helped Advance US Women’s Rights

curated_info.author: Wendy L. Rouse
curated_info.excerpt: “Would you rather have a vote than a husband?”
curated_info.title: The Very Queer History of the Suffrage Movement

curated_info.author: Cathleen D. Cahill and Sarah Deer
curated_info.excerpt: The 19th Amendment did not bring the right to vote to all Native women, but two experts in a conversation said it did usher in the possibility of change.
curated_info.title: In 1920, Native Women Sought the Vote. Here’s What’s Next.

curated_info.author: Maggie Fuller
curated_info.excerpt: On the 100th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, trace the route of the national women’s suffrage movement and stand in the spots where history happened.
curated_info.title: Celebrate Women’s Suffrage on an Epic, Self-Guided Road Trip

curated_info.author: Melissa Gira Grant
curated_info.excerpt: The women who remain locked out of the right to vote are the fractured legacy of a fractured movement.
curated_info.title: The Unfinished Business of Women’s Suffrage

collections.description: American democracy is a lot younger than it looks. Just 100 years ago, on August 18, 1920, the 19th Amendment was ratified, enshrining women’s right to vote in the U.S. Constitution. While women’s suffrage was hard won, the battle for the ballot would continue for decades, especially for Black and Indigenous women. This collection explores the history and impact of that century-old victory, and the complicated legacy that still informs today.
collections.subtitle: On the 100th anniversary, explore the fascinating history and complicated legacy of this democratic milestone.
collections.title: On the 100th anniversary, explore the fascinating history and complicated legacy of this democratic milestone.

curated_info.author: December 1987
curated_info.excerpt: “Once there was another city here, and now it is gone. There are almost no traces of it anymore, but millions of us know it existed, because we lived in it: the Lost City of New York.”

curated_info.author: June 13, 1968
curated_info.excerpt: “Kennedy’s face had a kind of sweet acceptance to it, the eyes understanding that it had come to him, the way it had come to so many others before him. The price of the attempt at excellence was death”

curated_info.author: September 12, 2001
curated_info.excerpt: “We were gathered at a large table in the Tweed Courthouse, discussing over bagels and coffee its future as a symbol of civilization, a museum of the history of New York. About 8:45, we heard a boom.”

curated_info.author: June 5, 1975
curated_info.excerpt: “He is the sort of artist, like the aforementioned Picasso, who is always in the process of becoming. I think of this as a kind of interim report from one of the bravest human beings I know.”

curated_info.author: December 1989
curated_info.excerpt: “The Man of the Decade? Easy—that guy who built, uh, What’s-his-name Tower.”

curated_info.author: June 1996
curated_info.excerpt: “For too long a time, I loved the brutal sport of prizefighting. But I’ve arrived at last at that cold morning. You cannot love anything that lives in a sewer.”

curated_info.author: October 1974
curated_info.excerpt: “It is no accident that Nixon was from California. He was a master of desecration. And make no mistake: this place has been desecrated.”

curated_info.author: June 2019
curated_info.excerpt: “Count your blessings: if you ever wrote a regular column for the New York Daily News you’ve had one of the best jobs in the history of newspapers, a ringside seat at the greatest show on Earth.”

collections.description: “There’s no one New York,” Pete Hamill once said. “There’s multiple New Yorks. Anybody who sits and says ‘I know New York’ is from out of town.” The legendary journalist, who chronicled daily life in the Big Apple for more than 50 years as a columnist for the New York Post, New York Daily News, New York Newsday, and The Village Voice, died this week at age 85. Hamill’s punchy prose, everyman sensibilities, and unabashed love of the news business and the city he covered inspired a generation of journalists.
collections.subtitle: Remembering the legendary journalist with a collection of some of his best articles, including a frank conversation with John Lennon and encounters with Donald Trump.
collections.title: Remembering the legendary journalist with a collection of some of his best articles, including a frank conversation with John Lennon and encounters with Donald Trump.

curated_info.author: Michael Greshko
curated_info.excerpt: Human memory happens in many parts of the brain at once, and some types of memories stick around longer than others.

curated_info.author: Shayla Love
curated_info.excerpt: Memory researchers say these months will eventually become a blur for those of us isolating at home.
curated_info.title: You’ll Probably Forget What It Was Like to Live Through a Pandemic

curated_info.author: Linda Rodriguez McRobbie
curated_info.excerpt: An extremely rare condition may transform our understanding of memory.

curated_info.author: Erika Hayasaki
curated_info.excerpt: The strange case of the woman who can’t remember her past—or imagine her future.

curated_info.author: Amelia Tait
curated_info.excerpt: Hundreds of people online have shared memories of a cheesy ’90s movie called “Shazaam.” There is no evidence the film was ever made. What does this tell us about the quirks of collective memory?

curated_info.author: Kathy Benjamin
curated_info.excerpt: Long-term, immediate, and habitual methods for keeping your memories fresh and clear.

curated_info.author: Julie Beck
curated_info.excerpt: … and the movies and TV shows we watch.

curated_info.author: Ferris Jabr
curated_info.excerpt: Your brain needs to forget in order to grow.

curated_info.author: Eleanor Cummins
curated_info.excerpt: Societies forget, and this physicist wants to know why.

curated_info.author: Sarah Laskow
curated_info.excerpt: Scientists are beginning to understand that plants have abilities, previously unnoticed and unimagined, that we’ve only ever associated with animals.

curated_info.author: Louise Fabiani
curated_info.excerpt: Of the many experts who figured in Henry Molaison’s life, one man would change him into amnesiac patient H.M., but two women ensured he would never be forgotten.

curated_info.author: Clive Thompson
curated_info.excerpt: Nope. It’s much, much weirder than that.

curated_info.author: Christine Hyung-Oak Lee
curated_info.excerpt: An excerpt from Christine Hyung-Oak Lee’s memoir Tell Me Everything You Don’t Remember: The Stroke That Changed My Life.

curated_info.author: Ainslie Johnstone
curated_info.excerpt: Without the changes in the brain that allow you to learn new skills, nothing would be “as easy as learning to ride a bike.”

collections.description: Explore the mysteries of memory with this collection of fascinating articles that break down how we form memories, why we forget so much of our childhood, and the profound impact this has on our lives.
collections.subtitle: Our memories make us who we are, and as with anything involving the human brain, they’re pretty complicated.
collections.title: Our memories make us who we are, and as with anything involving the human brain, they’re pretty complicated.

curated_info.author: Loren Grush
curated_info.excerpt: Perseverance’s biggest goal is to dig up samples to bring back to Earth one day, where eager scientists will be waiting to receive them.
curated_info.title: NASA’s New Mars Rover Is About to Embark on a Hunt for Ancient Alien Life

curated_info.author: Becky Ferreira
curated_info.excerpt: How habitable was early Mars? Why did it become less hospitable? And could there be life there now?
curated_info.title: 3 Great Mysteries About Life on Mars

curated_info.author: Kate Greene
curated_info.excerpt: I spent four months pretending to live on Mars. Here’s what I learned about staying sane and passing time.
curated_info.title: Living Life at a Distance

curated_info.author: Brian Gallagher
curated_info.excerpt: Elon Musk wants to engineer Mars’ atmosphere and “make life multiplanetary.” Can he?
curated_info.title: So Can We Terraform Mars or Not?

curated_info.author: George RR Martin
curated_info.excerpt: The author behind Game of Thrones spent his childhood reading stories about Mars and hoping to write one himself. As new discoveries on the red planet capture the world’s attention, he surveys a rich Martian literature.
curated_info.title: George RR Martin: Our Long Obsession With Mars

curated_info.author: Sarah Stewart Johnson
curated_info.excerpt: Percival Lowell’s dogged belief helped bring Mars science to 19th century America.
curated_info.title: The Astronomer Who Believed There Was an Alien Utopia on Mars

curated_info.author: Marina Koren
curated_info.excerpt: A mission atop a Hawaiian volcano shows humans still have much to learn before they set foot on another world.
curated_info.title: When a Mars Simulation Goes Wrong

curated_info.author: Sarah Scoles
curated_info.excerpt: Astrobiologists have used Mars Jars for decades. Many didn’t know about the controversial Air Force scientist who started them.
curated_info.title: The Doctor From Nazi Germany and the Search for Life on Mars

curated_info.author: Alina Simone
curated_info.excerpt: “I don’t think you will find one single person that believes we are going to be able to do this.” The DIY explorers who dream of a 35-million-mile trek.

curated_info.author: David Warmflash
curated_info.excerpt: Is the Red Planet really the best target for a human colony, or should we look somewhere else?

curated_info.author: Rebecca Boyle
curated_info.excerpt: But this jerk planet is still humanity’s best hope for another home in the cosmos, at least for the foreseeable future.
curated_info.title: Everything About Mars Is the Worst

collections.description: The July 30th launch of NASA’s Perseverance rover brings us one step closer to a better understanding of the Red Planet. Explore these 11 fascinating stories about the potential for life on Mars (past and present), the science of getting there, and the lore that inspires the journey.
collections.subtitle: Earth to Mars: We’re on our way.
collections.title: Earth to Mars: We’re on our way.

curated_info.author: Matt Blintz
curated_info.excerpt: Beloved for its ease of use, the indispensable appliance was invented utterly by accident. Never underestimate the power of snacks and serendipity.
curated_info.title: The Amazing True Story of How the Microwave Was Invented by Accident

curated_info.author: James Geary
curated_info.excerpt: Serendipity is credited with some of our most important discoveries, from penicillin to super glue. But what is it?

curated_info.author: Jake Swearingen
curated_info.excerpt: How a hunting trip led George de Mestral to invent the velcro fastener—a middle ground between buttons, zippers, and simply sewing stuff together.
curated_info.title: An Idea That Stuck

curated_info.author: David Kindy
curated_info.excerpt: The much-loved children’s toy was a desperate spinoff of a putty used to clean soot off of wallpaper.
curated_info.title: The Accidental Invention of Play-Doh

curated_info.author: Jennifer Latson
curated_info.excerpt: No one was initially more skeptical of the existence of X-rays than Wilhelm Roentgen — the man who discovered them.
curated_info.title: The Shy Scientist Who Could See Through Skin

curated_info.author: Sarah Laskow
curated_info.excerpt: Three different artificial sweeteners have been the result of scientists with poor hand hygiene.

curated_info.author: Dr. Howard Markel
curated_info.excerpt: The discovery of penicillin, one of the first antibiotics, marks a true turning point. Many school children can recite the basics. But there is much more to the historic sequence of events.

curated_info.author: Jacopo Prisco
curated_info.excerpt: When he started fiddling with chemicals in his home in March 1856, William Henry Perkin had no idea what was about to happen.
curated_info.title: The Color Purple: How an Accidental Discovery Changed Fashion Forever

curated_info.author: James Simpson
curated_info.excerpt: Quick-bonding adhesive was a happy accident of wartime research. Its story begins just before World War II.
curated_info.title: Super Glue Built Planes, Nukes and Saved Soldiers’ Lives

collections.description: Necessity isn’t always the mother of invention. Sometimes it’s serendipity. Dive into these nine great reads about everyday innovations that were invented by accident, from life-changing penicillin to the whimsical wonder that is Play-Doh. Turns out even the color mauve came to us by chance.
collections.subtitle: From life-changing penicillin to the whimsical wonder that is Play-Doh.
collections.title: From life-changing penicillin to the whimsical wonder that is Play-Doh.

curated_info.author: Paul Theroux
curated_info.excerpt: In the spirit of Kerouac and Steinbeck, a celebrated travel writer fulfills a childhood fantasy: to drive across his native land.
curated_info.title: Taking the Great American Roadtrip

curated_info.author: Janine Rubenstein
curated_info.excerpt: Journalist Janine Rubenstein took her family on a road trip from New Jersey to California just days before George Floyd’s murder set this nation ablaze. Here’s what they learned about motor homes, the country and life.
curated_info.title: Inside a Black Family’s Cross-Country RV Trip

curated_info.author: Kathryn Miles
curated_info.excerpt: Make a new canine friend in Maine and chances are good she’s from down south. To understand why—and how they arrive—Kathryn Miles joined 37 very good dogs on a 1,600-mile road trip.

curated_info.author: Peter Brannen
curated_info.excerpt: A science journalist tours the geological ruins of our planet’s worst mass extinction ... in Western Kansas.
curated_info.title: A Road Trip to the End of the World

curated_info.author: Gustavo Arellano
curated_info.excerpt: This palate-scorching, Mexican hamburger- and adovada-fueled road trip up I-25 from Las Cruces to Denver is not for the faint of heart.
curated_info.title: The Great American Chile Highway

curated_info.author: David Samuels
curated_info.excerpt: A truck driver uncovers secrets about the first nuclear bombs and makes clear that our belief in the secrecy of the bomb is a theological construct, adopted to counter the idea that someone might use one against us.
