curated_info.author: Holly Patton
curated_info.excerpt: Doctors said we could blame my father’s football career for his vanishing memory. So Dad and I decided to take a road trip down south to revisit the schools that made him.
curated_info.title: Football, My Dad’s Dementia, and Me

curated_info.author: Karl Ove Knausgaard
curated_info.excerpt: In the land of Tolstoy, Turgenev and now Putin, what are the stories Russians are telling themselves?
curated_info.title: A Literary Road Trip Into the Heart of Russia

curated_info.author: Mary Melton
curated_info.excerpt: Alta Editor at Large Mary Melton searches for a deeper connection with her autistic son—and with a divided country—on a 15-day journey along Route 66.
curated_info.title: A Mother’s Road

curated_info.author: Michael Chabon
curated_info.excerpt: Why take your family to France or Florida when you could pack them into a minivan with a stranger in Morocco? Novelist Michael Chabon explains.
curated_info.title: That Time Writer Michael Chabon Packed His Family Into a Minivan With a Stranger in Morocco

curated_info.author: Bryan Di Salvatore
curated_info.excerpt: A recklessly picaresque, highly philosophical, gloriously unmapped road trip in search of secret places you’ll have to find yourself.
curated_info.title: Tracking the Elusive Western Shoe Tree

curated_info.author: Meredith Carey
curated_info.excerpt: It’s a rather insane premise: drive in a tiny, terrible car, from the U.K. to Mongolia and on into Siberia. But since 2004, thousands have driven the so-called “Mongol Rally,” raising money for charity along the way.
curated_info.title: 7 Weeks, 11,000 Miles, and 2 Tiny Cars: The Mongol Rally

curated_info.author: Pete Candler
curated_info.excerpt: “We were looking for endings: vestiges of a South we had not known in Atlanta.” A road trip through the Old South reveals uncomfortable family truths.
curated_info.title: A Deeper South

curated_info.author: Marya Hornbacher
curated_info.excerpt: Fleabag motels, caesuras, femme phases, double bank shots, stale sweat, McDonald’s, bedside Bibles, hatchbacks, counter girls, evolved orchids, tomorrow’s underwear, impetus & traffic signals in Laredo.
curated_info.title: Drifters (Interstate 35)

collections.description: Venture on an 11,000-mile odyssey across Eurasia, tag along with a mother and son as they discover Historic Route 66, and get lost in a science writer’s harrowing voyage to the Cretaceous Interior Seaway (also known as Western Kansas).
collections.subtitle: Hit the highway with this collection of some of our favorite reads about epic road trips.
collections.title: Hit the highway with this collection of some of our favorite reads about epic road trips.

curated_info.author: Safiya Umoja Noble
curated_info.excerpt: My first encounter with racism in search was in 2009 when I was talking to a friend who causally mentioned one day, “You should see what happens when you Google ‘black girls.’” I did and was stunned. (An excerpt from Algorithms of Oppression.)
curated_info.title: Google Has a Striking History of Bias Against Black Girls

curated_info.author: Julia Angwin, Jeff Larson, Surya Mattu and Lauren Kirchner
curated_info.excerpt: There’s software used across the country to predict future criminals. And it’s biased against blacks.
curated_info.title: Machine Bias

curated_info.author: Cade Metz
curated_info.excerpt: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
curated_info.title: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say

curated_info.author: Annette Zimmermann, Elena DiRosa, and Hochan Kim
curated_info.excerpt: We need greater democratic oversight of AI not just from developers and designers, but from all members of society.
curated_info.title: Technology Can’t Fix Algorithmic Injustice

curated_info.author: Rebecca Heilweil
curated_info.excerpt: A computer can make a decision faster. That doesn’t make it fair.
curated_info.title: Why Algorithms Can Be Racist and Sexist

curated_info.author: Safiya Noble
curated_info.excerpt: We need more intense attention on how artificial intelligence forestalls the ability to see what kinds of choices we are making.
curated_info.title: Social Inequality Will Not Be Solved by an App

curated_info.author: Sharon Begley
curated_info.excerpt: Algorithms used by hospitals and physicians to guide the health care given to tens of millions of Americans are shot through with implicit racism that their creators are often unaware of, according to a study.
curated_info.title: Racial Bias Skews Algorithms Widely Used to Guide Care from Heart Surgery to Birth, Study Finds

curated_info.author: Beth Schwartzapfel
curated_info.excerpt: A new study adds to the debate over racial bias in risk assessment tools widely used in courtrooms.
curated_info.title: Can Racist Algorithms Be Fixed?

curated_info.excerpt: The Apple Card debut stumbled as good credit scores didn’t help boost womens’ credit limits.
curated_info.title: Human Biases Are Baked into Algorithms. Now What?

curated_info.excerpt: From the way search engines reinforce racism to how digital culture has reshaped the way Black identity is expressed.

publisher.name: UCLA Center for Critical Internet Inquiry

curated_info.title: 15 Books by Black Scholars the Tech Industry Needs to Read Now

curated_info.author: Isaac Chotiner and Sarah T. Roberts
curated_info.excerpt: How the work of content moderation takes a psychological toll.
curated_info.title: The Underworld of Online Content Moderation

curated_info.author: Sasheer Zamata
curated_info.excerpt: Is the future more Black Panther or Black Mirror? Guest correspondent Sasheer Zamata investigates Afrofuturism and the journey to make Snapchat filters actually work.
curated_info.title: Black Future Month

curated_info.excerpt: A conversation about the underlying systems of power, privilege, and oppression as they relate to present-day conversations about algorithms.
curated_info.title: Before Algorithms: A History of Bias and Oppression in Computing

curated_info.excerpt: From everyday apps to complex algorithms, technology has the potential to hide, speed, and even deepen discrimination, while appearing neutral and even benevolent when compared to racist practices of a previous era.
curated_info.title: Ruha Benjamin on “The New Jim Code? Race, Carceral Technoscience, and Liberatory Imagination”

curated_info.excerpt: The increasingly precise segmentation and targeting of commercial messages has been enabled in large part through the analysis of massive amounts of transaction-generated-information.
curated_info.title: Surveillance and the Public Sphere: Confronting a Democratic Dilemma

curated_info.author: Dr. Seeta Peña Gangadharan
curated_info.excerpt: Most of us don’t realize how much digital systems govern access to our basic public services, like education, health and housing. Even more terrifying is how much data is collected about us and used without our knowledge.
curated_info.title: Technologies of Control and Our Right of Refusal

curated_info.author: Kishonna L. Gray
curated_info.excerpt: It is important to examine the digital manifestations of misogynoir – or what it means to be a Woman of Color existing in the hegemonic spaces of digital technology. But our conceptual frameworks fail to capture the everyday practices that Women of Color exhibit online.

publisher.name: The Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society

curated_info.title: Examining Black Feminism in the Digital Era

curator.about:
About the Curator

Safiya Umoja Noble is an Associate Professor at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) in the Department of Information Studies, where she serves as the Co-Director of the UCLA Center for Critical Internet Inquiry. She is the author of a best-selling book on racist and sexist algorithmic bias in commercial search engines, Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism (NYU Press).
curator.name: Safiya Umoja Noble

collections.description: ​Algorithms and the data that drive them are designed and created by people, which means those systems can carry biases based on who builds them and how they’re ultimately deployed. Safiya Umoja Noble, author of Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism, offers a curated reading list exploring how technology can replicate and reinforce racist and sexist beliefs, how that bias can affect everything from health outcomes to financial credit to criminal justice, and why data discrimination is a major 21st century challenge.
collections.subtitle: A curated reading list exploring how algorithmic bias can affect everything from health outcomes to financial credit to criminal justice.
collections.title: A curated reading list exploring how algorithmic bias can affect everything from health outcomes to financial credit to criminal justice.

curated_info.author: Pamela Colloff
curated_info.excerpt: Revisiting a decades-old cold case with only one suspect: the priest who heard the deceased’s final confession.
curated_info.title: Unholy Act

curated_info.author: Josh Dean
curated_info.excerpt: When an all-star crew with the perfect plan pulled off the caper of the century, it made them more than a fortune—it made them folk heroes.
curated_info.title: The Great Buenos Aires Bank Heist

curated_info.author: Gabriel Cohen
curated_info.excerpt: When a mystery writer moves into a new apartment that seems too good to be true, he slowly unravels its grisly history.

curated_info.author: Richard Ben Cramer
curated_info.excerpt: Was the rock legend’s fourth wife murdered, and did the man known as “the Killer” do it?

curated_info.author: David Grann

collections.description: Immerse yourself in this collection of riveting true-crime writing, including tales of audacious heists, mysterious deaths, and the reflections of a serial killer’s daughter.
collections.subtitle: For some of us, dark times call for dark reads.
collections.title: For some of us, dark times call for dark reads.

curated_info.author: Michael S. Rosenwald
curated_info.excerpt: A look at how pandemics have remade the world.

curated_info.author: Chris Mackie
curated_info.excerpt: Thucydides’ account of the plague that struck Athens in 430 B.C. focuses on the social response, both of those who died and those who survived.

curated_info.author: Annalee Newitz
curated_info.excerpt: Humanity has been surviving plagues for thousands of years, and we have managed to learn a lot along the way.

curated_info.author: Brian Patrick O’Malley
curated_info.excerpt: Some of which may ring familiar today.

curated_info.author: Amy Fleming

curated_info.author: Hannah Wunsch

curated_info.author: Meilan Solly

collections.description: Previous epidemics have a lot to teach us about the coronavirus and this moment in history. See our curated collection examining how infectious diseases have altered the way people live — and what this means for the future we’re currently facing.
collections.subtitle: Twelve stories to help gauge how infectious diseases have changed society.
collections.title: Twelve stories to help gauge how infectious diseases have changed society.

curated_info.author: Michael Finkel

collections.description: There’s nothing like getting lost in a fascinating story — and now is a better time than any to dive into another world. From the gripping account of a 64-year-old woman who swam from Florida to Cuba to the mysterious life of a hermit who lived in the woods undisturbed for 30 years — you won’t be able to put these articles down.

curator.about:
About the Curator

Keith Law has been a senior baseball writer since 2006, formerly at ESPN and now at The Athletic. His book, “The Inside Game: Bad Calls, Strange Moves, and What Baseball Behavior Teaches Us About Ourselves,” comes out in April. Find him @keithlaw or on his blog, The dish.
curator.name: Keith Law

collections.description: Welcome to What I’m Reading, a special series in which we invite interesting people to handpick articles around a theme of their choice.

collections.description: Feeling anxious? You’re not alone—and not without resources. We’ve created a collection of a dozen stories that delve into how anxiety affects your body, brain, and habits, as well as the world around you. Because the first step towards better mental health is understanding the science of how and why anxiety works. As for the next steps? From vaccines to psychedelics to video games, scientists and experts are on the case.

curated_info.title: The Best Books on Dinosaurs

collections.description: If you ever want to put things in perspective, consider this: Less time separates human beings in history from Tyrannosaurus rex than T. rex from Stegosaurus. That’s right. While T. rex went extinct about 66 million years ago, at the end of the Cretaceous Period, the Jurassic Period’s stegosaurus roamed the Earth 83 million years before T. rex had even evolved. All told, dinosaurs ruled the planet for some 180 million years, while homo sapiens emerged a paltry 200,000 years ago.
collections.title: The Ultimate Dinosaur Reading List

curated_info.author: Nikole Hannah-Jones (@nhannahjones)

curated_info.excerpt: Nearly 80 Latino staffers at the @latimes sent a letter to the owner and managers demanding a newspaper that truly reflects the community.

curated_info.author: Hanaa’ Tameez

curated_info.author: Knight Foundation
curated_info.excerpt: A hard look at journalism and how it has been complicit in upholding systemic racism.

curated_info.author: Nikita Richardson

curated_info.author: Meghan McCarron

The first of these were directly tied to issues of racism and anti-Blackness, but they have since expanded to the broader problem of toxic leadership in the industry, and the dominance of white men and women in positions of power.
curated_info.title: The Boundary Pusher: How Peter Meehan Allegedly Created a Toxic Work Culture at L.A. Times food and Lucky Peach

collections.description: After the George Floyd protests in May, Black journalists in the United States started a revolt of their own. What began with industry outcry over the on-camera arrest of a Black CNN reporter in Minneapolis (while his white colleague also worked nearby, untouched) escalated on Twitter to Black and other journalists of color exposing workplace frustrations over racism, representation and “objectivity” that affect how U.S. newsrooms cover the police killings of unarmed Black men and women. Top editors stepped down. Journalists resigned. Advertisers balked. Some outlets promised change—and still the airing of dirty laundry continues apace on Twitter. This is unprecedented, says long-time social justice journalist Carla Murphy. To help understand the roots and ramifications of this public revolt, she has curated a reading list about how this latest reckoning on race is disrupting the nation’s newsrooms.
collections.title: Inside the Black Journalist-Led Revolts Rocking U.S. Newsrooms

curated_info.excerpt: Healing a spooked horse takes time, patience, and skill. And maybe a little help from beyond.
curated_info.title: How Animal Psychics Helped Untangle a Mixed-up Horse

collections.description: Crazy-smart bees. Rogue wolves. A world-famous pig. Animals are more complex than we give them credit for. We’ve collected some of the best stories out there on the unique creatures, furry and otherwise, that enrich our lives.
collections.title: 9 Tales of Amazing Animal Behavior

curated_info.author: Joe Moran
curated_info.excerpt: Orwell advised cutting as many words as possible, Woolf found energy in verbs, and Baldwin aimed for ‘a sentence as clean as a bone’. What can we learn from celebrated authors about the art of writing well?
curated_info.title: How to Write the Perfect Sentence

curated_info.author: John Wenz
curated_info.excerpt: What is, “very carefully?”
curated_info.title: How to Write a Jeopardy Clue

curated_info.author: Daniel Midgley
curated_info.excerpt: When you make a protest sign, you’re working with considerable linguistic constraints: Space is limited by what you (and your friends) can carry, and if you’re marching, your reader will have to absorb your message quickly, making sign-writing a tough task.
curated_info.title: A Linguist Explains How to Write Protest Signs That Everyone Will Remember

curated_info.author: The New York Times
curated_info.excerpt: Jerry Seinfeld describes the anatomy of his Pop-Tart joke, still a work in progress, and shows his longhand writing process.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Joke

curated_info.author: Virginia Hughes
curated_info.excerpt: Organizing tasks on paper is a tried and true method for getting things done. Here are some types of to-do lists that may be right for you.
curated_info.title: 7 Expert-Approved Ways to Write a Better To-Do List

curated_info.author: T. Rachel Cole
curated_info.excerpt: A guide to reading and writing poetry for people who don’t (yet) read or write poetry.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Poem

curated_info.author: Kabir Sehgal
curated_info.excerpt: A few tips on how to quickly and clearly relay information and avoid miscommunication.
curated_info.title: How to Write Email with Military Precision

curated_info.author: NPR Weekend Edition
curated_info.excerpt: Ten tips for writing the perfect thank you note from John Kralik, author of 365 Thank Yous.
curated_info.title: Perfect Thank You Notes: Heartfelt And Handwritten

curated_info.author: Bonnie S. Benwick
curated_info.excerpt: It’s a two-way street toward clarity and comprehension
curated_info.title: How to Write — and Read — Recipes Better

curated_info.author: Joanna Goddard
curated_info.excerpt: When a person is bereaved, the simple, sincere expressions of sympathy you write are deeply felt and appreciated. At this time of withdrawal from the world, your letter can be a warm and understanding handclasp.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Condolence Note

curated_info.author: Emily VanDerWerff
curated_info.excerpt: “[Songwriting] is work. Experience, selection, taste. None of those things are something that happens to you. You’re not just an antenna.”
curated_info.title: How to Write a Great Song, According to Singer-Songwriter Neko Case

curated_info.author: Brett & Kate McKay
curated_info.excerpt: While email and texts have become the standard form of written communication in today’s fast-paced, digital world, there’s still a place for old-fashioned, snail mail letters.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Letter

curated_info.author: Alan Henry
curated_info.excerpt: The best online reviews offer up the kind of information that’s invaluable when making a decision. Here’s how you can write those kinds of reviews.
curated_info.title: How to Write Genuinely Useful Reviews Online

curated_info.author: Alison Green
curated_info.excerpt: Ten personalized, compelling cover letters are likely to get you far more interview invitations than 50 generic ones will.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Cover Letter That Will Get You a Job

curated_info.author: Kara Alaimo
curated_info.excerpt: Be personal. Be clear-sighted. And don’t be afraid to laugh at yourself.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Killer Commencement Speech

curated_info.author: Emma Cook
curated_info.excerpt: Everyone has a book in them, but how do you get it out? Here are some great tips from the ‘book doctor’ Philippa Pride.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Bestselling Novel

curated_info.author: Olga Khazan
curated_info.excerpt: Expert advice on ending procrastination and finishing that manuscript, dissertation, or other big project.
curated_info.title: How to Write a Book Without Losing Your Mind

curated_info.author: Drew Magary
curated_info.excerpt: The most productive writers know that writing is only one step in a larger process.
curated_info.title: How to Write 10,000 Words a Week

collections.description: There’s an old saying attributed to legendary sports journalist Red Smith: “There’s nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and open a vein.” The technology may have changed since the 1940s; the painful parts, unfortunately, haven’t. But that’s no reason for despair. Whether you’re just looking to punch up your tweets or have ambitions to write the Great American Novel, we’ve got you covered with this collection of great articles about the craft of writing, well, just about anything.
collections.title: How to Write (Almost) Anything, From a Great Joke to a Killer Cover Letter

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: A virus has brought the world’s most powerful country to its knees.
curated_info.title: How the Pandemic Defeated America

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: Which is too bad because we really need to understand how the immune system reacts to the coronavirus.
curated_info.title: Immunology Is Where Intuition Goes to Die

curated_info.author: Wade Davis
curated_info.excerpt: Anthropologist Wade Davis on how COVID-19 signals the end of the American era.
curated_info.title: The Unraveling of America

curated_info.author: Irina Aleksander
curated_info.excerpt: Even before the pandemic, the whole fashion industry had started to unravel. What happens now that no one has a reason to dress up?
curated_info.title: Sweatpants Forever

curated_info.author: Laura Huang and Ryan Yu
curated_info.excerpt: How do you go about convincing someone who, for one reason or another, doesn’t see eye-to-eye with you? Someone who gives you a flat out “no”?
curated_info.title: How to (Actually) Change Someone’s Mind

curated_info.author: Steven Levy
curated_info.excerpt: The techie-turned-philanthropist on vaccines, Trump, and why social media is “a poisoned chalice.”
curated_info.title: Bill Gates on COVID: Most US Tests Are ‘Completely Garbage’

curated_info.author: Arthur C. Brooks
curated_info.excerpt: The pursuit of achievement distracts from the deeply ordinary activities and relationships that make life meaningful.
curated_info.title: ‘Success Addicts’ Choose Being Special Over Being Happy

curated_info.author: Christine Hauser
curated_info.excerpt: As the influenza pandemic swept across the United States in 1918 and 1919, masks took a role in political and cultural wars.
curated_info.title: The Mask Slackers of 1918

curated_info.author: Graham Averill
curated_info.excerpt: In his book, “Lifespan,” celebrated scientist David Sinclair lays out exactly why we age—and why he thinks we don’t have to.
curated_info.title: This Scientist Believes Aging Is Optional

curated_info.author: Jesse Frederik
curated_info.excerpt: Blockchain technology is going to change everything: the shipping industry, the financial system, government … in fact, what won’t it change? But enthusiasm for it mainly stems from a lack of knowledge and understanding. The blockchain is a solution in search of a problem.
curated_info.title: Blockchain, The Amazing Solution for Almost Nothing

collections.description: It might not come as a surprise, but the coronavirus pandemic was top of mind for Pocket users in August. Six of the top 10 most-saved stories for the month were about the virus, with science journalist Ed Yong’s coronavirus coverage for The Atlantic claiming the top two spots. Pocket readers were also interested in COVID-19’s far-reaching impact and historical parallels, including a New York Times deep dive into the pandemic’s effect on high fashion and an exploration of the 1918 culture war over face masks.
collections.title: Pocket’s 10 Most-Saved Stories in August

curated_info.author: A. Roger Ekirch
curated_info.excerpt: A madman versus a crook? Unexpected twists? Fake news? Welcome to the election of 1800.
curated_info.title: The Immigration-Obsessed, Polarized, Garbage-Fire Election of 1800

curated_info.author: Mark R. Cheathem
curated_info.excerpt: Outlandish rumors helped elect Presidents Andrew Jackson and Martin Van Buren and have been with us ever since.
curated_info.title: When American Politicos First Weaponized Conspiracy Theories

curated_info.author: Harold Holzer
curated_info.excerpt: As soon as the returns were in, the burdens of the presidency weighed upon Abraham Lincoln.
curated_info.title: Election Day 1860

curated_info.author: Becky Little
curated_info.excerpt: Fearing Abraham Lincoln would lose reelection, some wondered if the country should delay the election.
curated_info.title: How the Union Pulled Off a Presidential Election During the Civil War

curated_info.author: Ed Kilgore
curated_info.excerpt: If you want an example of a real nation-rending, Constitution-bending contested presidential election that might have conceivably led to a second Civil War, you have to go back to the U.S. Centennial Year of 1876.
curated_info.title: The Last Time a Contested Presidential Election Nearly Tore the Country Apart

curated_info.author: S.J. Ackerman
curated_info.excerpt: Old style ballots cast illegally in Indiana helped President Grover Cleveland in 1888.
curated_info.title: The Vote That Failed

curated_info.author: Will Moreland
curated_info.excerpt: Though the election of 1948 is best remembered for the Chicago Tribune newspaper’s embarrassing, incorrect “Dewey Defeats Truman” headline, its forgotten story is of Henry Wallace, a liberal dreamer who became the Kremlin’s unwitting pawn.
curated_info.title: The Last Russian Leader to Mess With a US Election? Josef Stalin.

curated_info.author: John A. Farrell
curated_info.excerpt: It took decades to unravel Richard Nixon’s sabotage of Vietnam peace talks in 1968. Now, the full story can be told.
curated_info.title: When a Candidate Conspired With a Foreign Power to Win An Election

curated_info.author: Ena Alvarado-Esteller, David A. Graham, Cullen Murphy, and Amy Weiss-Meyer
curated_info.excerpt: An oral history of the craziest presidential election in modern history.
curated_info.title: The Bush-Gore Recount Is an Omen for 2020

curated_info.author: Esquire
curated_info.excerpt: What really happened?
curated_info.title: The Untold Stories of Election Day 2016

curated_info.author: Jill Lepore
curated_info.excerpt: Voting in America, it’s fair to say, used to be different. The founders didn’t anticipate that voting would be done in secret. And, in the middle decades of the nineteenth century, eighty-nine Americans were killed at the polls during Election Day riots.
curated_info.title: Bonus Read: How We Used to Vote

collections.description: Partisan rancor. Conspiracy theories. Disenfranchised voters. Foreign meddling. Contested results. Maybe it’s not exactly a comfort, but the United States has seen it all before. Dive into the history of contentious presidential elections that rival 2020 for drama and intrigue, including the “Corrupt Bargain” of 1824 (when a popular-vote loser squeaked into the White House for the first time), the 1864 election (held during the middle of the Civil War), and, yeah, the last one.
collections.title: America’s History of Nasty, Tumultuous, and Strange Presidential Elections

curated_info.author: Alex Moshakis
curated_info.excerpt: Some sleep on electromagnetic mats, others pop up to 150 pills a day. But are ‘life extensionists’ any closer to finding the key to longevity?
curated_info.title: How To Live Forever: Meet the Extreme Life-Extensionists

curated_info.author: Cynthia Koons
curated_info.excerpt: It’s based on the substance that causes botulism. That’s part of what protects Allergan’s $2.8 billion Botox empire.
curated_info.title: The Wonder Drug for Aging (Made From One of the Deadliest Toxins on Earth)

curated_info.author: David Adam
curated_info.excerpt: If this controversial idea gains acceptance, it could radically change the way we treat getting old.
curated_info.title: What If Aging Weren’t Inevitable, but a Curable Disease?

curated_info.author: Cheryl Wischhover
curated_info.excerpt: Brands are still selling the idea of trying to look younger — they’ve just changed the vocabulary.
curated_info.title: The Fall of “Anti-Aging” Skin Care

curated_info.author: Joel Stein
curated_info.excerpt: At the dawn of a new decade, I wondered: How many more decades can I live?
curated_info.title: I Biohacked for 10 Weeks To Try To Live Forever

curated_info.author: Audrey McGlinchy
curated_info.excerpt: The peat found in some anti-oxidant-rich wetlands has preserved the youthfulness of thousand-year-old corpses. Can it do the same for those who are still alive?
curated_info.title: Finding the Fountain of Youth in an Ancient Irish Bog

curated_info.author: Abby Mims
curated_info.excerpt: Five years after her mother’s death, while still grieving and suddenly middle-aged, one writer turns to beauty products to cure what ails her.
curated_info.title: Searching Sephora for an Antidote to Aging — and Grief

curated_info.author: Lauren Collins
curated_info.excerpt: Some researchers have cast doubt on the record of the celebrated supercentenarian.
curated_info.title: Was Jeanne Calment the Oldest Person Who Ever Lived—or a Fraud?

curated_info.author: Sam Anderson
curated_info.excerpt: I went to Florida recently to follow the traces of the traces of the legend of Juan Ponce de León.
curated_info.title: Searching for the Fountain of Youth

curated_info.author: Ezekiel J. Emanuel
curated_info.excerpt: An argument that society and families—and you—will be better off if nature takes its course swiftly and promptly.
curated_info.title: Why I Hope to Die at 75

collections.description: At what age does adding another birthday candle go from a thrill to slog? Society’s obsession with turning back the clock has brought us everything from pricey face creams and injectable toxins to cryogenic chambers and “miracle” diets. Explore this collection of great reads on some of our most quixotic attempts at staying forever young.
collections.title: The Fountain of Youth: 10 Stories About Our Obsession With Living Forever

curated_info.author: Sylvia Varnham O’Regan
curated_info.excerpt: Inside the strange, predatory, and lucrative world of psychics who have successfully scammed customers out of their life savings, and the private investigator who’s trying to put a stop to it.
curated_info.title: When a Psychic Reading Costs You $740,000

curated_info.author: Mark Seal
curated_info.excerpt: Investors all over the world fell for the schemes of the man who called himself Khalid bin al-Saud. But the truth turned out to be more incredible than the lie.
curated_info.title: “He Actually Believes He Is Khalid”: The Amazing 30-Year Odyssey of a Counterfeit Saudi Prince

curated_info.author: Allie Conti
curated_info.excerpt: While searching for the person who grifted me in Chicago, I discovered just how easy it is for users of the short-term rental platform to get exploited.
curated_info.title: I Accidentally Uncovered a Nationwide Scam on Airbnb

curated_info.author: Brian X. Chen
curated_info.excerpt: Fraudsters see opportunities to target us in these uncertain times. Here are their most popular schemes and how we can protect ourselves.
curated_info.title: A Guide to Pandemic Scams, and What Not to Fall For

curated_info.author: Jessica Pressler
curated_info.excerpt: The story of New York City’s most notorious faux heiress-turned-inmate, Anna Delvey, and the wild antics that won her intrigue—and tens of thousands of dollars.
curated_info.title: Maybe She Had So Much Money She Just Lost Track of It

curated_info.author: Maria Konnikova
curated_info.excerpt: Are con artists clinical psychopaths—or are they just slightly more devious versions of our more conniving selves?
curated_info.title: Psychopathic, Narcissistic Machiavellians

curated_info.author: Arielle Pardes
curated_info.excerpt: The pink princess philodendron is the ultimate Instagram plant, with three-digit price tags to match. The following it cultivated was also ripe for deception.
curated_info.title: The Princess, the Plantfluencers, and the Pink Congo Scam

curated_info.author: Dustin Grinnell
curated_info.excerpt: The son of a bank robber and sibling of a psychopath explains how he found his own calling scamming a litany of unsuspecting suckers.
curated_info.title: Secret Life of a Con Man

curated_info.author: Genevieve Carlton
curated_info.excerpt: Frisland never existed, but for centuries, people wanted to believe that it did.
curated_info.title: How to Put a Fake Island on the Map

curated_info.author: Alexis Conran
curated_info.excerpt: People and businesses routinely use five techniques to get us to do what they want. Here’s how to recognize them.
curated_info.title: Don’t Get Fooled or Conned Again — Here Are the 5 Tactics to Look out For

curated_info.author: Guy Lawson
curated_info.excerpt: That old adage that you can be anything you want? Well, Jeremy Wilson has lived it for years, crisscrossing the country and inventing new identities. A war hero, an MIT grad, a Hollywood journalist, an IRA operative—Jeremy has claimed to be all those things and more. And oh, what a mess he’s made.
curated_info.title: The Grand Schemes of the Petty Grifter

curated_info.author: Jacob Bernstein
curated_info.excerpt: Nicolas DeMeyer was a scammer. Or a hero for the age of inequality. Or a young man haunted by the death of a dear friend. Or all of these things.
curated_info.title: The Wine Thief

collections.description: Con artists have been scamming and scheming since ancient times. And yet every generation seems to bring a new bag of tricks, inspired by the latest app, platform, or pandemic there is to exploit. Take a careful step into our collection of great features about capers and frauds, and uncover some prudent advice on how to avoid becoming an unsuspecting sucker.
collections.title: 12 Unbelievable Stories of Scams and Schemes

curated_info.author: Erin Blakemore
curated_info.excerpt: Despite being a heartbeat from the presidency, this role was surprisingly ill-defined throughout much of the country’s history.
curated_info.title: How U.S. Vice Presidents Went From Irrelevant to Influential

curated_info.author: Brennan Weiss
curated_info.excerpt: Almost everyone knows the White House, but few people know that the vice president has an official residence of their own.
curated_info.title: Inside Number One Observatory Circle

curated_info.author: Ronald G. Shafer
curated_info.excerpt: Was John Tyler really president after pneumonia claimed the life of William Henry Harrison? In 1841, the country wasn’t sure.
curated_info.title: ‘His Accidency’: The First President to Die in Office and the Constitutional Confusion That Followed

curated_info.author: Gil Troy
curated_info.excerpt: A hoax about the president’s death led him to believe he was Commander-in-Chief—and it paralyzed him with fear.
curated_info.title: The Most Useless Veep in U.S. History

curated_info.author: Stacy Conradt
curated_info.excerpt: To date, Charles Dawes is the only Vice President to have a song chart at #1, though he missed the whole thing.
curated_info.title: The Vice President Who Wrote a Hit Song

curated_info.author: Jeffrey Frank
curated_info.excerpt: The possibility of a sudden succession now plays a larger part in the selection of Vice-Presidents, but not always.
curated_info.title: How F.D.R.’s Death Changed the Vice-Presidency

curated_info.author: Tony Horwitz
curated_info.excerpt: The U.S. vice presidency has been filled by a rogues gallery of mediocrities, criminals and even corpses.
curated_info.title: The Vice Presidents That History Forgot

curated_info.author: Jaime Fuller
curated_info.excerpt: John Adams, the first vice president: “I am Vice President. In this I am nothing, but I may be everything.”
curated_info.title: A Brief History of Vice Presidents Bemoaning the Vice Presidency

curated_info.author: Nicole Hemmer
curated_info.excerpt: Choosing a running mate used to be more about campaigning than governing. But after Richard Nixon’s ruinous relationship with Spiro Agnew, the job has changed. Introducing the executive vice presidency.
curated_info.title: Why the Vice Presidency Matters

collections.description: With vice presidential picks in the news, you might be asking yourself: what, exactly, does the vice president do? For much of American history, the answer was “not much.” But since the end of World War II, the vice president’s job has evolved from constitutional afterthought to indispensable part of the executive branch.
collections.title: Vice Presidents: From Afterthought to Indispensable

curated_info.author: Casey Cep
curated_info.excerpt: A century after the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment, it’s worth remembering why suffragists had to fight so hard, and who was fighting against them.
curated_info.title: The Imperfect, Unfinished Work of Women’s Suffrage

curated_info.author: Anne Wallentine
curated_info.excerpt: The material history of the movement reveals many of its priorities and problems, and its relevance to the persisting struggles for equal rights today.
curated_info.title: A History of the US Women’s Suffrage Movement in Five Objects

curated_info.author: Erin Blakemore
curated_info.excerpt: This leading suffragist devoted her life to the movement but never got to vote—legally at least.
curated_info.title: Susan B. Anthony Fought for Women’s Suffrage in the Face of Ridicule

curated_info.author: Meilan Solly
curated_info.excerpt: The process varied by state, with some making accommodations for the new voting bloc and others creating additional obstacles
curated_info.title: What the First Women Voters Experienced When Registering for the 1920 Election

curated_info.author: Martha S. Jones
curated_info.excerpt: Racism and sexism were bound together in the fight to vote – and Black women made it clear they would never cede the question of their voting rights to others
curated_info.title: The US Suffragette Movement Tried to Leave Out Black Women. They Showed Up Anyway

curated_info.author: Samantha Schmidt
curated_info.excerpt: The anti-suffragist women would become a nationwide force that would influence later generations of conservative women. And today, a century after women gained the right to vote, echoes of their message remain.
curated_info.title: Why Thousands of Women Fought Against the Right to Vote

curated_info.author: Christine Crudo Blackburn, Gerald W. Parker and Morten Wendelbo
curated_info.excerpt: One hundred years ago, a powerful strain of the flu swept the globe, infecting one third of the world’s population. The aftermath of this disaster, too, led to unexpected social changes, opening up new opportunities for women and in the process irreversibly transforming life in the United States.
curated_info.title: How the Devastating 1918 Flu Pandemic Helped Advance US Women’s Rights

curated_info.author: Wendy L. Rouse
curated_info.excerpt: “Would you rather have a vote than a husband?”
curated_info.title: The Very Queer History of the Suffrage Movement

curated_info.author: Cathleen D. Cahill and Sarah Deer
curated_info.excerpt: The 19th Amendment did not bring the right to vote to all Native women, but two experts in a conversation said it did usher in the possibility of change.
curated_info.title: In 1920, Native Women Sought the Vote. Here’s What’s Next.

curated_info.author: Maggie Fuller
curated_info.excerpt: On the 100th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, trace the route of the national women’s suffrage movement and stand in the spots where history happened.
curated_info.title: Celebrate Women’s Suffrage on an Epic, Self-Guided Road Trip

curated_info.author: Melissa Gira Grant
curated_info.excerpt: The women who remain locked out of the right to vote are the fractured legacy of a fractured movement.
curated_info.title: The Unfinished Business of Women’s Suffrage

collections.description: American democracy is a lot younger than it looks. Just 100 years ago, on August 18, 1920, the 19th Amendment was ratified, enshrining women’s right to vote in the U.S. Constitution. While women’s suffrage was hard won, the battle for the ballot would continue for decades, especially for Black and Indigenous women. This collection explores the history and impact of that century-old victory, and the complicated legacy that still informs today.
collections.title: How Women Won the Vote: A 19th Amendment Reading List

curated_info.author: December 1987
curated_info.excerpt: “Once there was another city here, and now it is gone. There are almost no traces of it anymore, but millions of us know it existed, because we lived in it: the Lost City of New York.”
curated_info.title: The New York We’ve Lost

curated_info.author: June 13, 1968
curated_info.excerpt: “Kennedy’s face had a kind of sweet acceptance to it, the eyes understanding that it had come to him, the way it had come to so many others before him. The price of the attempt at excellence was death”
curated_info.title: RFK, Two Minutes to Midnight: The Very Last Hurrah

curated_info.author: September 12, 2001
curated_info.excerpt: “We were gathered at a large table in the Tweed Courthouse, discussing over bagels and coffee its future as a symbol of civilization, a museum of the history of New York. About 8:45, we heard a boom.”
curated_info.title: Death Takes Hold Among the Living

curated_info.author: June 5, 1975
curated_info.excerpt: “He is the sort of artist, like the aforementioned Picasso, who is always in the process of becoming. I think of this as a kind of interim report from one of the bravest human beings I know.”
curated_info.title: John Lennon: Long Night’s Journey into Day

curated_info.author: December 1989
curated_info.excerpt: “The Man of the Decade? Easy—that guy who built, uh, What’s-his-name Tower.”
curated_info.title: T. Without Sympathy

curated_info.author: June 1996
curated_info.excerpt: “For too long a time, I loved the brutal sport of prizefighting. But I’ve arrived at last at that cold morning. You cannot love anything that lives in a sewer.”
curated_info.title: Blood On Their Hands

curated_info.author: October 1974
curated_info.excerpt: “It is no accident that Nixon was from California. He was a master of desecration. And make no mistake: this place has been desecrated.”
curated_info.title: Nixon’s Exile: Death in California

curated_info.author: June 2019
curated_info.excerpt: “Count your blessings: if you ever wrote a regular column for the New York Daily News you’ve had one of the best jobs in the history of newspapers, a ringside seat at the greatest show on Earth.”
curated_info.title: The Do’s and Don’ts of Writing a Newspaper Column

collections.description: “There’s no one New York,” Pete Hamill once said. “There’s multiple New Yorks. Anybody who sits and says ‘I know New York’ is from out of town.” The legendary journalist, who chronicled daily life in the Big Apple for more than 50 years as a columnist for the New York Post, New York Daily News, New York Newsday, and The Village Voice, died this week at age 85. Hamill’s punchy prose, everyman sensibilities, and unabashed love of the news business and the city he covered inspired a generation of journalists.
collections.title: Reading Pete Hamill, Iconic Newspaperman (1935-2020)

curated_info.author: National Geographic
curated_info.excerpt: Human memory happens in many parts of the brain at once, and some types of memories stick around longer than others.
curated_info.title: Human Memory: How We Make, Remember, and Forget Memories

curated_info.author: Shayla Love
curated_info.excerpt: Memory researchers say these months will eventually become a blur for those of us isolating at home.
curated_info.title: You’ll Probably Forget What It Was Like to Live Through a Pandemic

curated_info.author: Linda Rodriguez McRobbie
curated_info.excerpt: An extremely rare condition may transform our understanding of memory.
curated_info.title: Total Recall: The People Who Never Forget

curated_info.author: Erika Hayasaki
curated_info.excerpt: The strange case of the woman who can’t remember her past—or imagine her future.
curated_info.title: In a Perpetual Present

curated_info.author: Amelia Tait
curated_info.excerpt: Over the years, hundreds of people online have shared memories of a cheesy Nineties movie called “Shazaam.” There is no evidence that such a film was ever made. What does this tell us about the quirks of collective memory?
curated_info.title: The Movie That Doesn’t Exist and the Redditors Who Think It Does

curated_info.author: Kathy Benjamin
curated_info.excerpt: Long-term, immediate, and habitual methods for keeping your memories fresh and clear.
curated_info.title: 11 Simple Ways to Improve Your Memory

curated_info.author: Julie Beck
curated_info.excerpt: … and the movies and TV shows we watch.
curated_info.title: Why We Forget Most of the Books We Read

curated_info.author: Ferris Jabr
curated_info.excerpt: Your brain needs to forget in order to grow.
curated_info.title: This Is Where Your Childhood Memories Went

curated_info.author: Eleanor Cummins
curated_info.excerpt: Societies forget, and this physicist wants to know why.
curated_info.title: How Long Can an Event Hold Humanity’s Attention? There’s an Equation for That

curated_info.author: Sarah Laskow
curated_info.excerpt: Scientists are beginning to understand that plants have abilities, previously unnoticed and unimagined, that we’ve only ever associated with animals.
curated_info.title: A Quiet Revolution in Botany: Plants Form Memories

curated_info.author: Louise Fabiani
curated_info.excerpt: Of the many experts who figured in Henry Molaison’s life, one man would change him into amnesiac patient H.M., but two women ensured he would never be forgotten.
curated_info.title: A Stranger in the House of Memory

curated_info.author: Clive Thompson
curated_info.excerpt: Nope. It’s much, much weirder than that.
curated_info.title: Is Google Wrecking Our Memory?

curated_info.author: Christine Hyung-Oak Lee
curated_info.excerpt: An excerpt from Christine Hyung-Oak Lee’s memoir Tell Me Everything You Don’t Remember: The Stroke That Changed My Life.
curated_info.title: What It’s Like to Lose Your Short-Term Memory

curated_info.author: Ainslie Johnstone
curated_info.excerpt: Without the changes in the brain that allow you to learn new skills, nothing would be “as easy as learning to ride a bike.”
curated_info.title: The Amazing Phenomenon of Muscle Memory

collections.description: Our memories make us who we are, and as with anything involving the human brain, they’re pretty complicated. Explore the mysteries of memory with this collection of fascinating articles that break down how we form memories, why we forget so much of our childhood, and the profound impact this has on our lives.
collections.title: The Strange Science of Memory

curated_info.author: Loren Grush
curated_info.excerpt: Perseverance’s biggest goal is to dig up samples to bring back to Earth one day.
curated_info.title: Nasa’s New Mars Rover Is About to Embark on a Hunt for Ancient Alien Life

curated_info.author: Becky Ferreira
curated_info.excerpt: How habitable was early Mars? Why did it become less hospitable? And could there be life there now?
curated_info.title: 3 Great Mysteries About Life on Mars

curated_info.author: Kate Greene
curated_info.excerpt: I spent four months pretending to live on Mars. Here’s what I learned about staying sane and passing time.
curated_info.title: Living Life at a Distance

curated_info.author: Brian Gallagher
curated_info.excerpt: Elon Musk wants to engineer Mars’ atmosphere. Can he?
curated_info.title: So Can We Terraform Mars or Not?

curated_info.author: George RR Martin
curated_info.excerpt: The author behind Game of Thrones spent his childhood reading stories about Mars and hoping to write one himself. As new discoveries on the red planet capture the world’s attention, he surveys a rich Martian literature.
curated_info.title: George RR Martin: Our Long Obsession With Mars

curated_info.author: Sarah Stewart Johnson
curated_info.excerpt: Percival Lowell’s dogged belief helped bring Mars science to 19th century America.
curated_info.title: The Astronomer Who Believed There Was an Alien Utopia on Mars

curated_info.author: Marina Koren
curated_info.excerpt: A mission atop a Hawaiian volcano shows humans still have much to learn before they set foot on another world.
curated_info.title: When a Mars Simulation Goes Wrong

curated_info.author: Sarah Scoles
curated_info.excerpt: Astrobiologists have used Mars Jars for decades. Many didn’t know about the controversial Air Force scientist who started them.
curated_info.title: The Doctor From Nazi Germany and the Search for Life on Mars

curated_info.author: Alina Simone
curated_info.excerpt: The DIY explorers who dream of a 35-million-mile trek.
curated_info.title: Mars Madness

curated_info.author: David Warmflash
curated_info.excerpt: Is the Red Planet really the best target for a human colony?
curated_info.title: Forget Mars. Here’s Where We Should Build Our First Off-World Colonies

curated_info.author: Rebecca Boyle
curated_info.excerpt: But this jerk planet is still humanity’s best hope for another home in the cosmos.
curated_info.title: Everything About Mars Is The Worst

collections.description: Earth to Mars: We’re on our way. The July 30th launch of NASA’s Perseverance rover brings us one step closer to a better understanding of the Red Planet. Explore these 11 fascinating stories about the potential for life on Mars (past and present), the science of getting there, and the lore that inspires the journey.
collections.title: 11 Far-Out Stories About the Journey to Mars

curated_info.author: Paul Theroux
curated_info.excerpt: In the spirit of Kerouac and Steinbeck, a celebrated travel writer fulfills a childhood fantasy: to drive across his native land.
curated_info.title: Taking the Great American Roadtrip

curated_info.author: Janine Rubenstein
curated_info.excerpt: Journalist Janine Rubenstein took her family on a road trip from New Jersey to California just days before George Floyd’s murder set this nation ablaze. Here’s what they learned about motor homes, the country and life, along the way.
curated_info.title: Inside a Black Family’s Cross-Country RV Trip

curated_info.author: Kathryn Miles
curated_info.excerpt: Make a new canine friend in Maine and chances are good she’s from down south, as the dog-crazy Pine Tree State is among the most common destinations for southern rescue dogs. To understand why — and how they arrive — Kathryn Miles joined 37 very good dogs on a 1,600-mile road trip.
curated_info.title: Homeward Bound

curated_info.author: Peter Brannen
curated_info.excerpt: A science journalist tours the geological ruins of our planet’s worst mass extinction.
curated_info.title: A Road Trip to the End of the World

curated_info.author: Gustavo Arellano
curated_info.excerpt: A palate-scorching, Mexican hamburger- and adovada-fueled road trip up I-25 from Las Cruces to Denver
curated_info.title: The Great American Chile Highway

curated_info.author: David Samuels
curated_info.excerpt: A truck driver uncovers secrets about the first nuclear bombs.
curated_info.title: Atomic John

curated_info.author: Holly Patton
curated_info.excerpt: Doctors said we could blame my father’s football career for his vanishing memory. So Dad and I decided to take a road trip down south to revisit the schools that made him.
curated_info.title: Football, My Dad’s Dementia, and Me

curated_info.author: Karl Ove Knausgaard
curated_info.excerpt: In the land of Tolstoy, Turgenev and now Putin, what are the stories Russians are telling themselves?
curated_info.title: A Literary Road Trip Into the Heart of Russia

curated_info.author: Mary Melton
curated_info.excerpt: Alta Editor at Large Mary Melton searches for a deeper connection with her autistic son—and with a divided country—on a 15-day journey along Route 66.
curated_info.title: A Mother’s Road

curated_info.author: Michael Chabon
curated_info.excerpt: Why take your family to France or Florida when you could pack them into a minivan with a stranger in Morocco? Novelist Michael Chabon explains.
curated_info.title: That Time Writer Michael Chabon Packed His Family Into a Minivan With a Stranger in Morocco

curated_info.author: Bryan Di Salvatore
curated_info.excerpt: A recklessly picaresque, highly philosophical, gloriously unmapped road trip in search of secret places you’ll have to find yourself.
curated_info.title: Tracking the Elusive Western Shoe Tree

curated_info.author: Meredith Carey
curated_info.excerpt: It’s a rather insane premise: drive in a tiny, terrible car, from the U.K. to Mongolia and on into Siberia. But since 2004, when founder Tom Morgan and his Adventurists crew led the first rally with six cars, thousands of people have driven the so-called “Mongol Rally,” raising money for charity along the way.
curated_info.title: 7 Weeks, 11,000 Miles, and 2 Tiny Cars: The Mongol Rally

curated_info.author: Pete Candler
curated_info.excerpt: A road trip through the Old South reveals uncomfortable family truths.
curated_info.title: A Deeper South

curated_info.author: Marya Hornbacher
curated_info.excerpt: Fleabag motels, caesuras, femme phases, double bank shots, stale sweat, McDonald’s, bedside Bibles, hatchbacks, counter girls, evolved orchids, tomorrow’s underwear, impetus, the Aqua City Motel & traffic signals in Laredo.
curated_info.title: Drifters (Interstate 35)

collections.description: Hit the highway with this collection of some of our favorite reads about epic road trips, including an 11,000-mile odyssey across Eurasia, a mother and son’s discoveries along Historic Route 66, and a science writer’s harrowing voyage to the Cretaceous Interior Seaway (also known as Western Kansas).
collections.title: Life Is a Highway: 14 Great Articles About Road Trips

curated_info.author: James Baldwin
curated_info.excerpt: From 1962: “Whatever white people do not know about Negroes reveals, precisely and inexorably, what they do not know about themselves.”
curated_info.title: Letter from a Region in My Mind

curated_info.author: Leanne Betasamosake Simpson
curated_info.excerpt: We must look at the roots of capitalism, white supremacy, heteropatriarchy, and anti-Blackness to leave settler colonialism in the past.
curated_info.title: Resisting the Power Structures That Keep Colonialism Alive

curated_info.author: Crystal Marie Fleming
curated_info.excerpt: Slavery, lynchings, Jim Crow, mass incarceration and centuries of systematic racism all happened under the star-spangled banner.
curated_info.title: To Be Clear, White Supremacy Is the Foundation of Our Country. We Won’t Destroy It by Toppling Statues

curated_info.author: Stephen Kantrowitz
curated_info.excerpt: White supremacy is a language of unease. It does not describe racial domination so much as worry about it.
curated_info.title: White Supremacy Has Always Been Mainstream

curated_info.author: Chauncey DeVega
curated_info.excerpt: Working-class whites are suffering but still willing to defend racism, says author of “Dying of Whiteness.”
curated_info.title: Jonathan Metzl: White Supremacy Is Literally Killing White People

curated_info.author: Lanre Bakare
curated_info.excerpt: The veteran civil rights campaigner on growing up in segregated America, the opportunity of the Black Lives Matter movement, and what inspires her to keep fighting.
curated_info.title: Angela Davis: ‘We Knew That the Role of the Police Was to Protect White Supremacy’

curated_info.author: Barbara Smith
curated_info.excerpt: ‘Systemic racism’ conveys the pervasiveness of racial oppression, but white supremacy goes further by indicating that there is a rigid nexus of power that protects and enforces it.
curated_info.title: The Problem Is White Supremacy

curated_info.author: Dae Shik Kim, Jr.
curated_info.excerpt: Too many Asian Americans have put proximity to whiteness over solidarity with Black people. It’s time for a radical readjustment.
curated_info.title: Why Be a ‘Model Minority’ When You Could Dismantle White Supremacy?

curated_info.author: Intersectionality Matters with Kimberlé Crenshaw
curated_info.excerpt: The different locations where White Supremacy has been deployed and unveiled amidst crisis — from voting booths in Wisconsin, royal handshakes at 10 Downing Street, and gun stores in the “American heartland,” to overcrowded jails in Chicago, public housing in the American South, and the chambers of Congress.
curated_info.title: Under the Blacklight: COVID & Disaster White Supremacy

curated_info.author: Gaslit Nation with Andrea Chalupa and Sarah Kendzior
curated_info.excerpt: On the anniversary of the violent white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., the hosts continue with the Get Un-Gaslit Summer Reading Series with an interview with sociologist Dr. Crystal Fleming.

publisher.name: Gaslit Nation with Andrea Chalupa and Sarah Kendzior

curated_info.title: Crystal Fleming on White Supremacy

curated_info.author: The Dick Cavett Show
curated_info.excerpt: James Baldwin has an open discussion of racial prejudice, civil rights activism and policing. (1969)
curated_info.title: James Baldwin Discusses Racism

curated_info.author: YouTube
curated_info.excerpt: A striking feature of the literature on social justice produced over the past few decades is the marginality of racial justice as a central theme.
curated_info.title: Provost Lecture: Charles Mills – Liberalism and Racial Justice

curated_info.author: PBS NewsHour
curated_info.excerpt: What comes to mind when you hear the phrase “white supremacy”? For actor comedian Peter Kim, it’s facing the commonplace cultural assumption that white is the default race in America.
curated_info.title: The White Supremacy of Being Asked Where I’m From

curated_info.author: The Intercept
curated_info.excerpt: The sanctity of the Second Amendment for all Americans is a myth. It is a myth today and it has been a myth from the beginning.
curated_info.title: White Supremacy and the Second Amendement

collections.description: The phrase “white supremacy” is often invoked in reference to the Ku Klux Klan or white nationalist extremism, rather than as a system of power with long historical roots. Crystal Marie Fleming, author of How to Be Less Stupid About Race: On Racism, White Supremacy and the Racial Divide, offers a curated reading list examining how systemic racism has been deeply entrenched within our economic system, social and political institutions, public policies, and cultural symbols.
collections.title: Beyond the KKK: Understanding White Supremacy as a System of Power

curated_info.author: Jamil Smith
curated_info.excerpt: How the movement that’s changing America was built and where it goes next.
curated_info.title: The Power of Black Lives Matter

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Hinton
curated_info.excerpt: A proper understanding of urban rebellion depends on our ability to interpret it not as a wave of criminality, but as political violence.
curated_info.title: The Minneapolis Uprising in Context

curated_info.author: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
curated_info.excerpt: “What I want to see is not a rush to judgment, but a rush to justice.”
curated_info.title: Don’t Understand the Protests? What You’re Seeing is People Pushed to the Edge

curated_info.author: Brittney Cooper
curated_info.excerpt: Why does it remain so difficult for outrage over the killing of Black women to be the tipping point for national protests challenging state violence?
curated_info.title: Why Are Black Women and Girls Still an Afterthought in Our Outrage Over Police Violence?

curated_info.author: Michael Harriot
curated_info.excerpt: Without the proper context, it is impossible to understand the mushroom cloud of uprisings that are exploding across the country in the wake of the deaths of George Floyd, Breanna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery and countless others.
curated_info.title: A Timeline of Events That Led to the 2020 ‘Fed Up’-rising

curated_info.author: Special Report
curated_info.excerpt: In 1921, Tulsa was home to one of the most prosperous African American communities in the country. But in a span of just more than 12 hours, the thriving community known as Black Wall Street was wiped out by white mobs.
curated_info.title: Tulsa Race Massacre: This is What Happened in Tulsa in 1921

curated_info.author: Maurice Carlos Ruffin
curated_info.excerpt: “It occurred to me that like a wedding or a funeral announcement, a lynching was a kind of press release.”
curated_info.title: The Great American Press Release

curated_info.author: Orly Clerge
curated_info.excerpt: The sparks of global rebellion we are seeing today are rooted in the Haitian Revolution, the first successful Black-led uprising for racial equality and independence in the modern world.
curated_info.title: Big Fires Everywhere: How the Haitian Revolution Inspired Today’s Protesters

curated_info.author: Age of Revolutions
curated_info.excerpt: Perhaps more than ever, we need to better educate ourselves on the history of slavery, and consider the ways in which it informs how we have arrived at the present.
curated_info.title: Reading the History of Slavery: 3 Experts Offer Book Recommendations

curated_info.author: Nikole Hannah-Jones
curated_info.excerpt: Our founding ideals of liberty and equality were false when they were written. For generations, black Americans have fought to make them true.
curated_info.title: America Wasn’t a Democracy, Until Black Americans Made It One

curated_info.author: Jabari Asim
curated_info.excerpt: “What could be more American than pretending truths were self-evident when they seldom were?”
curated_info.title: Getting it Twisted

curated_info.author: David Montgomery
curated_info.excerpt: Demands for racial equity and justice have always been part of the American story. While the images here span the past two weeks, the words paired with them span the past 100 years.
curated_info.title: The Endless Call

curated_info.author: As told to Angelina Chapin
curated_info.excerpt: “It’s hard to breathe without her.”
curated_info.title: A Mother’s Birthday Tribute to Breonna Taylor

curated_info.author: Manny Fernandez and Audra D. S. Burch
curated_info.excerpt: George Floyd had big plans for life nearly 30 years ago. His death in police custody is powering a movement against police brutality and racial injustice.
curated_info.title: George Floyd, From ‘I Want to Touch the World’ to ‘I Can’t Breathe’

curated_info.author: Mitchell S. Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: Ahmaud Arbery went out for a jog and was gunned down in the street. How running fails Black America.
curated_info.title: Twelve Minutes and a Life

curated_info.author: Kate Shellnutt
curated_info.excerpt: As a person of peace, “Big Floyd” opened up ministry opportunities in the Third Ward housing projects.
curated_info.title: George Floyd Left a Gospel Legacy in Houston

curated_info.author: Melissa Segura
curated_info.excerpt: These are their stories.
curated_info.title: On The Day George Floyd Died, Police Across The US Shot And Killed At Least Five Other Men

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Alexander
curated_info.excerpt: “I call the young people who grew up in the past twenty-five years the Trayvon Generation. They always knew these stories. These stories formed their world view. These stories helped instruct young African-Americans about their embodiment and their vulnerability.”
curated_info.title: The Trayvon Generation

curated_info.author: Ibram X. Kendi
curated_info.excerpt: To be black and conscious of anti-black racism is to stare into the mirror of your own extinction.
curated_info.title: The American Nightmare

curated_info.author: Erica Dawson
curated_info.excerpt: Black lives matter and so do the characterizations of those lives that lead to their demise.
curated_info.title: Americana

curated_info.author: Shenequa Golding
curated_info.excerpt: “I just witnessed the lynching of a black man, but don’t worry Ted, I’ll have those deliverables to you end of day.”
curated_info.title: Maintaining Professionalism In The Age of Black Death Is….A Lot

curated_info.author: Bernice L. McFadden
curated_info.excerpt: Bernice L. McFadden ruminates on all the things her mother has endured only to find herself spending her golden years in the midst of a deadly plague and state-sanctioned racism.
curated_info.title: What Didn’t Kill Her

curated_info.author: Brian Crooks
curated_info.excerpt: “The first time I was acutely aware of my Blackness, I was probably 6 or 7 years old.”
curated_info.title: What It’s Like To Be Black in Naperville, America

curated_info.author: R. Eric Thomas
curated_info.excerpt: On Omar Jimenez, George Floyd, Christian Cooper and the myth of being non-threatening.
curated_info.title: It Does Not Matter If You Are Good

curated_info.author: Garnette Cadogan
curated_info.excerpt: “I wasn’t prepared for any of this. I had come from a majority-black country in which no one was wary of me because of my skin color. Now I wasn’t sure who was afraid of me.”
curated_info.title: Walking While Black

curated_info.author: Niela Orr
curated_info.excerpt: On the eve of her birthday, in a moment of extraordinary darkness, a critic explores questions of aging and visibility through two exceedingly different works of art.
curated_info.title: Long Time Woman

curated_info.author: Saeed Jones
curated_info.excerpt: For Saeed Jones, generations collapse into seconds during an American week of chaos and sorrow.
curated_info.title: Whose Grief? Our Grief

curated_info.author: Nikole Hannah-Jones
curated_info.excerpt: Shots were fired in Long Island, but there was no rush to call 911. It made perfect sense to this reporter.
curated_info.title: Yes, Black America Fears the Police. Here’s Why.

curated_info.author: Anna North
curated_info.excerpt: “The problem is the way policing was built,” historian Khalil Muhammad says.
curated_info.title: How Racist Policing Took Over American Cities, Explained by a Historian

curated_info.author: Katherine Landergan
curated_info.excerpt: And rebuilt the department from the ground up. The strange, hopeful, politically complicated story of Camden, N.J.
curated_info.title: The City That Really Did Abolish the Police

curated_info.author: Maya Dukmasova
curated_info.excerpt: Police unions were born of resistance to discipline for brutality. Do they belong in the labor movement?
curated_info.title: From Soldier to Worker

curated_info.author: Aaron Mak
curated_info.excerpt: How tear gas went from a World War I weapon to police’s favorite anti-protester tool.
curated_info.title: “The Charged Vapor”

curated_info.author: Kathryn VanArendonk
curated_info.excerpt: TV perfected the cop show, metastasized it, and then franchised it into ubiquity. How does that affect the way audiences think about police?
curated_info.title: On TV, Cops Are Always the Main Characters

curated_info.author: Ryan Cooper
curated_info.excerpt: Nordic nations have both enormously smaller police departments and prison systems than the United States, and much less violent crime, especially murders.
curated_info.title: What America Can Learn From Nordic Police

curated_info.author: Maurice Chammah and Cary Aspinwall
curated_info.excerpt: The controversial version of the U.S. flag has been hailed as a sign of police solidarity and criticized as a symbol of white supremacy.
curated_info.title: The Short, Fraught History of the ‘Thin Blue Line’ American Flag

curated_info.author: Joshua Nevett
curated_info.excerpt: When videos of controversial police encounters generate headlines, there’s an important figure in the story that we rarely hear about – the person filming.
curated_info.title: The Personal Cost of Filming Police Brutality

curated_info.author: Wendi C. Thomas
curated_info.excerpt: Wendi C. Thomas is a black journalist who has covered police in Memphis. One officer admitted to spying on her. She’s on a long list of prominent black journalists and activists who have been subjected to police surveillance over decades.
curated_info.title: The Police Have Been Spying on Black Reporters and Activists for Years. I Know Because I’m One of Them.

curated_info.author: Imani Perry
curated_info.excerpt: So many people taught us to be more than the hatred heaped upon us.
curated_info.title: Racism Is Terrible. Blackness Is Not.

curated_info.author: Wesley Morris
curated_info.excerpt: Awash in the ghastly video mosaic shot by black people’s cameraphones, I found myself doubled over the kitchen sink. Then a lyric gave me strength.
curated_info.title: The Videos That Rocked America. The Song That Knows Our Rage.

curated_info.author: Nyle Fort
curated_info.excerpt: Between the coronavirus and police killings, Black communities are coping with seemingly endless grief. The absence of funerals during the pandemic has been particularly devastating to a culture in which collective mourning plays a vital role.
curated_info.title: Refusing to Give Death the Last Word

curated_info.author: Amethyst Ganaway
curated_info.excerpt: For 500 years, Black communities in America have sustained and supported protest through food.
curated_info.title: Black Communities Have Always Used Food as Protest

curated_info.author: Nic Stone
curated_info.excerpt: Nic Stone, author of the best-selling young adult novel Dear Martin, explains why your anti-racist reading lists aren’t enough.
curated_info.title: Don’t Just Read About Racism—Read Stories About Black People Living

curated_info.author: Doreen St. Félix
curated_info.excerpt: Understanding the appeal of the ‘carefree’ aesthetic to black male musicians from Young Thug to Chance the Rapper.
curated_info.title: On Carefree Black Boys

curated_info.author: Alicia A. Wallace
curated_info.excerpt: “Parable of the Sower” isn’t just a prescient dystopia—it’s a monument to the wisdom of Black women and girls.
curated_info.title: You Should Have Been Listening to Octavia Butler This Whole Time

curated_info.author: L.L. McKinney
curated_info.excerpt: “Black readers need to see themselves in narratives outside of racism, slavery, Jim Crow, police brutality. As do non-Black readers. In order to create a safe world for Black people, books that don’t focus on “issues” need to be given just as much space.”
curated_info.title: The Role Publishing Plays in the Commodification of Black Pain

curated_info.author: Rahawa Haile
curated_info.excerpt: What happens when an African American woman decides to solo-hike the Appalachian Trail from Georgia to Maine during a summer of bitter political upheaval? Everything you can imagine, from scary moments of racism to new friendships to soaring epiphanies about the timeless value of America’s most storied trekking route.
curated_info.title: Going It Alone

curated_info.author: Panama Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: “I don’t know exactly when I decided to stop writing about whiteness and focus purely on blackness. What I do know is that for the past few years I specifically made a decision to write about the celebration of blackness and black culture and whatever comes with it.”
curated_info.title: Just Don’t Forget That Black Pain Isn’t All We Have

curated_info.author: Lovey Cooper
curated_info.excerpt: If you’re a “well-meaning” white person feeling lost in your own self-actualization process, here are five basic ideas you must grasp.
curated_info.title: Reckoning With White Supremacy: Five Fundamentals for White Folks

curated_info.author: Tomi Obaro
curated_info.excerpt: If you’re not black and you have black friends whom you are only reaching out to now, be thoughtful about how you do it.
curated_info.title: White People, Read This Before You Text Your Black Friends

curated_info.author: Emmanuel Dzotsi
curated_info.excerpt: Black people all across the US are receiving the world’s weirdest form of reparations: Venmo payments from white people. In this podcast, producer Emmanuel Dzotsi investigates.
curated_info.title: The Least You Could Do

curated_info.author: Megan Reid
curated_info.excerpt: Mostly, my non-Black friends are doing all of the right things this week, both online and off. But that doesn’t stop me from being mad.
curated_info.title: My White Friends Are Buying Books About Racism. I Wish They’d Talked To Me Instead.

curated_info.author: Ijeoma Oluo
curated_info.excerpt: Too often whites at discussions on race decide for themselves what will be discussed, what they will hear, what they will learn. And it is their space. All spaces are.
curated_info.title: Confronting Racism is Not About the Needs and Feelings of White People

curated_info.author: Emmanuel Acho
curated_info.excerpt: Emmanuel Acho sits down to have an “uncomfortable conversation” with white America, in order to educate and inform on racism, system racism, social injustice, rioting & the hurt African Americans are feeling today.
curated_info.title: Uncomfortable Conversations with a Black Man

curated_info.author: Marina Magloire
curated_info.excerpt: “This sudden attention to the ongoing grief of black life can also feel like a slap in the face. Didn’t you notice we were dying?”
curated_info.title: Black Bereavement, White Condolences

curated_info.author: Lanre Bakare
curated_info.excerpt: The veteran civil rights campaigner on growing up in segregated America, the opportunity of the Black Lives Matter movement and what inspires her to keep fighting.
curated_info.title: Angela Davis: ‘We Knew That the Role of the Police Was to Protect White Supremacy’

curated_info.author: Zak Cheney-Rice
curated_info.excerpt: John Lewis, congressman and civil-rights legend, will never lose hope.
curated_info.title: The Long View

curated_info.author: Isaac Chotiner
curated_info.excerpt: “Changing the way we police, prosecute, judge, and punish is the essence of criminal-justice reform,” the famed civil-rights lawyer and founder founder of the Equal Justice Initiative says.
curated_info.title: Bryan Stevenson on the Frustration Behind the George Floyd Protests

curated_info.author: Karen Grigsby Bates
curated_info.excerpt: Talking about race, feminism and COVID-19 with Mikki Kendall, author of the new book Hood Feminism: Notes from the Women that a Movement Forgot.
curated_info.title: What Does ‘Hood Feminism’ Mean For A Pandemic?

curated_info.author: Ezra Klein
curated_info.excerpt: The author of Between the World and Me on why this isn’t 1968, the Colin Kaepernick test, police abolition, nonviolence and the state, and more.
curated_info.title: Why Ta-Nehisi Coates is Hopeful

curated_info.author: Zach Baron
curated_info.excerpt: In a rare interview, the activist opens up about the George Floyd protests, police brutality, and the conditions in the Missouri Eastern Correctional Center after a staffer came down with coronavirus.
curated_info.title: Jailed Ferguson Protester Joshua Williams Wants to Be Out There With Everyone

curated_info.author: Emma Bracy
curated_info.excerpt: An interview with adrienne maree brown on why changing the world doesn’t have to be just another form of work.
curated_info.title: Pleasure Activism: A Feel-Good Approach to Changing the World

curated_info.author: Harper’s Bazaar
curated_info.excerpt: Activist and academic Rachel Cargle takes us into the weeds of America’s systems of oppression with womanist scholar EbonyJanice Moore.
curated_info.title: Rachel Cargle Insists Rest Is the Real Revolution for Black Women

curated_info.author: Under The Radar Staff
curated_info.excerpt: In Black families, it’s known as “The Talk”: the discussion Black parents have with their kids about what to do should they end up in an interaction with a police officer.
curated_info.title: Black Fatherhood In The Wake Of George Floyd

curated_info.author: Stacia Brown
curated_info.excerpt: This country prizes Black children’s precocity — insists on it, even, much of the time.
curated_info.title: The Sacrifice Black Children Shouldn’t Have to Make

curated_info.author: Jimmie Briggs
curated_info.excerpt: With a new daughter entering a world defined by protests and a pandemic, a middle-aged father feels his faith in America—or, more accurately, “Great-Again America”—slipping away.
curated_info.title: “No, I Am Not Okay”: A Black Journalist Addresses His White Friends

curated_info.author: Clint Smith
curated_info.excerpt: When the Movement for Black Lives began, I did not have children. Now the fight means more to me—coupled with fears that are even deeper.
curated_info.title: Becoming a Parent in the Age of Black Lives Matter

curated_info.author: Topher Sanders
curated_info.excerpt: On a playground, the messy birth of a 5-year-old’s “otherness.”
curated_info.title: ‘Only White People,’ Said the Little Girl

curated_info.author: Allison Briscoe-Smith
curated_info.excerpt: Even for a psychologist who studies how kids understand racism and violence, talking to her own children about it is difficult.
curated_info.title: How Can I Stay Positive for My Kids When I’m So Overwhelmed?

curated_info.author: Politico
curated_info.excerpt: Two dozen experts explain why.
curated_info.title: It Really Is Different This Time

curated_info.author: Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor
curated_info.excerpt: The quest to transform this country cannot be limited to challenging its brutal police.
curated_info.title: How Do We Change America?

curated_info.author: Zyahna Bryant
curated_info.excerpt: A Charlottesville-based activist, organizer, and social impact strategist — offers insight into how people can take anti-racist action.
curated_info.title: Beyond the Hashtag: How to Take Anti-Racist Action in Your Life

curated_info.author: Shanita Hubbard
curated_info.excerpt: An expert breaks down what anti-racism actually is, and how we can truly embrace it.
curated_info.title: Why Anti-Racism Is Our Best Chance at Creating Real Change

curated_info.author: Michelle Alexander
curated_info.excerpt: We must get it right this time or risk losing our democracy forever.
curated_info.title: America, This is Your Chance

collections.description: Since demonstrations against anti-Black racism and police brutality began in late May, Pocket has recommended dozens of articles, essays, and interviews on the fight for racial justice and Black lives — from the history of anti-Black racism in America to reflections on Black resilience and remembrances of those lost. Below is a small sampling of these recommended reads.
collections.title: What We’re Reading: The Fight for Racial Equity, Justice and Black Lives

curated_info.excerpt: Noted journalist Jenna Wortham (of The New York Times and the NYT podcast Still Processing) sits down with superb music supervisor Morgan Rhodes (Middle of Nowhere, Selma, Dear White People) and talks beginnings, process and chance.
curated_info.title: Seeing Sounds

curated_info.excerpt: Our mothers, ourselves. Hate it or love it, traits of the women who birthed and raised us are coursing through our veins.
curated_info.title: An Ode to The Mamas

curated_info.author: Chanté Joseph
curated_info.excerpt: Turning the experiences of disparate groups into a monolith has never been good practice. We need to think radically about the terms we use to identify collectively moving forward.
curated_info.title: Bookmark This: Are Acronyms Like BAME a Nonsense?

curated_info.author: Leah Cowan
curated_info.excerpt: From watching queer film and TV to cooking up a storm, there’s more than one way to celebrate Pride this year.
curated_info.title: 5 Ways I’ve Been Celebrating Pride in Lockdown

curated_info.author: Sarah Cuddie and Betty Fermin
curated_info.excerpt: The workplace can be stressful for everyone, but there are additional stressors that negatively impact women and non-binary people in the workplace, especially if they also hold other marginalized identities.
