curated_info.title: Your Identity is a Risk Factor: Workplace Stress and Your Health

curated_info.author: Cara Taylor
curated_info.excerpt: A photo series created in contemplation of what it means to nourish the Black body.
curated_info.title: Protect Ya Neck

curated_info.author: Renata Cherlise
curated_info.excerpt: A research based series examining the yearbooks of predominately Black high-schools across America. The series begins in Chicago & takes a look at the many ways Black lives were documented and celebrated throughout the years.
curated_info.title: The Class of Blackness

curated_info.author: Renata Cherlise and Russell Hamilton
curated_info.excerpt: Paying homage to Sthaddeus “Polo Silk” Terrell, the photographer who captured the heartbeat of New Orleans over three decades.
curated_info.title: Polo Silk: ‘BURY ME WITH THE LO ON’

curated_info.excerpt: Classical singer and musicologist Kameron Locke talks about the anxiety, anger and sadness he feels while watching the uprisings against police brutality from abroad.
curated_info.title: Black, American, and Abroad During the Uprisings

curated_info.excerpt: Veteran Chicago journalist Monroe Anderson reflects on today’s anti-police uprisings and the 1968 anti-war uprisings, and the police who battered and bruised the press and the protestors during both.
curated_info.title: 1968: When the Whole World Was Watching, the Chicago Police Rioted

curated_info.excerpt: Volume Four of The Tenth Magazine explores the Black queer identity at the threshold of the future—unchartered territory where the obvious consequences of technology are changing the face of the planet we live on, but the more obscure consequences—the far-reaching and truly philosophical, social implications—are being overlooked by us all.
curated_info.title: The Technology Issue

curated_info.excerpt: From “Hollywood It Boys” to “The Men Behind The Muses,” our editors and collaborators present an authentic epistemology of contemporary Los Angeles from all sides— the dark side of the Southern California dream to the glitter of the Hollywood Hills.
curated_info.title: The Hollywood Issue

curated_info.excerpt: #BlkGrlsWurld’s top metal picks from Post-Hardcore to Mathcore, plus a self-care mix for Black Womxn.
curated_info.title: Spotify Playlists To Get You Through

curated_info.excerpt: An interview with Chris L.Terry Writer of Black Card: A Novel.
curated_info.title: In the Scene

curated_info.author: Briyana D. Clarel
curated_info.excerpt: A short list of organizations, groups, and projects that support Black livelihood and well-being.
curated_info.title: 7 Black Projects for Black Well-being

curated_info.author: Briyana D. Clarel
curated_info.excerpt: It took a pandemic for me to start a morning routine, but it’s finally happening.
curated_info.title: 6 Prompts to Jumpstart Your Journaling

collections.description: It took a pandemic for me to start a morning routine, but it’s finally happening.
collections.title: Discover 8 Great Black Indie Publications

curated_info.author: Doreen St. Felix
curated_info.excerpt: Black teens are shaping the culture we consume. But what happens when they don’t own their work?
curated_info.title: Black Teens Are Breaking the Internet and Seeing None of the Profits

curated_info.author: David Dennis Jr.
curated_info.excerpt: From Black Voices to MySpace to Instagram, black creativity has defined social media from the start.
curated_info.title: A Blessing and a Curse: The Rich History Behind ‘Black Twitter’

curated_info.author: Lauren Michele Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: Digital blackface allows non-black people to embody blackness. Are you part of the problem?
curated_info.title: We Need to Talk About Digital Blackface

curated_info.author: Taylor Lorenz
curated_info.excerpt: A 14-year-old in Atlanta created one of the biggest dances on the internet. But nobody really knows that.
curated_info.title: The Original Renegade

curated_info.author: Tatiana Walk-Morris
curated_info.excerpt: Under the hashtags #Ghetto and #CripWalkChallenge, white teens appropriate Black culture.
curated_info.title: Tik Tok’s Digital Blackface Problem

curated_info.author: Kat Tenbarge
curated_info.excerpt: Stan culture phrases like ‘periodt,’ ‘wig,’ and ‘and I oop’ originated in Black slang, while terms like ‘sksksk’ have less identifiable origins.
curated_info.title: From ‘Periodt’ to ‘And I Oop,’ the Most Common Stan Culture and VSCO Girl Slang Is Rooted in Cultural Appropriation

curated_info.author: Lauren Michele Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: Vine was a white-hot sterling feature of a larger truth: The internet depends on black people.
curated_info.title: The Undeniable Blackness of Vine (RIP)

curated_info.author: Amanda Hess and Shane O’Neill
curated_info.excerpt: All across the internet, white people feel empowered to play around with black identity.
curated_info.title: The White Internet’s Love Affair With Digital Blackface

curated_info.author: Function with Anil Dash
curated_info.excerpt: Exploring the concept of commodifying culture through video games.
curated_info.title: What Does Epic Games Owe Artists Who Inspire Fortnite Emotes?

collections.title: When Black Digital Culture Gets Appropriated

curated_info.author: Bryan Lee Jr.
curated_info.excerpt: Architects and planners have an obligation to protect health, safety and welfare through the spaces we design. As the George Floyd protests reveal, we’ve failed.
curated_info.title: America’s Cities Were Designed to Oppress

curated_info.author: Manisha Claire
curated_info.excerpt: How Better Homes in America—a collaboration between Herbert Hoover and the editor of a conservative women’s magazine—promoted idealized whiteness.
curated_info.title: The Latent Racism of the Better Homes in America Program

curated_info.author: Abdallah Fayyad
curated_info.excerpt: Areas that are changing economically often draw more police—creating conditions for more surveillance and more potential misconduct.
curated_info.title: The Criminalization of Gentrifying Neighborhoods

curated_info.author: Amina Yasin
curated_info.excerpt: Planners and urbanists, it’s time to reckon with the racism rampant in city building. Here are four actions to take.
curated_info.title: Whose Streets? Black Streets

curated_info.author: Corinne Ramey
curated_info.excerpt: How our transportation system discriminates against the most vulnerable.
curated_info.title: America’s Unfair Rules of the Road

curated_info.author: Jay Pitter
curated_info.excerpt: Placemaker and author Jay Pitter argues for an equity-based understanding of urban density during the COVID-19 crisis and beyond.
curated_info.title: Urban Density: Confronting the Distance Between Desire and Disparity

curated_info.author: Aaron Williams and Armand Emamdjomeh
curated_info.excerpt: The United States is on track to be a majority-minority nation by 2044. But census data show most of our neighbors are the same race.
curated_info.title: America Is More Diverse Than Ever — But Still Segregated

curated_info.author: Carolina A. Miranda
curated_info.excerpt: Conversations in the world of design and urban planning can often get tied up on issues such as bike lanes and height limits, without considering the larger inequities our cities perpetuate — such as the ways in which the public space is policed.
curated_info.title: Nine Ideas for Making Our City’s Public Space More Race Equitable

curated_info.author: Wai Architecture Think Tank
curated_info.excerpt: An anti-racist architecture manifesto.
curated_info.title: Un-Making Architecture

collections.description: Decades of discriminatory policy and planning decisions have kept many American urban centers segregated and inequitable. In this curated reading list, Fortune staff writer Aric Jenkins examines how race continues to shape the design and infrastructure of American cities—from public spaces to mass transit, housing to architecture—and considers solutions to help make cities more reflective of the people who live there.
collections.title: How Race Shapes the American City

curated_info.author: Safiya Umoja Noble
curated_info.excerpt: My first encounter with racism in search was in 2009 when I was talking to a friend who causally mentioned one day, “You should see what happens when you Google ‘black girls.’” I did and was stunned. (An excerpt from Algorithms of Oppression.)
curated_info.title: Google Has a Striking History of Bias Against Black Girls

curated_info.author: by Julia Angwin, Jeff Larson, Surya Mattu and Lauren Kirchner
curated_info.excerpt: There’s software used across the country to predict future criminals. And it’s biased against blacks.
curated_info.title: Machine Bias

curated_info.author: Cade Metz
curated_info.excerpt: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
curated_info.title: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say

curated_info.author: Annette Zimmermann, Elena DiRosa, and Hochan Kim
curated_info.excerpt: We need greater democratic oversight of AI not just from developers and designers, but from all members of society.
curated_info.title: Technology Can’t Fix Algorithmic Injustice

curated_info.author: Rebecca Heilweil
curated_info.excerpt: A computer can make a decision faster. That doesn’t make it fair.
curated_info.title: Why Algorithms Can Be Racist and Sexist

curated_info.author: Safiya Noble
curated_info.excerpt: We need more intense attention on how artificial intelligence forestalls the ability to see what kinds of choices we are making.
curated_info.title: Social Inequality Will Not Be Solved by an App

curated_info.author: Sharon Begley
curated_info.excerpt: Algorithms used by hospitals and physicians to guide the health care given to tens of millions of Americans are shot through with implicit racism that their creators are often unaware of, according to a study.
curated_info.title: Racial Bias Skews Algorithms Widely Used to Guide Care from Heart Surgery to Birth, Study Finds

curated_info.author: Beth Schwartzapfel
curated_info.excerpt: A new study adds to the debate over racial bias in risk assessment tools widely used in courtrooms.
curated_info.title: Can Racist Algorithms Be Fixed?

curated_info.author: Marketplace
curated_info.excerpt: The Apple Card debut stumbled as good credit scores didn’t help boost womens’ credit limits.
curated_info.title: Human Biases Are Baked into Algorithms. Now What?

curated_info.author: UCLA Center for Critical Internet Inquiry
curated_info.excerpt: From the way search engines reinforce racism to how digital culture has reshaped the way Black identity is expressed.

publisher.name: UCLA Center for Critical Internet Inquiry

curated_info.title: 15 Books by Black Scholars the Tech Industry Needs to Read Now

curated_info.author: Isaac Chotiner and Sarah T. Roberts
curated_info.excerpt: How the work of content moderation takes a psychological toll.
curated_info.title: The Underworld of Online Content Moderation

curated_info.author: Sasheer Zamata
curated_info.excerpt: Is the future more Black Panther or Black Mirror? Guest correspondent Sasheer Zamata investigates Afrofuturism and the journey to make Snapchat filters actually work.
curated_info.title: Black Future Month

curated_info.author: Harvard Kennedy School
curated_info.excerpt: A conversation about the underlying systems of power, privilege, and oppression as they relate to present-day conversations about algorithms.
curated_info.title: Before Algorithms: A History of Bias and Oppression in Computing

curated_info.author: Othering & Belonging Institute
curated_info.excerpt: From everyday apps to complex algorithms, technology has the potential to hide, speed, and even deepen discrimination, while appearing neutral and even benevolent when compared to racist practices of a previous era.
curated_info.title: Ruha Benjamin on ”The New Jim Code? Race, Carceral Technoscience, and Liberatory Imagination“

curated_info.author: LSE’s Media Policy Project
curated_info.excerpt: The increasingly precise segmentation and targeting of commercial messages has been enabled in large part through the analysis of massive amounts of transaction-generated-information.
curated_info.title: Surveillance and the Public Sphere: Confronting a Democratic Dilemma

curated_info.author: Dr. Seeta Peña Gangadharan
curated_info.excerpt: Most of us don’t realize how much digital systems govern access to our basic public services, like education, health and housing. Even more terrifying is how much data is collected about us and used without our knowledge.
curated_info.title: Technologies of Control and Our Right of Refusal

curated_info.author: Kishonna L. Gray
curated_info.excerpt: It is important to examine the digital manifestations of misogynoir – or what it means to be a Woman of Color existing in the hegemonic spaces of digital technology. But our conceptual frameworks fail to capture the everyday practices that Women of Color exhibit online.

publisher.name: The Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society

curated_info.title: Examining Black Feminism in the Digital Era

collections.description: ​Algorithms and the data that drive them are designed and created by people, which means those systems can carry biases based on who builds them and how they’re ultimately deployed. Safiya Umoja Noble, author of Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism, offers a curated reading list exploring how technology can replicate and reinforce racist and sexist beliefs, how that bias can affect everything from health outcomes to financial credit to criminal justice, and why data discrimination is a major 21st century challenge.
collections.title: The Bias Embedded in Algorithms

curated_info.author: Afua Hirsch
curated_info.excerpt: This is not just ‘horrible stuff that happens in America’. Black people know we need to dismantle the same system in the UK.
curated_info.title: The Racism that Killed George Floyd Was Built in Britain

curated_info.author: Robyn Maynard and Andrea J. Ritchie
curated_info.excerpt: Black lives are being sacrificed in the name of (white) public health, whether through disproportionate exposure to COVID-19 or policing of the people least able to stay home.
curated_info.title: Black Communities Need Support, Not a Coronavirus Police State

curated_info.author: El Jones
curated_info.excerpt: If Americans think of Canada as the not-so-racist neighbor to the north, that might be because that is the myth white people in Canada like to tell themselves.
curated_info.title: Black Canadians Are Suffocating Under a Racist Policing System, Too

curated_info.author: Namwali Serpell
curated_info.excerpt: If witnessing suffering firsthand doesn’t necessarily spark good deeds, why do we think art about suffering will?

publisher.name: The New York Review of Books

curated_info.title: The Banality of Empathy

curated_info.author: Roxane Gay
curated_info.excerpt: Roxane Gay calls on booksellers to stop simply talking about diversity and to step up their role in providing sanctuary, delivered as the keynote to the Publishers Weekly Winter Institute in 2017.
curated_info.title: Tired of Talking About Diversity

curated_info.author: Nikole Hannah-Jones
curated_info.excerpt: Our democracy’s founding ideals were false when they were written. Black Americans have fought to make them true.
curated_info.title: America Wasn’t a Democracy Until Black Americans Made it One

collections.description: Esi Edugyan, the best-selling author of Washington Black and Half-Blood Blues, curates a collection of articles by Black women writers, about everything from the nature of empathy to exploring the Black experience within history and in the present moment – showing some of the many different ways we could be in the world.
collections.title: Esi Edugyan: Black Women I’m Reading

curated_info.author: Brittany Luse and Eric Eddings
curated_info.excerpt: Amid a still raging global pandemic, the nation has been reeling over the most recent spate of killings of Black people at the hands of police. Brittany and Eric sit down to process their feelings and memorialize the lives we lost.
curated_info.title: We’ve Been Here Before

curated_info.author: Brandon Ogbunu
curated_info.excerpt: Starting when he was a senior in college being shook down by a couple cops, Brandon tells us about navigating his ups and downs of a career in science, his startling connection to scientific racism, and his battle against biology’s central dogma.
curated_info.title: The Liberation of RNA

curated_info.author: The Ezra Klein Show
curated_info.excerpt: The author of Between the World and Me on why this isn’t 1968, the Colin Kaepernick test, police abolition, nonviolence and the state, and more.
curated_info.title: Why Ta-Nehisi Coates Is Hopeful

curated_info.author: Saidu Tejan-Thomas and Jay Allison
curated_info.excerpt: Saidu Tejan-Thomas is a young poet. For a long time, he had a story he needed to tell: an homage and apology to his mother.
curated_info.title: Borders Between Us

curated_info.author: B.A. Parker
curated_info.excerpt: A story of relationships told through the small recorded calls between people who love each other.
curated_info.title: Love and Lapses

curated_info.author: Jessica Jupiter
curated_info.excerpt: How it can be different to be an introvert while Black.
curated_info.title: The Black Introverts

curated_info.author: Kimberly Drew and Helga Davis
curated_info.excerpt: Tastemaker Kimberly Drew on the importance of mental health, what it really means to work in the art world, and how drinking water helps her keep the beat.
curated_info.title: Art Maven Kimberly Drew

curated_info.author: Trevor Noah and Tressie McMillan Cottom
curated_info.excerpt: Trevor Noah and guest host Dr. Tressie McMillan Cottom talk about why radical honesty around mental health can be liberating.
curated_info.title: Tressie McMillan Cottom & Trevor Noah: Optimistic and Depressed

curated_info.author: Karla Marie-Rose Derus (read by Uzo Aduba)
curated_info.excerpt: An essay about a book lover’s embarrassing secret.
curated_info.title: How Bibliophiles Flirt

curated_info.author: Neil Drumming
curated_info.excerpt: Afrofuturism is more than sci-fi. It’s a way of looking at black culture that’s fantastic, creative, and oddly hopeful—which feels especially urgent during a time without a lot of optimism.
curated_info.title: We Are in the Future

collections.description: Must-listen podcasts from Black voices, curated by radio producer Bethel Habte.
collections.title: Black Voices at the Mic: Great Podcasts on Love, Sci-Fi, and Radical Honesty

curated_info.author: Ta-Nehisi Coates
curated_info.excerpt: Two hundred fifty years of slavery. Ninety years of Jim Crow. Sixty years of separate but equal. Thirty-five years of racist housing policy. Until we reckon with our compounding moral debts, America will never be whole.
curated_info.title: The Case for Reparations

curated_info.author: Rachel Kaadzi Ghansah
curated_info.excerpt: “What are you?” a member of the Mother Emanuel AME Church in Charleston asked at the trial of the white man who killed eight of her fellow black parishioners and their pastor. Rachel Kaadzi Ghansah spent months in South Carolina searching for an answer.
curated_info.title: A Most American Terrorist: The Making of Dylann Roof

curated_info.author: Nikole Hannah-Jones
curated_info.excerpt: How one school became a battleground over which children benefit from a separate and unequal system.
curated_info.title: Choosing a School for My Daughter in a Segregated City

curated_info.author: Zadie Smith
curated_info.excerpt: Who owns black pain?
curated_info.title: Getting In and Out

curated_info.author: The New York Times
curated_info.excerpt: In August of 1619, a ship appeared on this horizon, near Point Comfort, a coastal port in the English colony of Virginia. It carried more than 20 enslaved Africans, who were sold to the colonists. No aspect of the country that would be formed here has been untouched by the years of slavery that followed. On the 400th anniversary of this fateful moment, it is finally time to tell our story truthfully.
curated_info.title: The 1619 Project

curated_info.author: Rembert Browne
curated_info.excerpt: The death of Michael Brown and 48 hours at the center of an American crisis in Ferguson, Missouri.
curated_info.title: The Front Lines of Ferguson

curated_info.author: Eli Saslow
curated_info.excerpt: How the 27-year-old son of white nationalist leaders quit following his parents’ footsteps and began building bridges with the communities he previously worked to eliminate.
curated_info.title: The White Flight of Derek Black

curated_info.author: Ta-Nehisi Coates
curated_info.excerpt: A history of the first African American White House—and of what came next.
curated_info.title: My President Was Black

curated_info.author: James Baldwin
curated_info.excerpt: The landmark 1968 Q&A on race in America.
curated_info.title: How to Cool It

curated_info.author: Jamelle Bouie
curated_info.excerpt: How the Enlightenment created modern race thinking, and why we should confront it.
curated_info.title: The Enlightenment’s Dark Side

collections.description: From the case for reparations to the front lines of Ferguson, these have been some of the most saved and read essays on race and anti-Black racism on Pocket over the years.
collections.title: Extraordinary Long-Reads on Race & Anti-Black Racism

curated_info.author: National Museum of African American History and Culture
curated_info.excerpt: Talking about race, although hard, is necessary. The National Museum of African American History and Culture is here to provide tools and guidance to empower your journey and inspire conversation.

publisher.name: National Museum of African American History and Culture

curated_info.title: Talking About Race

curated_info.author: Dr. Eddie Moore, Jr.
curated_info.excerpt: For 21 days, do one action to further your understanding of power, privilege, supremacy, oppression, and equity. This plan includes suggestions for readings, podcasts, videos, observations, and ways to form and deepen community connections.
curated_info.title: 21-Day Racial Equity Habit Building Challenge

curated_info.author: Meilan Solly
curated_info.excerpt: These articles, videos, podcasts and websites from the Smithsonian chronicle the history of anti-black violence and inequality in the United States.
curated_info.title: 158 Resources to Understand Racism in America

curated_info.author: Curated by Dr. Nicole A. Cooke
curated_info.excerpt: A project of the Augusta Baker Endowed Chair at the University of South Carolina.

publisher.name: Curated by Dr. Nicole A. Cooke

curated_info.title: Anti-Racism Resources for All Ages

curated_info.author: Curated by Maya Popa
curated_info.excerpt: These recent poetry collections offer poignant narratives and snapshots of racial injustice in America, from lasting testaments of systemic violence to a public appeal for the vital work that remains to be done as the country confront its legacy of racism and exploitation.
curated_info.title: An Anti-Racist Poetry Reading List

curated_info.author: African American Intellectual History Society
curated_info.excerpt: These readings provide valuable information about the history of racial violence in this country and contextualize the history of race relations in South Carolina and the United States in general.
curated_info.title: #CharlestonSyllabus

curated_info.author: Greater Good Magazine
curated_info.excerpt: Articles that explore our potential to reduce prejudice in society and in ourselves.
curated_info.title: Anti-Racist Resources from Greater Good

curated_info.author: Layla F. Saad
curated_info.excerpt: What will happen after this news cycle is over and social media posts about diversity die down? Author Layla F. Saad chooses books to fortify a long-term struggle.
curated_info.title: Do the Work: An Anti-Racist Reading List

curated_info.author: JSTOR Daily
curated_info.excerpt: The United States has seen escalating protests over the past week, following the death of George Floyd while in custody of the Minneapolis police. Educators everywhere are asking how can we help students understand that this was not an isolated, tragic incident perpetrated by a few bad individuals, but part of a broader pattern of institutionalized racism.
curated_info.title: Institutionalized Racism: A Syllabus

curated_info.author: Kenneth Jones and Tema Okun
curated_info.excerpt: ​This web-based workbook was originally designed to support the ​Dismantling Racism Works 2-day basic workshop. The workbook is now offered as a resource to the community.
curated_info.title: Dismantling Racism: A Workbook for Social Change Groups

curated_info.author: Jessica Grose
curated_info.excerpt: The conversation about race needs to start early and keep happening.
curated_info.title: Anti-Racism Books for Kids

collections.description: A curated collection of anti-racist reading lists and resource guides — with links to articles, books, films, and more — to better understand systemic racism and ways to confront and dismantle it.
collections.title: Anti-Racist Resources and Reading Lists

curated_info.author: Maya Dukmasova
curated_info.excerpt: Grassroots groups around Chicago are already putting abolitionist ideas into practice.
curated_info.title: Abolish the Police? Organizers Say It’s Less Crazy Than It Sounds

curated_info.author: Rachel Kushner
curated_info.excerpt: In three decades of advocating for prison abolition, the activist and scholar has helped transform how people think about criminal justice.
curated_info.title: Is Prison Necessary? Ruth Wilson Gilmore Might Change Your Mind

curated_info.author: Dan Berger, Mariame Kaba, and David Stein
curated_info.excerpt: Prison abolitionists aren’t naive dreamers. They’re organizing for concrete reforms, animated by a radical critique of state violence.
curated_info.title: What Abolitionists Do

curated_info.author: Kelly Lytle Hernandez
curated_info.excerpt: Felons, illegals, and the case for a new abolition movement.
curated_info.title: Amnesty or Abolition?

curated_info.author: History Is a Weapon
curated_info.excerpt: A conversation between Angela Y. Davis and Dylan Rodriguez
curated_info.title: The Challenge of Prison Abolition

curated_info.author: The Center for Popular Democracy
curated_info.excerpt: Over the last 30 years, at both the national and local levels, governments have dramatically increased their spending on criminalization, policing, and mass incarceration while drastically cutting investments in basic infrastructure and slowing investment in social safety net programs.
curated_info.title: Freedom to Thrive: Reimagining Safety and Security in Our Communities

curated_info.author: Garrett Felber
curated_info.excerpt: Prison and police abolition were key to the thinking of many midcentury civil rights activists. Understanding why can help us ask for change in our own time.
curated_info.title: The Struggle to Abolish the Police is Not New

curated_info.author: Jenn M. Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: Black people’s citizenship remains tethered to whether or not white people feel “safe” around them.
curated_info.title: Calling the Police on Black People Can Put Them in Danger

curated_info.author: Simone Weichselbaum and Nicole Lewis
curated_info.excerpt: Past budget cuts have had unintended consequences. Now, proponents say it’s time to fundamentally reimagine the role of the police.
curated_info.title: Support For Defunding The Police Department Is Growing. Here’s Why It’s Not A Silver Bullet.

curated_info.author: Philip V. McHarris and Thenjiwe McHarris
curated_info.excerpt: Redirect it to emergency response programs that don’t kill black people.
curated_info.title: No More Money for the Police

curated_info.author: Radical Imagination
curated_info.excerpt: As cases of police abuse and misconduct gain attention, activists have moved beyond calls for reform to advocate for the abolition of police. It’s a controversial and widely misunderstood idea. How would police abolition work, exactly? How would we protect public safety? Radical Imagination host Angela Glover Blackwell explores these questions with humanitarian hip-hop artist Jessica Disu, a.k.a. FM Supreme, who has publicly called for police abolition.
curated_info.title: Radical Imagination: Police Abolition (Podcast)

curated_info.author: The Appeal
curated_info.excerpt: Josie and Clint discuss prison abolition with Mariame Kaba, one of the leading organizers in the fight against America’s criminal legal system and a contributing editor for The Appeal. Mariame discusses her own journey into this work, provides perspective on the leaders in this space, and helps us reimagine what the future of this system could look like.
curated_info.title: Justice in America: Mariame Kaba and Prison Abolition (Podcast)

curated_info.author: Radcliffe Institute
curated_info.excerpt: A cross-generational group of leading scholars, activists, and incarcerated women lead discussions on the rich tradition of activism and social theory in the late 20th century using the life and work of the political activist and pioneering philosopher Angela Davis.
curated_info.title: Radical Commitments: The Life and Legacy of Angela Davis, Session on Abolition (Video)

curated_info.author: The Intercept
curated_info.excerpt: A comprehensive road map for understanding how we have arrived at the present political moment of brutality and rebellion.
curated_info.title: Ruth WIlson Gilmore Makes the Case for Abolition (Podcast)

collections.description: As demonstrations against racial injustice and police misconduct sweep the U.S., activists and scholars calling for massive decreases to police spending and deep, structural changes to the prison system have suddenly gained mainstream attention. To better understand the arguments for ‘defunding the police’ and abolishing prisons, explore this list of essential reading curated by political scientist Megan Ming Francis.
collections.title: Reimagining Justice: A Primer on Defunding the Police and Prison Abolition

curated_info.author: Carol Anderson
curated_info.excerpt: There is something so wounded in American society that basic commitment to justice is not part of the operating code.
curated_info.title: In 1919, the State Failed to Protect Black Americans. A Century Later, It’s Still Failing

curated_info.author: Kellie Carter Jackson
curated_info.excerpt: The nationwide protests against police killings have been called un-American by critics, but rebellion has always been used to defend liberty.
curated_info.title: The Double Standard of the American Riot

curated_info.author: Keisha N. Blain
curated_info.excerpt: Police violence against African Americans has persisted for centuries.
curated_info.title: Violence in Minneapolis Is Rooted in the History of Racist Policing in America

curated_info.author: Brittney Cooper
curated_info.excerpt: In a country reeling from being involuntary witnesses to the murder of George Floyd by Minneapolis police, Breonna Taylor’s death does not fit the spectacular forms of police killing that we have come to associate with America’s nefarious lynching past.
curated_info.title: Why Are Black Women and Girls Still an Afterthought in Our Outrage Over Police Violence?

curated_info.author: Robert Greene II
curated_info.excerpt: In the Red Summer of 1919, racist violence hit America as the Spanish flu ravaged the country. With mass protests against police murders sweeping the pandemic-plagued United States, it appears we might be now living in a Red Spring.
curated_info.title: We Are Living in a Red Spring

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Hinton
curated_info.excerpt: A proper understanding of urban rebellion depends on our ability to interpret it not as a wave of criminality, but as political violence.
curated_info.title: The Minneapolis Uprising in Context

curated_info.author: Ibram X. Kendi
curated_info.excerpt: To be black and conscious of anti-black racism is to stare into the mirror of your own extinction.
curated_info.title: The American Nightmare

curated_info.author: Brentin Mock
curated_info.excerpt: Cities spend tens of millions of dollars on lawsuits over police violence and killings. But municipalities are effectively using residents to mortgage the cost.
curated_info.title: How Cities Offload the Cost of Police Brutality

curated_info.author: Melvin Rogers
curated_info.excerpt: The rage on display in Minneapolis is not only about police violence. It is also about the country’s utter disregard for the pain of black Americans.
curated_info.title: We Should Be Afraid, But Not of Protesters

curated_info.author: Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor
curated_info.excerpt: The collapse of politics and governance leaves no other option.
curated_info.title: Of Course There Are Protests. The State Is Failing Black People.

collections.description: In the weeks since the deaths of Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, Tony McDade, and George Floyd, marches against racism and police brutality have swept the United States and cities around the world. To help make sense of this moment, award-winning historian Keisha N. Blain offers this curated collection of articles by black writers on the history of black protest, the legacy of state violence, and why these demonstrations might yet be different.
collections.title: How the Past Echoes in the Protests: A Historian’s Recommended Reads

curated_info.author: Pamela Colloff
curated_info.excerpt: Revisiting a decades-old cold case with only one suspect: the priest who heard the deceased’s final confession.
curated_info.title: Unholy Act

curated_info.author: Josh Dean
curated_info.excerpt: They were an all-star crew. They cooked up the perfect plan. And when they pulled off the caper of the century, it made them more than a fortune—it made them folk heroes.
curated_info.title: The Great Buenos Aires Bank Heist

curated_info.author: Gabriel Cohen
curated_info.excerpt: When a mystery writer moves into a new apartment that seems too good to be true, he slowly unravels its grisly history.
curated_info.title: A Splash of Red

curated_info.author: Jessica Lussenhop
curated_info.excerpt: Inside one of America’s most corrupt police squads.
curated_info.title: When Cops Become Robbers

curated_info.author: Lucas Reilly
curated_info.excerpt: When a widow and three children are found dead after a suspicious fire, an investigation ensues that uncovers one of the victims’ monstrous past.
curated_info.title: Corpses in the Pig Pen: The Tale of Indiana’s Most Notorious Serial Killer

curated_info.author: Steven Leckart
curated_info.excerpt: Tom Justice was once a cyclist chasing Olympic gold. Then he began using his bike for a much different purpose: robbing banks.
curated_info.title: The Bicycle Thief

curated_info.author: Skip Hollandsworth
curated_info.excerpt: Beginning in 2015, Houston was plagued by a series of brutal armored car robberies that bewildered FBI agents for nearly two years. To finally bring down the unassuming mastermind behind it all, the agents had to stage an elaborate trap—and catch him in the act.
curated_info.title: The Doting Boyfriend Who Robbed Armored Cars

curated_info.author: Ned Zeman
curated_info.excerpt: A brilliant American financier and his exotic wife build a lavish mansion in the jungles of Costa Rica, set up a wildlife preserve, and appear to slowly, steadily lose their minds. A spiral of handguns, angry locals, armed guards, uncut diamonds, abduction plots, and a bedroom blazing with 550 Tiffany lamps ends with a body and a compelling mystery.
curated_info.title: The Tale of John and Ann Bender and Their Quest for Paradise

curated_info.author: Zach Schonfeld
curated_info.excerpt: A conversation with the daughter of the serial killer BTK.
curated_info.title: “I Knew Right Away It Was My Dad”

curated_info.author: Hannah Dreier
curated_info.excerpt: Police on Long Island wrote off missing immigrant teens as runaways. One mother knew better — and searched MS-13’s killing fields for answers.
curated_info.title: The Disappeared

curated_info.author: Richard Ben Cramer
curated_info.excerpt: Was the rock legend’s fourth wife murdered, and did the man known as “the Killer” do it?
curated_info.title: The Strange and Mysterious Death of Mrs. Jerry Lee Lewis

curated_info.author: David Grann
curated_info.excerpt: The strange death of a Sherlock Holmes fanatic.
curated_info.title: Mysterious Circumstances

collections.description: For some of us, dark times call for dark reads. Immerse yourself in this collection of riveting true-crime writing, including tales of audacious heists, mysterious deaths, and the reflections of a serial killer’s daughter.
collections.title: 12 Gripping True-Crime Reads

curated_info.author: Neil Payne
curated_info.excerpt: Was Jordan really the greatest basketball player of all time? FiveThirtyEight crunches the numbers.
curated_info.title: Why Michael Jordan Was the Best

curated_info.author: Wright Thompson
curated_info.excerpt: An unforgettable portrait of Jordan in retirement. “As he turns 50, MJ is wondering whether there are any more asses to kick.”
curated_info.title: Michael Jordan Has Not Left the Building

curated_info.author: Thomas Lake
curated_info.excerpt: For years the NBA Hall of Famer has claimed that his high school coach underestimated his talent as a sophomore. Clifton (Pop) Herring, whose life has been a struggle since then, tells a different story.
curated_info.title: Did this Man Really Cut Michael Jordan?

curated_info.author: David Halberstam
curated_info.excerpt: In 1998, legendary journalist David Halberstam chronicled Jordan’s final championship run. A sportswriting classic.
curated_info.title: Jordan’s Moment

curated_info.author: Tom Verducci
curated_info.excerpt: Baseball writer Tom Verducci revisits Jordan’s infamous mid-career foray into baseball, with surprising conclusions.
curated_info.title: Michael Jordan Chose Baseball. Baseball Never Chose Him Back.

curated_info.author: Foster Kamer
curated_info.excerpt: Michael Jordan was about to ditch Nike — until an inexperienced designer created the shoe he’d always dreamed of.
curated_info.title: Air Jordan III: The Shocking Story of the Greatest Shoe Jordan Never Wanted

curated_info.author: Jerry Bembry
curated_info.excerpt: In 2003, John Rogers, a former Princeton guard, legit took down His Airness.
curated_info.title: The CEO Who Beat Michael Jordan One-On-One, and How He Did It

curated_info.author: Henry Louis Gates, Jr.
curated_info.excerpt: How the greatest player in the history of basketball became the greatest brand in the history of sports.
curated_info.title: Net Worth

collections.description: ESPN’s documentary “The Last Dance” about Michael Jordan’s final season with the Chicago Bulls has become required quarantine viewing for many sports-starved fans. With the 10-part miniseries wrapping up this weekend, fill your Pocket with this curated collection of some of the best articles about His Airness, including a few lesser known stories from Jordan’s storied career.
collections.title: Beyond ‘The Last Dance’: A Michael Jordan Reader

curated_info.author: Michael S. Rosenwald
curated_info.excerpt: A look at how pandemics have remade the world.
curated_info.title: History’s Deadliest Pandemics, from Ancient Rome to Modern America

curated_info.author: Chris Mackie
curated_info.excerpt: Thucydides’ account of the plague that struck Athens in 430 B.C. focuses on the social response, both of those who died and those who survived.
curated_info.title: Thucydides and the Plague of Athens – What It Can Teach Us Now

curated_info.author: Annalee Newitz
curated_info.excerpt: Humanity has been surviving plagues for thousands of years, and we have managed to learn a lot along the way.
curated_info.title: What Social Distancing Looked Like in 1666

curated_info.author: Brian Patrick O’Malley
curated_info.excerpt: Despite hopes that America in the future would be spared from anything like Philadelphia’s yellow fever outbreak in 1793, particular incidents might remind Americans of the initial public reaction to the 1980s AIDS crisis or the 2020 coronavirus outbreak.
curated_info.title: The Yellow Fever Outbreak of 1793: Nine Observations and Lessons

curated_info.author: Amy Fleming
curated_info.excerpt: Until the mid-1800s, doctors didn’t bother washing their hands – they would go from dissecting a cadaver to delivering a child. Then a Hungarian medic made an essential, much-resisted breakthrough.
curated_info.title: Keep It Clean: The Surprising 130-Year History of Handwashing

curated_info.author: Daniela Blei
curated_info.excerpt: The history of unpleasant odor, or miasma, has unexpected relevance in the time of COVID-19.
curated_info.title: In 19th-Century America, Fighting Disease Meant Battling Bad Smells

curated_info.author: Hannah Wunsch
curated_info.excerpt: A heroic community effort at a daring hospital saved lives, led to today’s ventilators and revolutionized medicine — it holds lessons for our times.
curated_info.title: The Outbreak that Invented Intensive Care

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Yuko
curated_info.excerpt: Cholera and tuberculosis outbreaks transformed the design and technology of the home bathroom. Will COVID-19 inspire a new wave of hygiene innovation?
curated_info.title: How Infectious Disease Defined the American Bathroom

curated_info.author: Orhan Pamuk
curated_info.excerpt: People have always responded to epidemics by spreading rumor and false information, and portraying the disease as foreign and brought in with malicious intent.
curated_info.title: What the Great Pandemic Novels Teach Us

curated_info.author: David Remnick
curated_info.excerpt: John M. Barry, author of “The Great Influenza: The Story of the Deadliest Pandemic in History,” discusses what the epidemic can tell us about our current situation and the future.
curated_info.title: A Historian’s View of the Coronavirus Pandemic and the Influenza of 1918

curated_info.author: Meilan Solly
curated_info.excerpt: These letters and journals offer insights on how to record one’s thoughts amid a pandemic.
curated_info.title: What We Can Learn From 1918 Influenza Diaries

curated_info.author: Simon Schama
curated_info.excerpt: For millennia, epidemics have tested friendships, faith and society. But, amid the horror there is hope.
curated_info.title: Plague Time: Simon Schama on What History Tells Us

collections.description: Previous epidemics have a lot to teach us about the coronavirus and this moment in history. See our curated collection examining how infectious diseases have altered the way people live — and what this means for the future we’re currently facing.
collections.title: How Past Plagues & Pandemics Have Shaped Human History

curated_info.author: Michael Finkel
curated_info.excerpt: For nearly thirty years, a phantom haunted the woods of Central Maine. Unseen and unknown, he lived in secret, creeping into homes in the dead of night and surviving on what he could steal.
curated_info.title: The Strange & Curious Tale of the Last True Hermit

curated_info.author: Matt Stopera
curated_info.excerpt: This really weird thing happened to me. Then it got even weirder. Then it turned insane. Do I have a story for you.
curated_info.title: How I Became A Minor Celebrity In China (After My Stolen Phone Ended Up There)

curated_info.author: Elizabeth Evitts Dickinson
curated_info.excerpt: How a big crime in a small town produced a whodunit as gripping and colorful as “The Wizard of Oz” itself.
curated_info.title: The Case of the Stolen Ruby Slippers

curated_info.author: Jason Fagone
curated_info.excerpt: Gaming the lottery seemed as good a retirement plan as any.
curated_info.title: Jerry and Marge Go Large

curated_info.author: Ben Montgomery
curated_info.excerpt: When the Great Depression put Plennie Wingo’s Texas cafe out of business, he tried to find fame and fortune by embarking on an audacious trip around the world on foot. In reverse.
curated_info.title: The Man Who Walked Backwards

curated_info.author: Ariel Levy
curated_info.excerpt: In her sixties, a swimmer revives an old dream: to swim from Florida to Cuba—111 miles—no matter how many curious sharks and stinging jellyfish get in her way.
curated_info.title: Breaking the Waves

curated_info.author: Gideon Lewis-Kraus
curated_info.excerpt: If you want to know why the Internet chose cats, you must go to Japan.
curated_info.title: In Search of the Heart of the Online Cat-Industrial Complex

curated_info.author: Caity Weaver
curated_info.excerpt: Tell your fellow Americans that you plan to cross the United States by train, and their reactions will range from amusement at your spellbinding eccentricity to naked horror.
curated_info.title: We’re All In This Together

curated_info.author: Christopher Goffard
curated_info.excerpt: She was the PTA mom everyone knew. Who would want to harm her?
curated_info.title: Framed: A Mystery in Six Parts

curated_info.author: Keith Romer
curated_info.excerpt: Tony Carleo stole $1 million in chips – then checked himself into the casino’s hotel to live like a king.
curated_info.title: Bellagio Bandit: How One Man Robbed Vegas’ Biggest Casino and Almost Got Away

collections.description: There’s nothing like getting lost in a fascinating story — and now is a better time than any to dive into another world. From the gripping account of a 64-year-old woman who swam from Florida to Cuba to the mysterious life of a hermit who lived in the woods undisturbed for 30 years — you won’t be able to put these articles down.
collections.title: 10 Incredible Long-Reads That’ll Transport You to Another Time and Place

curated_info.author: Marina Koren
curated_info.excerpt: Widespread social-distancing measures have produced some jarring effects across land, air, and sea.
curated_info.title: The Pandemic Is Turning the Natural World Upside Down

curated_info.author: Matt Simon
curated_info.excerpt: Sure, emissions have fallen. But a closer look at how the global crisis is influencing the environment reveals some surprising dynamics.
curated_info.title: How Is the Coronavirus Pandemic Affecting Climate Change?

curated_info.author: Howard Kunreuther and Paul Slovic
curated_info.excerpt: Humans don’t easily grasp the concept of exponential growth, but it’s exactly why coronavirus has gotten so hard to manage—and why climate change could too.
curated_info.title: What the Coronavirus Curve Teaches Us About Climate Change

curated_info.author: Russell Jacobs
curated_info.excerpt: Our disappearance will affect food webs and reproduction—and then we will come back.
curated_info.title: The Pandemic Is Giving Animals a Temporary New World

curated_info.author: Adam Levy
curated_info.excerpt: Pollution declines from pandemic shutdowns may aid in answering long-standing questions about how aerosols influence climate.
curated_info.title: COVID-19 Could Help Solve Climate Riddles

curated_info.author: Sigal Samuel
curated_info.excerpt: The story we tell about pandemics casts us as victims of nature. It’s the other way around.

curated_info.author: Sammy Roth
curated_info.excerpt: Society has moved far more aggressively to address the coronavirus than it has the climate crisis. But some experts wonder if the unprecedented global mobilization to slow the pandemic might help pave the way for more dramatic climate action. We asked eight scientists, activists and other experts what a coronavirus-like response to climate change would look like.
curated_info.title: What a Coronavirus-Like Response to the Climate Crisis Would Look Like

curated_info.author: Meehan Crist
curated_info.excerpt: Lockdowns and distancing won’t save the world from warming. But amid this crisis, we have a chance to build a better future.
curated_info.title: What the Coronavirus Means for Climate Change

curated_info.author: Jonathan Watts
curated_info.excerpt: While carbon emissions fall as human activity decreases, in the end it will be about the politics.
curated_info.title: Climate Crisis: In Coronavirus Lockdown, Nature Bounces Back – but for How Long?

collections.description: The 50th anniversary of Earth Day is taking place in a world transformed by the coronavirus pandemic. This April 22, empty highways and shuttered factories around the globe have led to better air quality, cleaner water, and emergent wildlife — a temporary recovery that offers a glimpse at the possibility of a cleaner future. Environmental experts say the global standstill has provided an object lesson in the power of collective action in the face of a large-scale, invisible threat — as well as the dangers of a delayed response.
collections.title: Marking Earth Day During a Pandemic

curated_info.author: Liz Neeley
curated_info.excerpt: Four ways to help those around you be better informed about the pandemic
curated_info.title: How to Talk About the Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Isaac Chotiner
curated_info.excerpt: No matter how often we have been given such advice, it can be hard to totally change our habits, and the specific advice about how to behave can be confusing and overwhelming.
curated_info.title: How to Practice Social Distancing

curated_info.author: Adrienne Matei
curated_info.excerpt: With millions of us lying low to limit the spread of Covid-19, how best to manage being cooped up for days on end?
curated_info.title: How to Survive Isolation With Your Roommates, Your Partner, Your Kids – and Yourself

curated_info.author: Scott Kelly
curated_info.excerpt: Take it from someone who couldn’t: Go outside.
curated_info.title: I Spent a Year in Space, and I Have Tips on Isolation to Share

curated_info.author: Ars Technica
curated_info.excerpt: Your productivity, your health, and your sanity: We have your home office covered.
curated_info.title: Suddenly Working at Home? We’ve Done It for 22 Years—and Have Advice

curated_info.author: Ellen Airhart and Christina Colizza
curated_info.excerpt: Although a quarantine sounds like a solitary pursuit, it takes the proverbial village. Here are the supplies and tips you need to prepare a “hot zone” space for an infected person, especially if there are other vulnerable individuals in the home.
curated_info.title: How to Properly Care for a Sick Person at Home (and Not Get Sick Yourself)

curated_info.author: J. Kenji López-Alt
curated_info.excerpt: Whether you managed to stock your fridge and pantry, or were left staring at empty supermarket shelves, there’s good news: you can still eat safely, even from restaurants, provided you follow a few basic guidelines.
curated_info.title: Food Safety and Coronavirus: A Comprehensive Guide

curated_info.author: Jess Grey
curated_info.excerpt: In-depth best practices for keeping yourself (and just about everything else) clean and virus-free.
curated_info.title: How to Clean and Disinfect Yourself, Your Home, and Your Stuff

curated_info.author: Rebecca Jennings
curated_info.excerpt: Isolation is hard. Here’s how to feel a little less alone, with digital gatherings or just a book.
curated_info.title: How to Gather With Friends While Social Distancing, According to a Meetings Expert

curated_info.author: Gretchen Reynolds
curated_info.excerpt: Those of us who are used to regular exercise naturally have pressing questions and concerns about how best to stay in shape.
curated_info.title: Exercising During Coronavirus: Can I Jog? Is That Water Fountain Safe?

curated_info.author: Courtney Leiva
curated_info.excerpt: The best precautions to take with your laundry, the right detergents to use, and more.
curated_info.title: How Long Coronavirus Lives On Clothes, And How To Wash Them

curated_info.author: Barbara Ortutay and David Klepper
curated_info.excerpt: The coronavirus pandemic is leading to information overload for many people, often making it difficult to separate fact from fiction and rumor from deliberate efforts to mislead.
curated_info.title: Virus Outbreak Means (Mis)information Overload: How to Cope

curated_info.author: Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
curated_info.excerpt: A pandemic is fertile ground for those who suffer from anxiety—here’s a short guide on how to manage it.
curated_info.title: If Coronavirus Scares You, Read This to Take Control Over Your Health Anxiety

curated_info.author: Joe Pinsker
curated_info.excerpt: A guide to convincing your loved ones to take the coronavirus pandemic seriously.
curated_info.title: What Do You Tell Someone Who Still Won’t Stay Home?

collections.description: As governments and communities work to stop the spread of Covid-19, many public health experts warn it could be weeks or even months before it’s safe to relax restrictions on business operations, public gatherings, and regular movement. We’ve curated the best guides to managing life amid the disruptions, from coping with isolation and shopping for groceries to convincing skeptical friends to stay home and caring for sick loved ones. For official U.S. updates on the pandemic, visit cdc.gov. Updated 4/2/20
collections.title: Life During a Pandemic: Adjusting to a New Normal

curated_info.author: Brian Resnick
curated_info.excerpt: Scientists say a moonshot effort is needed to end social distancing and this pandemic. Will leaders listen?
curated_info.title: Social Distancing Can’t Last Forever. Here’s What Should Come Next.

curated_info.author: Joe Pinsker
curated_info.excerpt: The coronavirus outbreak may last for a year or two, but some elements of pre-pandemic life will likely be won back in the meantime.
curated_info.title: The Four Possible Timelines for Life Returning to Normal

curated_info.author: Siddhartha Mukherjee
curated_info.excerpt: We’ve counted the viral spread across peoples; now we need to count it within people.
curated_info.title: How Does the Coronavirus Behave Inside a Patient?

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: The U.S. may end up with the worst COVID-19 outbreak in the industrialized world. This is how it’s going to play out.
curated_info.title: How the Pandemic Will End

curated_info.author: Valerie Bauerlein, Jennifer Levitz, and Alejandro Lazo
curated_info.excerpt: Many Americans are still on the job, tending to basic needs and risking their health as cities close down around them.
curated_info.title: The New Front-Line Coronavirus Workers: Grocery Clerks, Delivery Drivers

curated_info.author: David Remnick
curated_info.excerpt: John M. Barry, who knows the deadliest pandemic in history better than anyone, speculates on what the new coronavirus means for our lives in the future.
curated_info.title: A Historian’s View of the Coronavirus Pandemic and the Influenza of 1918

curated_info.author: Maggie Koerth
curated_info.excerpt: While test shortages are making headlines, there’s a lot about the technology behind these tests that isn’t as clear to the public.
curated_info.title: How Coronavirus Tests Actually Work

curated_info.author: Donald G. McNeil, Jr.
curated_info.excerpt: Scientists who have fought pandemics describe difficult measures needed to defend the United States against a fast-moving pathogen.
curated_info.title: Harsh Steps Are Needed to Contain Coronavirus, Experts Say

curated_info.author: Steven Levy
curated_info.excerpt: Epidemiologist Larry Brilliant, who warned of pandemic in 2006, says we can beat the novel coronavirus—but first, we need lots more testing.
curated_info.title: The Doctor Who Helped Defeat Smallpox Explains What’s Coming

curated_info.author: Ed Yong
curated_info.excerpt: We’ve known about SARS-CoV-2 for only three months, but scientists can make some educated guesses about where it came from and why it’s behaving in such an extreme way.
curated_info.title: Why the Coronavirus Has Been So Successful

curated_info.author: Jessica Lustig
curated_info.excerpt: Our world became one of isolation, round-the-clock care, panic and uncertainty — even as society carried on around us with all too few changes.
curated_info.title: What I Learned When My Husband Got Sick with Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Megan Molteni and Adam Rogers
curated_info.excerpt: How it works, why we need it, and why it’s taking so long for the U.S. to get people diagnosed.
curated_info.title: Everything You Need to Know About Coronavirus Testing

curated_info.author: Steven Bernard, Cale Tilford, John Burn-Murdoch, and Keith Fray
curated_info.excerpt: The countries affected, the number of deaths, and the economic impact.
curated_info.title: Coronavirus Tracked: The Latest Figures as the Pandemic Spreads

curated_info.author: Kaitlyn Tiffany
curated_info.excerpt: Experts weigh in on whether you should cancel your dates, dinner parties, and gym sessions.
curated_info.title: The Dos and Don’ts of ‘Social Distancing’

curated_info.author: Melissa Davey
curated_info.excerpt: The WHO has declared the Covid-19 outbreak to be a pandemic. But what does that mean?
curated_info.title: What Is a Pandemic?

curated_info.author: Anne Helen Petersen
curated_info.excerpt: Everything that was once simple feels difficult, and everything that was already difficult feels impossible.
curated_info.title: Here’s What Parents Dealing With Coronavirus Isolation Want You To Know

curated_info.author: Harry Stevens
curated_info.excerpt: Without any measures to slow it down, Covid-19 will continue to spread exponentially for months. To understand why, it is instructive to simulate the spread of a fake disease through a population.
curated_info.title: Why Outbreaks Like Coronavirus Spread Exponentially, and How to “Flatten the Curve”

curated_info.author: James Hamblin
curated_info.excerpt: Preventing the spread of an outbreak requires a massive global effort, but here are steps everyone can take.
curated_info.title: What You Can Do Right Now About Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Mary Harris
curated_info.excerpt: “It’s our everyday way of going about business on the planet that seems to be driving this.”
curated_info.title: A Warning from a Scientist Who Saw the Coronavirus Coming

curated_info.author: Natalie Escobar
curated_info.excerpt: As the coronavirus has spread from China to other countries, anti-Asian discrimination has followed closely behind.
curated_info.title: When Xenophobia Spreads Like a Virus

curated_info.author: Christian W. McMillen
curated_info.excerpt: We would do well to educate ourselves about the history of pandemics and disease. University of Virginia historian and associate dean Christian W. McMillen, author of Pandemics: A Very Short Introduction, recommends the best introductions to the subject.
curated_info.title: The Best Books on Pandemics

curated_info.author: Sharon Begley
curated_info.excerpt: The new coronavirus is not an equal-opportunity killer: Being elderly and having other illnesses, for instance, greatly increases the risk of dying from the disease the virus causes, Covid-19.
curated_info.title: Who Is Getting Sick, and How Sick?

curated_info.author: Julia Ioffe
curated_info.excerpt: How one young doctor at a Seattle lab tried to get out in front of the coronavirus crisis by inventing his own test.
curated_info.title: Inside the Race to Solve America’s Coronavirus Testing Crisis

curated_info.author: John M. Barry
curated_info.excerpt: The toll of history’s worst epidemic surpasses all the military deaths in World War I and World War II combined. And it may have begun in the United States.
curated_info.title: How the Horrific 1918 Flu Spread Across America

curated_info.author: Carolyn Kormann
curated_info.excerpt: A COVID-19 vaccine developed, licensed, and manufactured at a global scale in twelve months would be an unprecedented, remarkable, even revolutionary achievement.
curated_info.title: How Long Will It Take to Develop a Coronavirus Vaccine?

collections.description: Looking for reliable facts and context on coronavirus? Stay informed with this curated guide to the global outbreak. Updated 4/2/20
collections.title: Coronavirus: Essential Reads

curated_info.author: Madeline Levine
curated_info.excerpt: Tips from a psychologist and tailored by age, whether you have a toddler or a teen in the house.
curated_info.title: How to Talk to Your Child About the Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Amy Coopes
curated_info.excerpt: Kids hear our fears and share them. And they need our help to work it all out.
curated_info.title: Stop a Worry Becoming Catastrophic

curated_info.author: Deborah Farmer Kris
curated_info.excerpt: Just being in the presence of a compassionate, safe adult can help kids calm down. As families, we can be “that person” for each other. (PBS Kids also has resources for helping young kids build germ-busting habits.)
curated_info.title: How You and Your Kids Can De-Stress During Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Jacqueline Sperling
curated_info.excerpt: How to make sure teenagers are informed just enough without feeling overwhelmed, yet also have accurate information.
curated_info.title: How to Talk to Teens About Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Malaka Gharib
curated_info.excerpt: A printable comic for kids based on questions they are asking and facts they want to know.
curated_info.title: Just for Kids: A Comic Exploring the New Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Jackie Spinner
curated_info.excerpt: The world is out of order and scary right now, for adults and for kids, and for my autistic son and many other neurodiverse individuals, those changes can be particularly difficult to navigate.
curated_info.title: Helping Autistic Kids Cope

curated_info.author: Brigit Katz
curated_info.excerpt: Help yourself, and them, by learning techniques to manage stress in a healthy way.
curated_info.title: How to Avoid Passing Anxiety on to Your Kids

curated_info.author: Rae Jacobson
curated_info.excerpt: From keeping routines to limiting news consumption, here’s how to nurture and protect children at home.
curated_info.title: Supporting Kids During the Coronavirus Crisis

curated_info.author: Lindsey M. Roberts
curated_info.excerpt: Before embarking on ambitious academic plans, take a few days to adjust to the new reality.
curated_info.title: Veteran Home-Schoolers Share Tips for Parents During Coronavirus Closures

collections.description: With millions of children home from school and daily routines upended because of the coronavirus, many parents are struggling with how to handle the onslaught of news and disruptions without making kids more concerned than they already are. Experts say parents shouldn’t avoid talking about the pandemic, because children often worry more when they are kept in the dark. The key is to be reassuring and age appropriate, and to make sure you are managing your own anxiety in healthy ways.
collections.title: Talking to Kids About Coronavirus

curated_info.author: Peter Hessler
curated_info.excerpt: Forty-five days of avoiding the coronavirus.
curated_info.title: Life on Lockdown in China

curated_info.author: Rob Schmitz
curated_info.excerpt: Germany’s fatality rate so far — just 0.5% — is the world’s lowest, by a long shot.
curated_info.title: Why Germany’s Coronavirus Death Rate Is Far Lower Than In Other Countries

curated_info.author: Jason Horowitz, Emma Bubola, and Elisabetta Povoledo
curated_info.excerpt: The country’s experience shows that steps to isolate the coronavirus and limit people’s movement need to be put in place early, with absolute clarity, then strictly enforced.
curated_info.title: Italy, Pandemic’s New Epicenter, Has Lessons for the World

curated_info.author: Mattia Ferraresi
curated_info.excerpt: Many of us were too selfish to follow suggestions to change our behavior. Now we’re in lockdown and people are needlessly dying.
curated_info.title: A Coronavirus Cautionary Tale from Italy: Don’t Do What We Did

curated_info.author: Jin Wu, Weiyi Cai, Derek Watkins, and James Glanz
curated_info.excerpt: The most extensive travel restrictions to stop an outbreak in human history haven’t been enough. We analyzed the movements of hundreds of millions of people to show why.
curated_info.title: How the Virus Got Out

curated_info.author: James Palmer
curated_info.excerpt: Life in China is springing back after weeks of lockdown, but it’s still taking place under the shadow of the coronavirus.
curated_info.title: China’s New Normal

curated_info.author: The Wall Street Journal
curated_info.excerpt: Short on supplies and sleep, medical staff in Wuhan have been stretched to the limit.
curated_info.title: One Doctor’s Life on the Coronavirus Front Lines. ‘If We Fail, What Happens to You All?’

curated_info.author: Laura Bicker
curated_info.excerpt: Nearly 20,000 people are being tested every day for coronavirus in South Korea, more people per capita than anywhere else in the world.
curated_info.title: Coronavirus in South Korea: How ‘Trace, Test and Treat’ May Be Saving Lives

curated_info.author: Adam Rogers
curated_info.excerpt: After SARS and H1N1, Singapore built a robust system for tracking and containing epidemics. South Korea, Taiwan, and others did too—here’s what they learned.
curated_info.title: Singapore Was Ready for Covid-19—Other Countries, Take Note

curated_info.author: Ashley Fetters and Timothy McLaughlin
curated_info.excerpt: We can get a sense of what to expect from Hong Kong, where students have already been out of school for more than a month.
curated_info.title: What Could Happen if the Coronavirus Closed Schools for Days, Weeks, or Even Months

curated_info.author: Morena Columbi
curated_info.excerpt: More than the virus, it’s the ignorance that frightens me.
curated_info.title: Coronavirus Diaries: I Had the Coronavirus. This Was the Worst Part.

curated_info.author: Karen Turner
curated_info.excerpt: People in Iran, China, Italy, Singapore, and South Korea describe the anxiety and boredom of life under isolation measures.
curated_info.title: “Our New Life of Isolation”: 5 People Across the World on Staying Inside to Avoid Covid-19

curated_info.author: Vernon Silver, Alessandra Migliaccio, and John Follain
curated_info.excerpt: There are key lessons for the rest of the world: impose harsh rules, fast, and make sure your message is clear.
curated_info.title: Italy’s Nightmare Offers a Chilling Preview of What’s Coming

curated_info.author: Keith Bradsher
curated_info.excerpt: Beijing brought the world’s No. 2 economy to a halt to quell the coronavirus epidemic. Its difficulties in reviving business offer a potential lesson for other countries.
curated_info.title: Halting China’s Economy Was Hard. Restarting It Is Harder.

curated_info.author: Meghan O’Rourke
curated_info.excerpt: We are stubbornly hung up on a damaging idea of self-reliance.
curated_info.title: The Shift Americans Must Make to Fight the Coronavirus

collections.description: For the latest news and data from affected countries, the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security offers daily recaps with case counts and travel restrictions. Johns Hopkins also has a global map of confirmed outbreaks, while The New York Times has mapped confirmed U.S. cases. The World Health Organization has useful guides on protecting yourself and how to tell fact from myth. For official U.S. updates on the pandemic, visit cdc.gov. Updated 4/2/20
collections.title: What Happens Now? Coronavirus Stories from Around the World

curated_info.author: Bee Wilson
curated_info.excerpt: Keith Law: “Clean eating is a fad diet founded on quackery, pseudoscience, and good marketing. So why are people still so desperate to believe in it?”
curated_info.title: Why We Fell for Clean Eating

curated_info.author: Maryn McKenna
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “The federal government and antibiotic manufacturers have worked hand in hand to protect the latter’s profits over the public good.”
curated_info.title: How Pharma Hides Data About Farm Antibiotic Use

curated_info.author: Ferris Jabr
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “Industrial production has made wheat less nutritious and less flavorful. This profile of the director of Washington State University’s Bread Lab, argues for one way to fix it.”
curated_info.title: Bread is Broken

curated_info.author: Nell Porter Brown
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “Two members of the Harvard class of 2013 are growing high-quality mushrooms to serve a market looking for ingredients that can take the place of meat.”
curated_info.title: Are Mushrooms the New Meat?

curated_info.author: Michael Frank
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “That cheap produce you see at your local megamart wouldn’t be so inexpensive if pickers had higher pay and better working conditions — and it wouldn’t be so available without immigrant labor, much of it undocumented.”
curated_info.title: Can America’s Farms Survive the Threat of Deportations?

curated_info.author: Dana Goodyear
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “Driscoll’s made strawberries a ubiquitous, year-round product by breeding them for looks, size, and durability — not flavor.”
curated_info.title: How Driscoll’s Reinvented the Strawberry

curated_info.author: Multiple authors
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “This series of essays looks at different aspects of the future of our global food supply, including climate change, a growing income gap, and failing regulatory standards.”
curated_info.title: The Future of Food

curated_info.author: Dan Barber
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “Four companies control 60% of the world’s seed sales — a disaster for both our palates and the biodiversity that our planet and diet need.”
curated_info.title: Save Our Food. Free the Seed.

curated_info.author: Paul Tullis
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “A fungus is attacking banana plantations, and scientists are racing to engineer a replacement, which may mean all the bananas in tomorrow’s supermarket will be genetically modified.”
curated_info.title: Bananapocalypse: The Race to Save the World’s Most Popular Fruit

curated_info.author: Michael Paul Light
curated_info.excerpt: KL: “Examining the future of the high-quality, small-batch coffee movement and how a ‘fourth wave’ should include more people in the drive for better coffee.”
curated_info.title: Trish Rothgeb Coined ‘Third Wave’ — And is Now Looking Toward Coffee’s Future

collections.description: Welcome to What I’m Reading, a special series in which we invite interesting people to handpick articles around a theme of their choice.
collections.title: What I’m Reading: The Future of Food

curated_info.author: Bryan Walsh
curated_info.excerpt: “One of my favorite writers (and thinkers) allows you into his mind just a bit.”
curated_info.title: Chuck Klosterman In Winter (Okay, Mid-Autumn)

curated_info.author: Mina Kimes
curated_info.excerpt: “The quarterback trying to turn around my hometown Cleveland Browns.”
curated_info.title: Baker Mayfield Isn’t Afraid of the Hype

curated_info.author: David Segal
curated_info.excerpt: “A look at the legacy of James Daunt as he takes on perhaps his … most daunting task to date (sorry, had to!).”
curated_info.title: Can Britain’s Top Bookseller Save Barnes & Noble?

curated_info.author: Tom McTague
curated_info.excerpt: “Tom McTague writes about Boris Johnson after his landslide victory in the UK a few weeks back.”

curated_info.author: Jon Caramanica
curated_info.excerpt: “Much nostalgia for the once kings of dad rock.”
curated_info.title: Hootie & the Blowfish, Great American Rock Band (Yes, Really)

curated_info.excerpt: “A surprisingly refreshing and candid chat with Keanu Reeves.”
curated_info.title: ‘Grief and loss, those things don’t ever go away’

curated_info.author: David Marchese
curated_info.excerpt: “An even more surprising and refreshing chat with Stephen Colbert.”
curated_info.title: The Political Targets of Satire
